PAGE: 1
HEADING: WACHENDORFF

Wachendorff, Evert Jacob van (1702-1758), Dutch physician and botanist; studied
medicine in Leiden and Utrecht; Dr. med. 1724; municipal physician of Utrecht 1726-
1758; lecturer in chemistry at the University 1726-1743; professor of medicine, chemistry
and botany 1743-1758. (<em>Wachendorff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material in LINN. – Seeds and (or?) dried plants sent to
Linnaeus, fide preface Sp. pl. ed. 2, 1763. – <em>Letters</em> in G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 446 (d. 23 Dec 1748, sic err. for 1758); BM
5: 2244; Dryander 3: 105, 192; Herder p. 152; Jackson p. 441; JW 4: 413, 5: 255; NNBW
5: 1083 (b. 2 Nov 1903, d. 22 Dec 1758) (Römer); PR 9889-9890, ed. 1: 10862-10863;
Rehder 1: 51; SO 632e; TL-2/931, W.H. de Vriese.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Adanson, M., Fam. pl. 1: lix-lxiii, 27. 1763.
Anon., Wachendorffia 1(1): I. 1972 (portr.).
Bisset, N.G. &amp; D. Philcox, Taxon 20: 538-539. 1971 (on Strychnos colubrina).
Burdet, H.M. et al., Ouvr. bot. anc. no. 531. 1985.
Fries, Th.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(4): 208. 1910, 1(6): 87. 1912.
Haller, A. v., Bibl. bot. 2: 366-367. 1772.
Helbergen, G.A.P. van, Wachendorffia 3(4): 41-44. 1975 (on portrait and family).
Hulth, J.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 2(1): 99, 100. 1916; with A.H. Uggla 2(2): 100, 101,
	134, 136. 1943.
J., Dict. sci. méd., Biogr. méd. 7: 454-455. 1825.
Jackson, B.D., Proc. Linn. Soc. 134 (suppl.): 20. 1922 (herb. mat. in LINN).
Kuijlen, J. et al., Paradisus batavus 17, 159, 160. 1983.
Linnaeus, C., Sp. pl. ed. 2: [vi]. 1762.
Moehsen, J.C.W., Verz. Samml. Bildn. 2: 143. 1771 (mentions a portrait).
Sprengel, K.P.J., Gesch. Bot. 2: 247-248. 1818.
Stafleu, F.A., <em>in</em> G.H.M. Lawrence et al., Adanson 1: 161, 164. 1963 (Adanson's dis-
	cussion of index); Linnaeus and the Linnaeans 45, 166, 171-173, 194. 1971.
Terken-Vos, L., Wachendorffia 5(2): 17-20. 1977 (biogr. not.).
Visser, R.P.W., <em>in</em> Essays in Biohistory (Regnum vegetabile 7) 401. 1970.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm> (journal): <em>Wachendorffia</em>, Chronica Horti Botanici Rheno-Trajectini, Utrecht,
vol. 1-7. 1972-1981; (genera): <em>Wachendorfia</em> J. Burman (1757).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Candollea 34: 191-192. 1979.

16.460. Everardi Jacobi van Wachendorff <em>Oratio botanico-medica</em> de plantis, inmensitatis
intellectus divini testibus locupletissimis; publice habita, quam ordinariam medicinae,
botanices &amp; chemiae professionem susciperet. Die xxvi. Septemb. [1743]. Trajecti ad
Rhenum [Utrecht] (apud Joannem Broedelet, ...) 1743. Qu. (<em>Orat. bot. -med</em>.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1743, p. [i, iii], 1 -55. <em>Copy</em>: U.

16.461. <em>Horti ultrajectini index</em>, ... Trajecti ad Rhenum [Utrecht] (apud Nicolaum van
Vucht, ...) 1747. Oct. (in 4-s). (<em>Hort. ultraject. index</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1747, p. [i*-xiv*], [i]-xxx, [1-4, expl. nom. auct.], [1, h.t.], 1-394, [1-24 indexes].
	<em>Copies</em>: B-S, BR, G, M, NY, U(2). - See J. Kuijlen (1983) no. 108 for analytical
	collation.
<em>Editio nova</em>: 1758 fide G.R. Boehmer, Bibl. hist. nat. 3(1): 253. 1787 (n.v.); Boehmer is
	the only source known to us mentioning this "edition").
<em>Ref</em>.: Ehrhart, F., <em>Beitr. Naturk</em>.6: 1-13. 1791 (explanation of W.'s botanical
	terminology).

Wachter, Willem Hendrik (1882-1946), Dutch botanist and high school teacher;
studied at the teacher's college of Rotterdam (teacher's exam. 1901); teacher at various
schools in Rotterdam 1901-1936; active floristic botanist and bryologist; Dr. h.c. Utrecht
1946. (<em>Wacht</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L. – Other material AMD, H-BR, U. – <em>Letters</em> in G.

PAGE: 2
HEADING: WACHENDORFF

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(1): 347, 12(3): 476; Backer p. 619; Barnhart 3: 446
(b. 5 Dec 1882, d. 1 Sep 1946); BL 2: 423, 424, 425, 729; Bossert p. 422; Hirsch p. 313;
IH 2: 313; JW 1: 452, 2: 203; NI 3: 52, 65; TL-2/2284, 2727, 2733; see S.J. van
Ooststroom.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Biologia 1(1): [4]. 1947 (d.); Rev. bryol. lichénol. 18(1-2): 85. 1949.
Jacobs, M.J., Herman Johannes Lam (1892-1977): 99, 121, 144. 1984.
Jansen, P., Ned. kruidk. Arch. 56: 52-58. 1949 (obit., portr.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 768. 1985.
Mennema, J., Blumea 25: 117. 1979 (coll.).
Ooststroom, S.J. van, <em>in</em> Heukels-van Ooststroom, Fl. Nederl. ed. 14. 5-6. 1956 (biogr.
	sketch; eds. 13-19).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (coll.).
Steenis-Kruseman, M.J. van, Blumea 25: 48. 1979.

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 367. 1935.
Wachter, W.H., Ned. kruidk. Arch. 55: 12-116, 134-185. 1946 (history Ned. bot. Ver.).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor and in part author of H. Heukels, <em>Geill. Schoolfl. Nederl.</em> eds.
11-12, 1934, 1942, see TL-2/2727.
(2) Co-author with H. Heukels, but in fact virtually sole author of H. Heukels and W.H.
Wachter, <em>Bekn. Schoolfl. Nederl.</em> eds. 1-5. 1932-1946, see TL-2/2733.

16.464. <em>Naamlijst der Nederlandsche Levermossen</em> ... Amsterdam (N.V. Drukkerij en Uitge-
verij J.H. de Bussy) 1932. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 4 Apr 1932 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. [528]-532. <em>Copy</em>: U. – Reprinted and to be
	cited from Ned. kruidk. Arch. 41(3): [528]-532. 1932. – See also W.H. Wachter &amp; W.
	Meijer, <em>Inleiding tot de Nederlandsche levermosflora</em>, ib. 58: 110-120. 1951.

16.465. <em>De mossen van Jean Lambert Franquinet</em> ... Overdruk uit het Natuurhistorisch
Maandblad ... Maastricht 1932. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 28 Oct and 30 Nov 1932 (in journal), cover-t.p., p. 1-9. <em>Copy</em>: U. – Reprinted and
	to be cited from Natuurh. Maandbl. 21(10): 131-136. 28 Oct, 21(11): 138-141. 30
	Nov 1932.

Wacker, Hermann (x-1899), German (Prussian) high school teacher and botanist in
Kulm, later in Berlin. (<em>Wacker</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

HEADING: A. WADE

Waddell, Coslett Herbert (1858-1919), British clergyman and botanist; studied at
Trinity College, Dublin; ordained 1880; rector Saintfield and Grey Abbey (County
Down); secretary Moss Exchange Club 1896-1903. (<em>Waddell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DBN (10.000 bryo.), BEL (phan.); other material in BM(K)
(algae), BON, BRISTM, CGE, E, EBH, GALW, K, NMW, OXF. – <em>Notebooks</em> at BEL;
<em>letters</em> in FH, G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 446; BB p. 311; BM 5: 2244; Clokie p. 260;
CSP 19: 423-424; Desmond p. 632 (b. 6 Mar 1858, d. 8 Jun 1919); LS 28.127-28.128,
40.343.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., B.C.G. (Biology curators group), Newsletter 2(9): 415. 1981 (herb.
	donated to BEL by his widow in 1919); J. Bot. 57: 358. 1919 (obit. not.).
Bridson, G.D.R., Nat. hist. mss. resources 33.9. 1980.
Druce, G.C., Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isl. 5(5): 629-630. 1920 (obit. not.).
Hackney, P., Irish Natural. J. 17(7): 232, 233. 1972 (material BEL).
Kent, D.H., Brit. herb. 83. 1957 (herb. [phan.] at BEL).
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 264. 1984.
Knowles, M.C., Proc. R. Irish Acad. 38(B-10): 187, 188. 1929.
Praeger, R.L., Proc. R. Irish Acad. 7: cxlvi. 1901 (list publ.), Irish Natural. 28: 108.
	1919; Botanist in Ireland 78. 1934; Some Irish naturalists 172. 1949.
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (coll.).
Synnot, D.M., Glasra 4: 30. 1980 (bryoph. herb., 10.000 at DBN).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: <em>Lichens</em>, p. 140-144, <em>in</em> H. Hanna et al., <em>A guide to Belfast and the Counties
of Donn and Antrim</em>, Belfast 1902.

16.467. <em>Moss Exchange Club Catalogue of British Hepaticae</em> ... London (W. Wesley &amp; Son,
...) 1897. Oct. (<em>Moss Exch. Club Cat. Hepat.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Sep 1897 (J. Bot. Oct 1897; Hedwigia Nov-Dec 1897; Nat. Nov. Oct(2) 1897), p.
	[1]-7, [8]. <em>Copies</em>: G, NY.

16.468. <em>A census catalogue of British mosses</em>, with list of the botanical vice counties and their
boundaries, and lists of sources of records, compiled, ... York (Coultas and Volans, ...)
1907. Oct. (<em>Census cat. Brit. Moss.</em>).

<em>Authors</em>: Thomas Barker (1838-1907), William Ingham (1854-1923), Daniel Angell Jones
	(1861-1936), C.H. Waddell, Henry William Lett (1838-1920), Ernst Marquand
	(1848-1918). Introductory notes by Hugh Neville Dixon (1861-1944).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1907 (p. 4: 26 Jul 1907), p.[1]-63 (printed on one side). <em>Copies</em>: DBN, NY.

Wade, Arthur Edward (1895-x), British botanist; on active service World War I; at

PAGE: 4
HEADING: W. WADE

the National Museum of Wales, Cardiff 1920-1961; in retirement in Rotorua, New
Zealand; M.Sc. Univ. Wales 1958 (h.c). (<em>A. Wade</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NMW. – Other material in F, K, M, OXF (see also Kent &amp;
Allen 1984). – <em>Letters</em> in G and NY (Barnhart corr.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 446; BL 2: 314, 316, 319, 321, 322, 729;
Clokie p. 260; GR p. 384, <em>pl</em>. [<em>34</em>], cat. p. 73; IH 1 (ed. 2): 39, (ed. 3): 45, (ed. 4): 48,
(ed. 5): 42; (ed. 6): 55, 365, (ed. 7): 345; NI 2: 264; Roon p. 119; SBC p. 134; TL-
2/3174, 10.147.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 436. 1969; Rev. bryol. lichénol. 18:
	96, 192. 1949, 22: 116. 1953, 24: 172. 1955, 25: 206. 1956, 30: 183: 1961, 34: 974.
	1967 (note on publ.).
Bridson, G.D.R., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 84.19, 84.20. 1980.
Ellis, G., Amgueddfa 16: 14-15. 1974; Nature in Wales 15(1): 22-23. 1976 (80th
	birthday).

	also 42, autumn 1985 (note 90th birthday); Index coll. Welsh natl. Herb. 108-109.
	1986.

	(bibl. lich.).

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 178. 1935, 3: 158. 1937, 4: 533. 1938.
Wood, R.D., Monogr. Charac. 1: 847. 1965.

<em>Publ</em>.: Jun 1926, cover-t.p., p. 999-1027. <em>Copy</em>: G. – Reprinted and to be cited from Brit.
	Exch. Club Rep. 1925: 999-1027. 1926.

Wade, Walter (1760-1825), Irish botanist and physician practicing in Dublin; profes-
sor of botany for the Dublin Society; founder and director of the Botanical Garden of the
Society, now National Botanic Garden, Glasnevin 1794-1825. (<em>Wade</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DBN (specimens in Hortus gramineus glasnevensis 1818), LINN
(J.E. Smith herb.). – <em>Letters</em> to J.E. Smith in LINN.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 447; BB p. 312; BL 2: 286, 729; BM 5: 2244-
2245; Bossert p. 422; CSP 6: 221; DNB 58: 421 (20: 421-422) (G.S. Boulger); Dryander
3: 648; Henrey 2: 155, 156, 203, 3: 131-132; Jackson p. 125, 141, 143, 247, 251, 411; PR
9891-9895, ed. 1: 10865-10869; Rehder 5: 895; TL-2/5957, 15.549, see J.E. Smith;
Tucker 1: 726-727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 251: 316. 1965.
Crone, J.S., Conc. dict. Irish biogr. ed. 2. 257. 1937.

PAGE: 5
HEADING: W. WADE

Dawson, W.R., Smith papers 94. 1934.
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 264. 1984 (coll.).
Knowles, M.C., Proc. R. Irish Acad. 38(B)(10): 181. 1929.
Lett, H.W., Proc. R. Irish Acad. 32: 68-69. 1914-1916.
Nelson, E.C., Newslett. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 1:9, 10. 1979; Long Room 20-21: 16-21.
	1980 (on Flora dublinensis); Glasra 5: 1-20. 1981 (bibl.; copies at DBN); Occas. Pap.
	Natl. Bot. Gard. Glasnevin 122. 1982; Arch. nat. Hist. 10: 538. 1982.
Praeger, R.L., Proc. R. Irish Acad. 7: cxlvi. 1901; Botanist in Ireland 78. 1939; Some
	Irish naturalists 173. 1949.
Scully, R.W., Fl. County Kerry xii. 1916.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Published: <em>Quercus or oaks</em>: from the French of [A.] Michaux "Histoire
des chênes de l'Amérique septentrionale" [TL-2/5957], Trans. Dublin Soc. 6, 1810
(annotated); xxi, [ix], 85 [1] p.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) For a detailed bibliography of Wade's writings see E.C. Nelson (1981). For
Wade's projected <em>Flora dublinensis</em> of which only a sample was printed and distributed to
a small number of bookshops see Nelson (1980).
(2) A <em>Catalogus plantarum rariorum in comitatu Gallovidiae, praecipue Cunnemara inventarum</em>: ...
was published by Wade in Trans. Dublin Soc. 2(2): [103]-127. 1802. No separate issue
of this is known to E.C. Nelson.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wadea</em> Rafinesque (1838) may honor this author but no derivation was given.

16.470. <em>Catalogus systematicus plantarum</em> indigenarum in Comitatu Dublinensi inventarum.
Pars prima ... Dublini [Apud Gul. Sleater, ...] 1794. †. Oct. (in 4-s). (<em>Cat. syst. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1794 (Wade sent a copy to J.E. Smith on 20 Sep 1794; the book is not mentioned
	by name), p. [i]-viii, [1]-275, [277-306]. <em>Copies</em>: DNB, HH, MO, NY. – N. Colgan, Fl.
	county Dublin, p. xxiv, 1904, mentions a projected, but never published second part.

16.471. <em>Catalogue of plants</em> in the arboretum, fruticetum, herbarium, gramina vera, hortus
tinctorius, hot &amp; greenhouses of the Dublin Society's botanic garden at <em>Glasnevin ...
</em>Dublin (printed by Graisberry and Campbell, ...) 1802. Oct. (in fours). (<em>Cat. pl.
Glasnevin</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: anonymous; attributed to John Underwood by BM 5: 2163 (with reference to
	an earlier edition of 1800), to Walter Wade by E.C. Nelson 1982; see also under TL-
	2/15.549.
<em>Publ</em>.: 1802, p. [i], [1]-137. <em>Copies</em>: G, LIV. – Printed separately and issued with Trans.
	R. Dubl. Soc. 2(2). 1802. Continuation see below, <em>Syst. cat. Glasnevin.</em> See Nelson
	(1981) no. 10.

16.472. <em>Systematic catalogue</em> of green and hothouse plants, in the Dublin Society's botan-
ical garden at <em>Glasnevin</em>; with their scientific name, common name, country or native
soil, time of flowering, and whether annual, biennal, perennial, tree or shrub. Dublin
(printed by Graisberry &amp; Campbell ...) 1801 [1802]. (<em>Syst. cat. Glasnevin</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: anonymous; attributed to W. Wade by Nelson (1981, p. 9).
<em>Publ</em>.: 1802 (even though dated 1801, see Nelson (1981), no. 10), p. [139]-247. <em>Copies</em>:
	Amer, philos. Soc, G, LIV. – Pagination continued from <em>Cat. pl. Glasnevin</em> (above);
	also issued with Trans. Dublin Soc. 2(2).

16.473. <em>Plantae rariores in Hibernia</em> inventae; or habitats of some plants, rather scarce and
valuable found in Ireland; with concise remarks on the properties and uses of many of
them ... Dublin (printed by Graisberry and Campbell, ...) 1804. Oct. (<em>Pl. rar.
Hibernia</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Jul 1804 (p. [v]: 23 Jun 1804; copy sent to J.E. Smith 7 Aug 1804), frontisp., p.
	[i]-xiv, [xv-xvi], [1]-214. <em>Copies</em>: BR, DBN, G, HH, NY, USDA. – Also published,
	with two other papers, in Trans. Dubl. Soc. 4, 1804. – See Nelson (1981) no. 13.

16.474. <em>Salices</em> or an essay towards a general history of Sallows, Willows &amp; Osiers, their

PAGE: 6
HEADING: W. WADE

uses, and best methods of propagating and cultivating them ... Dublin (Graisberry &amp;
Campbell) 1811. Oct (in 4-s). (<em>Salices</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1811 (p. [iii]: Mar 1811), frontisp., p. [i]-xxii, [1]-7, [1], [2], [1]-406, [1]-56.
	<em>Copies</em>: B-S, DBN, G, HH, MO, NY, USDA.

Wächter, Wilhelm (1870-1928), German (Schleswig-Holstein) botanist; student
pharmacist in Hamburg, Hildburghausen, Frankfurt a. M. and Kolberg; state
examination pharmacy München; Dr. phil. Rostock 1897; assistant with K. Goebel
1897-1901, with Wieler in Aachen 1901-1903; with W. Pfeffer in Leipzig 1903-1905;
with Karl A.E. Müller in Berlin at the plant physiological laboratory of the Gardener's
College at Dahlem 1905-1907; with L. Kny at Botanical Institute of the College for
Agriculture ib. 1907-1909 (as guest 1909-1921), scientist at the Prussian Institute for
environmental control (Inst. Wasser-, Boden-, Lufthygiene) from 1909-1918; secretary
of the Deutsche botanische Gesellschaft 1907-1921; ultimately active as private scientist
in München. (<em>Wächter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Johann Karl Augustin Wächter (1773-1846) was a German (Mecklenburg-
Schwerin) forester in the Kingdom of Hannover (see R. Hoss, Lebensbild. hervorr.
Forstmänn., Berlin 1885, p. 387-388).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 447 (b. 23 Mar 1870, d. 26 Jun 1928); Biol.-
Dokum. 18: 9671; BJI 2: 185; GR p. 52, cat. p. 73; Hirsch p. 313; LS 28123, 40345-
40348.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 68: (48). 1928 (d.); Österr. bot. Ges. 77: 240. 1928 (d.).

Wächter, W., Apotheker Zeit. 1927 (88), 5 p. "Königsberger Getöse. Eine freundliche
	Abwehr", (polemics on serodiagnostics).

Waga, Jakub [Jakob] Ignacy (1800-1872), Polish botanist; student of Michel Szubert;
Mag. phil. Warsaw 1825; high school teacher at Warsaw, Radom and Szczuczyn; from
1828 at Lomza; school inspector ib. 1854-1862. (<em>Waga</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Owned a herbarium, in 1880 with his widow in Lomza.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 207; Barnhart 3: 447 (d. 23 Feb 1872); BM 5:
2245; Bossert p. 422; Herder p. 202; Jackson p. 330; PR 9897, p. 359; Rehder 1: 73, 361,
4: 427; TR 314; Tucker 2: xxxix.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1873: 28 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 30: "132" [is 232] 1872 (d.); Österr.
	bot. Z. 22: 238. 1872 (d.); Ottuv slovník naucny 27: 95. 1908; Wielka encykl. powss-
	zechna pwn 12: 75. 1969 (b. 25 Jul 1800).
Bourdeille de Montrésor, Bull. Soc. Imp. Natural. Moscou ser. 2. 7: 479-482. 1894
	(bibl.).
Candolle, Alph. de, Phytographie 457. 1880 (herb. with widow).
Hryniewiecki, B., Acta Soc. bot. Pol. 20 (suppl.): 33-45. 1951 (biogr., portr., b. 25 Jul
	1800).
J.R., Bot. Zeit. 30: 524-525. 1872 (obit. note and brief rev. of his Historja roslin).
Karpowiczowa, L., 150 Lat ogrodu botanicz. uniw. Warszaw. 8, 11. 1967 (photograph
	of bust).
Orgelbrand, S., Encykl. powsszechna 15: 105. 1903.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) Antoni Waga (1799-1890) published an alphabetical index of Polish plant
names: Ukaziciel Polskich nazwisk na rodzaje królestwa roslinnego, Warsawa 1846 [?],
p. [i]-xxx, [1]-336, added by J. Waga to his <em>Fl. polon. Phan.</em>, see below.
(2) J. Waga published a Polish version (greatly enlarged and in many aspects almost an
independent work) of Guillaume Louis Figuier (1819-1894), <em>Histoire des plantes</em>, Paris

1865 (xv, 531 p.). Polish: <em>Historja roslin</em>, 3 vols. 1871-1872, not seen by us; see J.R., Bot.

Wagener, Philipp Christian (<em>fl</em>. 1798), German botanist. (<em>Wagener</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 447; PR 9898, ed. 1: 10871; Rehder 1: 375.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wageneria</em> Klotzsch (1854) honors H. Wagener, a German collector of plants
in Venezuela (see below).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Hermann Wagener(1823-1877), Orchid collector in Venezuela and Colombia
(see e.g. K.S. Levonsen, Orchid Rev. 82: 348-352. 1974) who did not publish himself on
his collections. See D.F.L. von Schlechtendal, <em>Plantae Wagenerianae Columbiae</em> in Linnaea
25: 743-750. Dec 1853, 26: 127-144. Apr 1854, and 26: 631-674. Sep 1855 and H.G.
Reichenbach, Bonplandia 2: 9-26. 15 Jan 1854, 3: 65-72. 15 Mar 1855. See also H.
Pittier, <em>Manual de las plantas usuales de Venezuela</em> 1926, p. 5.

Hildesheim wildwachsenden Pflanzen ... Istes Zehend. Hildesheim (Gedruckt mit
Schlegelschen Schriften) 1798. Fol. (<em>Fl. Hildesheim</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1798, cover, p. [i-viii], <em>pl. 1-10</em> (col. copp.). <em>Copy</em>: NY.

Wager, Horace Athelstan (1876-1951), English botanist; went to South Africa 1903;
professor of botany and zoology Transvaal University College (later Pretoria Univers-
ity). (<em>Wager</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PRE. – Some further material (mosses) in BM (incl. some
holotypes), H.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Lenley p. 426; SBC p. 134.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 125. 1978.
Gunn, M. &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. expl. S. Afr. 366. 1981 (portr; main data).
Sayre, G., Bryologist 80: 519. 1977 (coll.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wageria</em> F.L. Stevens et Dalbey (1918).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) H.A. Wager's son, Vincent Athelstan Wager (b. 1904) published on phytopa-
thology and mycology, see E. Doidge, Bothalia 5: 1027. 1950. Herbarium material at
PRE.
(2) Harold William Taylor Wager (1882-1929), lecturer in botany, Yorkshire College of

Waghorne, Arthur Charles (1851-1900), British missionary and botanist; educated at
Canterbury for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel to Newfoundland 1875;
ordained Queen's College St. John's 1875 (deacon), 1878 (priest); mission priest in
Newfoundland, St. Pierre and Miquelon and Labrador until 1899; in retirement on
Jamaica 1899-1900. (<em>Waghorne</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at A, B (mainly destr.), BM, BUC, CUP, DBN, F, M,
MIN, MO, MTMG, NY, NYS, OXF, PH, QK, S, US, Z. – <em>Letters</em> at G, GH, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 447; BB p. 312; BL 1: 140, 323; BM 5: 2245;
Clokie p. 260; CSP 19: 428; Desmond p. 632 (d. 11 Apr 1900, Jamaica); Lenley p. 426;
Rehder 3: 262; Tucker 1: 727; Urban-Berl. p. 316.

Anon., Bot. Gaz. 18: 325-326. 1893 (Newfoundland and Labrador Sphagna for sale,
	named by D.C. Eaton and C.F. Warnstorf; prospectus 3 p.); Hedwigia 38: (114).
	1899 (Labrador and Newfoundland plants for sale); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966.

Wagner, Adolf (1869-1940), Austrian botanist; Dr. phil. Innsbruck 1893; assistant at
the Innsbruck botanical institute 1900-1906; Habil. Innsbruck 1901; extraordinary pro-
fessor of botany Innsbruck 1909; ord. professor ib. 1918-1936. (<em>A. Wagner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

	prof. bot. Innsbruck), 67: 312, 404. 1918 (ord. id.).

Wagner, D. (1800-?), Austro-Hungarian pharmacist and botanist; Dr. chem. Wien
1825; pharmacist in Pressburg (Bratislava) subsequently in Pesth (Budapest) until 1864.
(<em>D. Wagner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 448; BM 5: 2246; Kanitz p. 95, 96 (no. 140);
NI 2091; Plesch p. 453; PR 9899, ed. 1: 10873; Rehder 3: 56; Sotheby 799; WU 52: 93-
94 (bibl.).

16.482. <em>Pharmaceutisch-medicinische Botanik</em>, oder Beschreibung und Abbildung aller in der
k.k. österreichischen Pharmacopoe vom Jahre 1820 vorkommenden Arzneypflanzen, in
botanischer, pharmaceutischer, historischer und chemischer Beziehung, mit besonderer
Rücksicht auf die botanische und pharmaceutische Synonymie, und Verfälschung oder
Verwechslung der Abgehandelten Arzneystoffe; mit getreuen, genau nach der Natur
gezeichneten und ausgemahlten Abbildungen ... Wien (Auf Kosten und im Verlag des
Verfassers ...) 1828-1829. Fol. (<em>Pharm. - med. Bot.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1828, p. [i-viii, dated Jul 1829], lvs. text 1-103.
<em>2</em>: 1829, p. [i], lvs. 104-216.
<em>Plates</em>: <em>249</em> col. liths.
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, NY. – Issued in Hefte containing 8 liths. with accompanying text.

Wagner, Hermann (of Weissenfels) (1824-1879), German (Saxonian) high school
teacher and botanist; teacher at Weissenfels 1846; assistant teacher at the girls school of
the Frankische Stiftung, Halle 1850; teacher at the higher girls school Bielefeld 1851-
1857; from 1857-1863 in charge of a department of the Verlagsbuchhandlung Spamer in
Reudnitz near Leipzig and later living from the sale of his herbaria in Neuschönfeld;
retired from teaching because of loss of hearing. (<em>H. Wagner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Most holdings of herbaria consist of sets or partial sets of his
series of exsiccatae. Our information is incomplete.
(1) <em>Cryptogamen-Herbarium</em>, Bielefeld 1852-1862, fasc. 1-9, 25 specimens per fascicle (1-5:
1852-1854; ser. 2. 6-10. 1854-1862); Sets at B (mainly destr.), BM, BPI, BUC, DPU,
FH, H, MANCH, NY, S. – For accompanying text see <em>Führ. Crypt</em>. below. See Sayre
(1969).
(2) <em>Gras-Herbarium</em>, Lief. 1-8, nos. 1-201, Bielefeld 1855. A third edition is mentioned in
the periodical literature 1880-1884 (10 Lief.).
(3) <em>Phanerogamen-Herbarium</em>, Lief. 1-8, nos. 1-200. 1857-1858.
(4) <em>Arznei- und Giftgewächse</em>, Lief. 1-5, nos. 1-125.
(5) <em>Alpenstrauss</em>, enthaltend die schönsten Gewächse der Alpen. Bielefeld, s.d., 50
specimens.

PAGE: 10
HEADING: H. WAGNER

1879); Herder p. 62, 96, 189, 267, 278; Jackson p. 50, 52, 54, 59, 133, 148, 221, 294; PR
9900-9904; Tucker 1: 727, 3: 321; Urban-Berl. p. 407.

16.485. <em>Die Pflanzendecke der Erde</em> in pflanzengeographischen Bildern and Schilderungen

Wagner, Hermann (of Hadamar) (1824-1908 (1882?)), German (Hessen) botanist
and teacher; studied at the University of Göttingen 1843-1846, in Berlin 1846-1847;

PAGE: 11
HEADING: J. WAGNER

assistant teacher at the Gymnasium of Weilburg 1848-1851; id. at Dillenburg 1850-
1852; id. at Wiesbaden 1852, teacher at Weilburg 1858, conrector Weilburg 1859-1861;
at the "höhere Bürgerschule" (high school) of Wiesbaden 1861; in charge of the
Realschule at Diez 1863; rector of the Real-Progymnasium Bad-Ems 1866. (<em>H. Wagner
II</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Matrikel des Gymnasium Philipp. Weilburg 2: 306. s.d.; Programm
	Realschule Ems 9 u. 10 Apr 1867, id. Diel 12 Apr 1867, id. Limburg 15-16 Apr 1867,
	p. 8.
Löber, K., Pfl. Grenzgeb. Westerwald Rothaar, Göttingen 1972 (curr. vit., b.
	27.10.1824, d. "1882"; however no definite indication that his various post-1882 publ.
	were posthumous).

16.486. <em>Illustrirte deutsche Flora</em>. Eine Beschreibung der in Deutschland und der Schweiz
einheimischen Blüthenpflanzen und Gefässcryptogamen ... Stuttgart (Julius Hoffmann
...) [1869-] 1871. Oct. (<em>Ill. deut. Fl.</em>).

<em>Ed. 1</em>: 1869-1871, 16 Lieferungen of 64 p. <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HH, M, NY.
	<em>Preface material</em>: 1871, p. [i]-lxvviii.
	<em>Erste Hälfte</em>: Mar 1869-Mai 1870, p. [1]-496. – Published in 8 parts; livr. 1: Mar 1869;
	livr. 3-4.(p. 129-240) Aug-Oct 1869, livr. 5-8 publ. Mai 1870.
	<em>Zweite Hälfte</em>: Mai 1870-Jun 1871, p. [i], 497-939, [940, err.]. – Published in 8 parts
	(part 9 publ. Mai 1870; 10: Oct 1870; 11-16 publ. by 15 Jun 1871).
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1881-1882 (20 Lieferungen Apr 1881-Mai 1882), p. [iii]-lxxx, [1]-914. <em>Copies</em>: B,
	G, HH, MO, NY. – Bearbeitet und vermehrt von ... August Garcke [see TL-2/1:
	912-914]. Stuttgart (Verlag für Naturkunde ...) s.d. Oct.
<em>Ed. 3</em>: [1903]-1905 (16 Lieferungen Jun 1903-1905), p. [i]-xxxix, [xl], [1]-792. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	H, HH, NY, U. – Dritte Auflage nach der von ... August Garcke besorgten 2.
	Auflage neu durchgesehen und verbessert. Stuttgart (Verlag für Naturkunde ...).
	Oct.
<em>Note</em>: Our attribution of this publication to Hermann Wagner of Hadamar, is tentative.
	The circumstance that Garcke undertook the revision of ed. 2 in 1881-1882 is not in
	line with activities of the Wagner of Hadamar. It seems also less likely that the first
	edition was by H. Wagner of Weissenfels.

Wagner, János [Johannes] (1870-1955), Hungarian (Banat-born) botanist and high

PAGE: 12
HEADING: J. WAGNER

school teacher; studied at the teacher's college at Znióváralja; teacher in Csáktornya,
Kiskunfélogyhaza and 1901-1911 in Arad; from 1911-1914 teacher at a girls school in
Budapest; school inspector 1914, general inspector of the teacher's college in Hungary
1919-1928; Dr. h.c. Szeged 1953; Dr. biol. sci. h.t. 1952. (<em>J. Wagner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BP (see Vöröss 1984); further material in A, AK, C, DBN, E,
GB, MANCH, NH, PR, U.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Tiliae exsiccatae criticae</em> 1929-1934, 5 fasc., 250 nos. (see <em>Die Linden des historischen
Ungarns</em>, Mitt. deut. dendrol. Ges. 44: 316-345. 1932, 45: 5-60. 1933). Set at K. –
Wagner's monograph of Hungarian Tilia ("<em>Magyarország hársai</em>") was published in
Kertészeti Közlem. 7-10, 1941-1944.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 708; BM 5: 2246; CSP 19: 431; Hirsch p. 314;
LS 28162; Rehder 5: 897; Tucker 3: 324; Zander ed. 10, p. 729.

Krücken, O. &amp; I. Parlagi, Das geistige Ungarn 715-716. 1918.
Vörös, L.Z., Studia bot. hung. 17: 69-72. 1984 (on W.'s Tilia herbarium).

Wagner, Moritz Friedrich (1813-1887), German (Bavarian) traveller, botanist and
zoologist; travelled in Algeria (1836-1838), in Caucasia, Armenia and Persia (1844,
1850, 1852, 1855); in North and Central America (1853-1854), Panama and Ecuador
(1857-1860); professor of geography and ethnography at München from 1862, also
curator of the München ethnographic museum. (<em>M. Wagner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M (Caucasia; Panama 1858-1860, Ecuador 1859); other material
in BR, FI (Ecuador), GOET (Caucas., Armen., Crimea).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 40: 532-543 (F. Ratzel); Backer p. 619; Barnhart 3:

p. 33, 62; Jackson p. 101; PR 9906; Rehder 5: 897; Tucker 1: 727.

Wahl, Carl Georg von (1869-?), Baltic German (Livonian) botanist; studied natural
sciences at Dorpat 1890-1893; botany at Berlin 1893-1896, student of A. Engler, K.
Schumann, S. Schwendener; Dr. phil. Berlin 1896; later head of the botanical division of
the "Badische Staatliche Landwirtschaftliche Versuchsanstalt Augustenberg near
Karlsruhe. (<em>C. Wahl</em>).

Wahlberg, Pehr Fredrik (1800-1877), Swedish botanist, physician and pharmacist;
Dr. phil. Uppsala 1824 with C.P. Thunberg, Dr. med. ib. 1827; associate professor of
materia medica and natural history at the Karolinska Institut, Stockholm 1827-1836;
regular professor of materia medica 1836-1865; secretary of the Swedish Academy of
Sciences 1848-1866; travelled widely in Scandinavia between 1819 and 1857 and in S.
Europe 1828-1830. (<em>Wahlb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S; further material in BR, LZ, UPS-Thunb. – <em>Letters</em> to Elias
Fries in KVA-Stockholm (200) and UPS-UB (110).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 6(1): 646; Backer p. 619; Barnhart 3: 449; BL 2: 521,
729; BM 5: 2249; Bossert p. 423; CSP 6: 233-234, 12: 767; Herder p. 196; Hortus 3:
1206; KR p. 739-741 (b. 19 Jun 1800, d. 22 Mai 1877); NI 2: 273, no. 2223; PR 9318,
9381, 9908-9909, ed. 1: 10287-10299, 10879-10880, 11827; Rehder 5: 897; TL-1/947;
TL-2/14.403, 14.425, see Thunberg, C.P.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Biogr. Lexic. 19: 150-154. 1852 (detailed biogr., bibl.); Bot. Not. 1845:
	62, 174, 1877: 125 (obit.), 1883: 106; Flora 12(1): 95-96. 1829 (continental trip).
Afzelius, K., Nordisk familjebok ed. 3. 19: 1283. 1933.
Cooper, Th., Men of the time ed. 9. 982. 1875.

	(biogr., bibl.).
Högrell, B., Bot. hist. 246. 1886.

Lundqvist, A., Sv. bot. Tidskr. 75: 306. 1981 (coll. nr. Göteborg 1820-1824); Sv. Lin-

<sm>COMMEMORATIVE MEDAL</sm>: cast in 1883 by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, im-

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wahlberg's brother, Johan August Wahlberg (1810-1856) travelled in Norway
(1832), Sweden and parts of Germany 1833-1834; South Africa 1839-1845 and 1854-
1856. Main set of collections in S; duplicates e.g. in DBN, HBG, PRE. For itinerary and
further details see M. Gunn &amp; L.E. Codd, Bot. Explor. S. Afr. 366-369. 1981 and T.
Flensburg &amp; S. Lindman, Sv. män kvinn. 8: 140-141. 1955.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wahlbergella</em> E.M. Fries (1843).

Wahlbom, Johan Gustav (1724-1808), Swedish botanist and physician; student of C.
Linnaeus; Dr. med. Uppsala 1751; regional physician in Kalmar 1754-1794; appointed
botanical demonstrator h.c. Stockholm 1794, but stayed in Kalmar. (<em>Wahlbom</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Lost, but some specimens in UPS (Juel 1926, 1931); for zoolog-
ical collections see Löwegren (1952).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 619; Barnhart 3: 449; BM 5: 2249, 8: 1383;
KR p. 741 (b. 7 Jan 1724, d. 25 Jan 1808); PR 5444, ed. 1: 6025; Rehder 1: 198; SO
254, 1279, 1447, 1454*, 1750, 2491a; TL-2/4738; Tucker 1: 727.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Burdet, H.M. et al., Ouvr. bot. anc. no. 517, 552. 1985.
Fries, Th.M., Linné 2: 75-77. 1903; Bref skrifv. Linné 1(1): 58, 207. 1907, 1(2): 172, 210,
	356. 1908, 1(4): 66, 190, 202, 248. 1910, 1(5): 4, 224-226. 1911, 1(6): 280. 1912 (with
	J.M. Hulth), 1(7): 27, 33. 1917.
Juel, H.O., Sv. Linné-Sällsk. Årsskr. 9: 70. 1926, 14: 12-16. 1931 (42 specimens an-
	notated by Linnaeus).
Löwegren, Y., Årsb. i sv. undervisningshist. 132: 95-97. 1944 (taught natural history at
	Kalmar High School); Naturaliekabinett Sverige 356, 369. 1952.
Palmblad, F.W., Biogr. Lexic. 19: 155-157. 1852.
Tigerstedt, R., <em>in</em> Nordisk Familjebok ed. 3. 19: 1283. 1933.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 57. 1905.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wahlbomia</em> Thunberg (1790).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: See C. Linnaeus, <em>Sponsalia plantarum</em> 1746, TL-2/4738. Krok attributes
this thesis to J.G. Wahlbom. – Swedish translation: <em>Sponsalia plantarum</em>, eller blomstrens
biläger, ... Stockholm 1750; repr. in Skrift. C. v. Linné 4(1): 49-102. 1908 with plate
and notes by Th.M. Fries. – Further copies seen of original: B, G, NY.

Wahlenberg, Georg [from 1804: Göran] (1780-1851), Swedish botanist; Dr. med.
Uppsala 1806; botanical demonstrator Uppsala 1814; titular professor 1826; regular
professor of botany and medicine ib., succeeding C.P. Thunberg 1829; travelled in
Pommern 1796, Gotland 1799, Lapland and northern Norway (1800, 1802, 1807,
1810), Germany, Switzerland, Austria and the Carpathics (Hungary) 1811-1814; early
plant geographer and staunch Linnaean. (<em>Wahlenb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UPS, UPS-Thunb; other material in B (mainly destr.), BM, C,
CGE, GOET, H, KIEL, LD (3000), M, MANCH, PH, S, SBT (Carex, orig.), WRSL.
– A mss. <em>autobiography</em> by W. is at UPS-UB (see Palmblad (1852); <em>diaries and notebooks</em>
(Southern Sweden 1821) in UPS-UB. – <em>Letters</em> Kalmar Stifts- och Gymnasiebibl. (2).

PAGE: 18
HEADING: WAHLENBERG

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 512; Barnhart 3: 619; BL 2: 479, 549, 729; BM
5: 2249-2250, 8: 1383; Bossert p. 423; CSP 6: 234-235; De Toni 1: cxxvii, 2: cxix; DSB
14: 116-117 (G. Eriksson); DTS 1: 318, 6(4): 205-206; Frank 3 (Anh.): 110; GR p. 483-

praeside C.P. Thunberg ... pro gradu medico in Academia Upsaliensi publico subjicit
examini auctor Georg. Wahlenberg ... In Auditorio botanico d. iv Jun. mdcccvi hor.
ante post merid. sol. Upsaliae (Typis Edmannianis) [1806]. Qu. (4 parts 1806-1807). (<em>Tract. anat.</em>).

<em>Authorship</em>: G. Wahlenberg author of all four parts; first part defended by Wahlenberg
	under C.P. Thunberg; parts 2-4 defended by C. Svedelius, J.U. Nyberg, S. Kjellberg.

	publice proponit Georg Wahlenberg M. Doct. ... respondente Svenone Kjellberg
	..."
<em>Copies</em>: B-S, LC, LD-UB, NY, Peterson, USDA. – See KR p. 744, no. 24 for Swedish and
	German revisions. – The B-S copy has a general t.p. and index, p. [i-ii] to the four
	parts: <em>De Sedibus materiarum immediatarum in plantis tractatio</em> ... Upsaliae (Typis
	Edmannianis) 1806 et 1807.

16.518. Georgii Wahlenberg ... <em>Flora lapponica</em> exhibens plantas geographice et botanice
consideratas, in Lapponiis suecicis scilicet Umensi, Pitensi, Lulensi, Tornensi et Kemensi
nec non Lapponiis norvegicis scilicet Nordlandia et Finmarkia utraque indigenas, et
itineribus annorum 1800, 1802, 1807 et 1810 denuo investigatas ... Berolini (in Taberna
Libraría Scholae realis) 1812. Oct. (<em>Fl. lapp.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Mai 1812 (p. [iii]: 20 Dec 1811; Allg. Konst. Letterb. 3 Jul 1812; Leipzig
	Easter Fair 1812), p. [i]-lxvi, chart to p. lxv, col. map, ("1"), chart temp. ("2"), [1]-
	550, <em>pl. 1-30</em> (uncol. copp. author). <em>Copies</em>: B, BR, G, H, HH, LD, MICH, MO, NY,
	PH, US, USDA; IDC 5797. – <em>Note</em> (by O. Almborn): A fundamental work in plant

PAGE: 20
HEADING: WAHLENBERG

	geography. In the "Introductio" and the "mappa botanico-geographia" terms such
	as Lapponia (regio) alpina, r. subalpina, r. subsylvatica, r. sylvatica and limes nivalis
	are here used for the first time.
<em>Supplement</em>: 1826 see S.C. Sommerfelt, <em>Supplementum Florae Lapponicae</em> ... Christianiae
	(Typis Borgianis et Gröndahlianis). Oct., see TL-2/12.418.

HEADING: WAHLSTEDT

<em>Novitiae florae suecicae</em> by E.M. Fries, <em>ed. altera</em>, 1828, TL-2/1871 is a commentary on
	Wahlenberg's flora.

Wahlstedt, Lars Johan (1836-1917), Swedish botanist and lecturer; studied at Lund
1856-1862; Dr. phil. 1862; head of the botanical garden Lund 1862-1864; lecturer in
natural sciences and Swedish at Kristianstad college 1865-1905. (<em>Wahlstedt</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD; further material (incl. exsicc.) at AK, B (mainly destr.), BR,
G, DBN, E, F, GR, GOET, H, JE, K, LD, MANCH, MPU, MW, OXF, W, WRSL. –
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) With C.F.O. Nordstedt, <em>Characeae scandinavicae exsiccatae</em> fasc. 1-3, nos. 1-
120, 1871-1874, see under Nordstedt.
(2) With L.M. Neuman and S.S. Murbeck, <em>Violae Sueciae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-2, 1886, 1893,
nos. 1-60, see under Neuman.

1901, see under Migula.
(4) With Bengt Jönsson (1849-1911), <em>Urval af svenska fodergräs</em>, Lund 1884 (2 p., 32
plants) and <em>Urval af svenska foderbaljväxter</em>, Lund 1886 (2 p., 32 plants).

Wahlström, Johan Erik (1821-1892), Swedish botanist and high school teacher;
studied in Uppsala 1842-1848; Dr. phil. 1848; teacher at Stockholm 1856-1888.
(<em>Wahlström</em>).

Wahnschaffe, [Gustav Albert Bruno] Felix (1851-1914), German (Prussian) geo-
logist; studied natural sciences at Leipzig 1871-1874, at Jena 1874-1875; Dr. phil. Jena
1875; temporary assistant at the Königliche Geologische Landesanstalt und Berga-
kademie, Charlottenburg, Berlin 1875-1878, regular assistant 1878-1886; "Landes-
geologe" ib. 1886; Habil. Univ. Berlin 1886, from 1892 with the title professor; divi-
sional director ib. 1903-1914. (<em>Wahnschaffe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 449 (b. 27 Jan 1851); BM 5: 2250-2251;
Christiansen p. 321 [index]; Quenstedt p. 449 (d. 20 Jan 1914); Tucker 1: 727.

Wahrlich, Woldemar [Karlowitsch] (1859-1923), Russian pharmacist; assistant
pharmacist's examination Moscow 1877; studied medicine and pharmacy at Moscow
University 1877-1879; assistant at the Moscow Botanical Institute and Garden 1879-
1884; studied at the Kaiser-Wilhelms-Universität Strassburg with A. de Bary 1884-1886;
Dr. phil. ib. 1886; lecturer at the Veterinary Institute Dorpat 1888; professor at the
Military Medicinal Academy at St. Petersburg from 1923. (<em>Wahrlich</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Wakefield, Elsie Maud (1886-1972), British botanist (mycologist); studied at Oxford
and München (with Tubeuf); assistant Herbarium, Royal Botanic Gardens Kew 1910;
temporarily mycologist at Imp. Dept. Agric. W. Indies, Barbados 1920-1921 while
Mary Ewart Travelling Scholar; deputy keeper Kew 1945-1951. (<em>Wakef</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K. – Further material at E. Manuscripts at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 126, 283, 324; Barnhart 3: 450; Bossert p.

259; Kleppa p. 113; Lenley p. 426; LS 40388, suppl. 4138, 4139, 5752, 29134-29170;
Roon p. 120; Stevenson p. 1261.

	1910: 64 (appointment assistant Kew), 1921: 30 (temporarily [1920-1921] mycologist
	Imp. Dept. Agrie. W. Indies Barbados); Kew Bull. 1946: 3 (deputy keeper 1945,
	succeeding T.A. Sprague); Taxon 1: 99. 1952 (retirement); The Times 5 Jul 1972.

Wakker, Jan Hendrik (1859-1927), Dutch botanist, phytopathologist and plant
breeder; Dr. phil. Amsterdam 1885 (student of Hugo de Vries); at the Zoological
Station, Naples 1885; working at the Botanical Laboratory, Univ. Amsterdam 1885-
1887; assistant at the botanical laboratory, Univ. Utrecht 1887-1889; teacher at Alphen-
Oudshoorn 1889-1891; director of the Sugar Experiment Station East Java 1892-1897;
high school teacher in 's Hertogenbosch, Netherlands 1897-1925. (<em>Wakk</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: L (orig.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 283, 348; Barnhart 3: 450 (b. 28 Jun 1859);

28248, 40389; Rehder 5: 897; Stevenson p. 1261.

Waldstein, Franz de Paula Adam [Graf] (1759-1823), Austrian soldier and botanist;
in campaigns against the Turks and North African states as Maltese knight 1777-1781;
in the Austrian-Turkish war and the Prussian campaign 1787-1789; dedicating himself
to botany from 1789 together with Paul Kitaibel, mainly travelling in historical Hun-
gary; in the Austro-French war in Italy 1797; continued his botanical studies from
Vedröd near Pressburg (Bratislava), again in active service in the Austrian army 1809;
from 1814 in possession of the family estate in Bohemia (nr Oberleutensdorf). (<em>Waldst</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR. – Many of the Waldstein and Kitaibel types are at PR,
others in BP and BM (through Shuttleworth). The Prague types are listed by Chrtek

PAGE: 31
HEADING: E. WALKER

and Skocdopolová (1982). – A specimen from "Tauria" (Crimea), collected by Wald-
stein is at H; other material at PH, WRSL. – <em>Letter</em> to Jacquin at UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 148, 5(2): 137, 437, 12(3): 58; Backer p. 620;
Barnhart 3: 451 (b. 24 Feb 1759, d. 24 Mai 1823); BM 2: 987, 5: 2254; DU 325; Frank 3
(Anh.): 80; Futak-Domin p. 649; Hegi 4(2): 927, 5(1): 600; Herder p. 193; Hortus 3:
1206; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 345; Jackson p. 267; Kanitz p. 60 (no. 94); Klásterský p.
200; Lasègue p. 333, 527; Maiwald p. 87, 89, 91, 120, 140; NI 2096; Plesch p. 454; PR
9939, ed. 1: 10919; Rehder 1: 444; SK 4: ccxvi (Stearn); Sotheby 801; TL-1/1379; TL-
2/see P. Kitaibel; Tucker 1: 728; WU 52: 209, 234-236; Zander ed. 10, p. 729, ed. 11, p.
822.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 6(1): 383-384. 1823 (obit.).
Borbás, V., A Balaton tavának és partmellékének növény f. edény. növennyz. 309-310.
	1900.
Chrtek, J. &amp; B. Skocdopolová, Acta musei natl. Prag. 38B(4): 201-234. 1982 (on W.'s
	herbarium in PR, list types; analysis of herbarium shows that Waldstein took an
	active part in writing the <em>Descriptiones</em>).
Degen, A. v., Fl. velebitica 1: 517. 1936.
Gombocz, E., Acta hist. rer. nat. techn. special issue 6. Prague 1973, p. 153-157.
Junk, W., Rara 2: 134. 1926.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Waldsteinia</em> Willdenow (1799).

16.560. Francisci comitis Waldstein, ... et Pauli Kitaibel ... <em>Descriptiones et icones
plantarum rariorum Hungariae</em>. Viennae (Typis Matthiae Andreae Schmidt, ...) [1799]
1802-1812, 3 vols. Fol. †. (<em>Descr. icon. pl. Hung.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1799-1802 (ten parts, see below), p. [i*-iii*], [i]-xxxii, 1-104, <em>pl. 1-100</em> (col. copp. J.
	Schütz).
<em>2</em>: 1803-1805 (ten parts), p. [i*], [i]-xxxii, 105-220, <em>pl. 101-200</em> (id.).
<em>3</em>: 1806-1812 (eight parts; remained unfinished; no preface, but mss. introduction by
	Kitaibel published by A. Kanitz, Linnaea 33: 482-529. 1865), p. [i], [221]-310, [311-
	312], <em>pl. 201-280.</em>
<em>Copies</em>: G, HH, Teyler, U; IDC 676. – Four volumes were anticipated. A note on p. 310
	states that publication is suspended because of "multiplicia impedimenta, quae e
	gravibus temporibus in quibus vivimus inseparatibilia sunt".

Walker, Egbert Hamilton (1899-x), American botanist and botanical bibliographer;
A.B. Mich. Univ. 1922; Dr. phil. Johns Hopkins Univ. 1940; Instructor Canton Christ-
ian College 1922-1926; assistant in botany Univ. Wisconsin 1926-1928; aide, division of
plants Smithsonian Institution 1928-1942; assistant curator ib. 1942-1946, associate
curator 1946-1958; working on various grants ib. 1956-1964; research associate 1964-
1966, emeritus botanist 1967. (<em>E. Walker</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US; other material at CAL, DPU, LU, MO; manuscripts, field
notes and correspondence: US (SIA); other letters at NY (especially in Barnhart corr.).

3: 325.

Walker, Richard (1791-1870), British clergyman and botanist; educated at Balliol and
Magdalen Colleges, Oxford; MA. 1817, B.D. 1824; fellow of Magdalen College 1821,
subsequently dean, bursar and vice-president and master of the Grammar School of
Magdalen College, later curate of Tilehurst nr Reading; died at Olveston, Gloucester-
shire. (<em>R. Walker</em>).

Wallace, Alfred Russel (1823-1913), British explorer, zoologist and botanist; collected
with H.W. Bates in S. America 1848-1852, in the Malay Archipelago 1854-1862.
(<em>Wallace</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K; further material in BM (Borneo ferns), CGE, O. –<em>Manuscripts</em>
at the Linnean Society, London. – The material collected during the Amazon expedit-
ion of 1848-1852 was lost in fire on ship 6 August 1852. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Wallerius, Johan Gottschalk (Gottschalck) (1709-1785), Swedish agricultural che-
mist, mineralogist and botanist; Dr. phil. Uppsala 1731, Dr. med. ib. Lund 1735; assist-
ant professor of medecine Lund 1732; lecturer at Uppsala 1736; practicing physician,
from 1737 superintendent at Dannemarks ("Helsobrunn") nr Uppsala; assistant profes-
sor of medicine Uppsala 1741; professor of chemistry ib. 1750-1767. (<em>Wallerius</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 454; BM 5: 2258, 8: 1388-1390; Bossert p.

Jul 1709, d. 16 Nov 1785); PR 9946-9952, ed. 1: 6141, 10928-10938; Quenstedt p. 450;
Rehder 5: 899; SO see index.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 252: 289-291. 1965; Cat. gén. livr.
	impr. Bibl. natl. 217: 552-560. 1973.

	59, 336, 1910, 1(5): 134, 170. 1911, 1(6): 117, 211, 232. 1912 (with J.M. Hulth), 1(7):
	192 [index]. 1917.

HEADING: WALLICH

Hulth, J.M., Bref Skrifv. Linné 1(8): 30, 33, 104. 1922, 2(1): 95, 156. 1916.

	(autobiogr.); Sv. män kvinn. 8: 192-193. 1955 (biogr., portr.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Walleria</em> Kirk (1864) honors Horace Waller who discovered the plants named
for him in East Africa.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wallerius applied, together with Linnaeus, for two vacant chairs in the medical
Faculty in Uppsala. In both cases the Consistorium ranked Linnaeus before Wallerius.
As a specimen for the chair of medicine Wallerius published a thesis containing severe
criticism of Linnaeus's medical works, especially his thesis from 1735. The public defense
ended in chaos. However, Linnaeus was appointed in 1741. (Note by O. Almborn).

16.577. Q.B.V. [Quod bene vertat] <em>Dissertatio oeconomica de artificiosa foecundatione immersiva
seminum vegetabilium</em>. Quam, consensu ampliss. Senatus philosophici in illustri Academia
Upsaliensi, praeside, vire ... Joh. Gotschalk Wallerio, ... Speciminis Academici loco,
publicae luci et examini modeste offert Johannes Pihlman, ... in Aud. Carol. maj. die
[1, mss.] Junii anni mdcclii. H.A.M.S. Holmiae [Stockholm] (Literis Laurentii Salvii)
[1752]. Qu. (<em>Diss. foecund. semin. veg.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1 Jun 1752, p. [1-24]. <em>Copies</em>: B-S, LD-UB.

16.578. D.D. [Docente Deo] <em>Dissertatio gradualis, de vegetatione seminum vegetabilium</em> per
mortem, quam suffrag. Ampliss. Facult. philosoph. in Regia Academia Upsaliensi,
praeside, ... Johanne Gotsch [sic] Wallerio, ... stipendiarius regius Michael Henr.
Ottin, ... in Audit. Carol. min. die xviii Febr. anni mdcclxi. H.A.M.S. Upsaliae [1761]. (<em>Diss. veg. semin.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 18 Feb 1761, p. [1]-8. <em>Copy</em>: B-S.

Wallerton, Charles Louis Auguste (1721-1788). Fictitious French naturalist, said to
have explored the province of Michoacan, Mexico between 1760 and 1765 and to have
written e.g. <em>Tableau de la flore du royaume de la Nouvelle Espagne</em> (2 vols. 1775-1779).
<em>Ref</em>.: Anon., in J.G. Wilson and J. Fiske, Appleton's Cycl. Amer. biogr. 6: 338. 1889
	(wholly fictitious).

Wallich, Nathaniel (b. Nathan Wulff ["Wolff"] (1786-1854), Danish physician and
botanist; studied with M. Vahl at Copenhagen; surgeon at Serampore 1807, working
with W. Roxburgh at Calcutta 1809; to Mauritius for health reasons 1812, entered the
British colonial medical service at Calcutta 1814; assistant superintendent Calcutta
Botanic Garden 1815-1816, superintendent ib. 1817-1846 with interruptions for tours of
inspection, European and sick leave; collected in Nepal 1820-1822, Singapore and
Penang 1822, in Assam 1833 and the Cape 1842-1844 as well as in India. (<em>Wallich</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (K-W) (available on IDC 7394 incl. catalogue); further
material at A, AWH, B (partly destr.), BM, BR, C, CGE, CAL, DBN, DD, DPU, DS
(CAS), E, FI, G, G-DC, GJO, FH, FI, H, K, KIEL, L, LE, LINN (in J.E. Smith
herb.), LIV, M, MANCH, MICH, MO, NY, OXF, P, PH, PR, ROST, S, SING,
TCD, TO, TU, US, W, WRSL, WU. – Kew has the main set of the Wallich collections
(K-W). His types are also mainly at Kew. Wallich collected extensively and made many
duplicates; the <em>numbered</em> specimens were distributed from London (after 1826) under the
auspices of the East India Company. Wallich's main set was incorporated in the her-
barium of the East India Company which came to LINN in 1832, and which was
transferred to K in 1913. The numerous duplicates are in many herbaria, often accom-
panied by new names without descriptions. These names will also be found in the litho-
graphed "Numerical list".

PAGE: 38
HEADING: WALLICH

(2) D. Don's <em>Prodromus</em> (1825) was based on Wallich specimens sent to Lambert in 1818
and 1819 (see W.T. Stearn <em>in</em> H. Hara et al., Enum. fl. pl. Nepal 1: 8. 1978). Part of this
Nepal set is at BM and other parts are at CGE, FI and PR as well as perhaps in various
other herbaria. Prain's remark in Ann. Bot. Gard. Calcutta 8: 328. 1898, that Wallich's
Nepal plants in Lambert's herbarium were destroyed as unsaleable can therefore not be
entirely correct (Miller, Taxon 19: 545. 1970; inf. G. Seidenfaden).
<em>Correspondence</em>: partly at K, further letters at G, UPS-UB. For further mss. material see
Bridson et al. (1980).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 185; Backer p. 620; Barnhart 3: 454 (b. 28 Jan
1786, d. 28 Apr 1854); BB p. 314-315; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9720; BM 5: 2258-2259; Bossert
p. 425; Bret. p. 246; CSP 6: 252-253, 12: 769; Dawson p. 851-853; Desmond p. 637;

326; Hortus 3: 1206; IF p. 736-737; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed 7): 345; Jackson p. 377, 383,
389, 414; Lasègue p. 587 [index]; LS 28258; Moebius p. 77; MW p. 519-520; NI 2098-
2100; PH 129, 438; Plesch p. 455; PR 2364, 9953-9957, ed. 1: 2675, 10939-10944;

Wallis, Gustav (1830-1878), German (Hanoverian) gardener and botanical explorer;
gardener at Detmold and München; collected in South and Central America 1854-1868
(part of the time for J. Linden), in Europe 1868-1869; in the Philippines and Japan
1870-1871; in North America 1871-1872; in Colombia, Panama and Ecuador 1872-1878
for James Veitch; died in Ecuador. (<em>Wallis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material in B (mainly destr.), BM (mosses), BR, C, K, M, NY,
W. – The herbarium collections by Wallis are not numerous; he specialized on living
plants. "Leider hat Herr G. Wallis eine räthselhafte Autosyncrasie dagegen, der
Wissenschaft durch Sendung getrockneter Exemplare zu dienen" (Reichenbach 1876). –
Herbarium offered for sale, Flora 62: 336. 1879. – <em>Letters</em> at G. – Manuscripts acquired
by <em>Deutsche Gärtner Verband</em> (see Deut. Gärtn. Zeit. 1879: 285, 299, 327.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 620; Barnhart 3: 455 (b. 1 Mai 1830, d. 20 Jun
1878); CSP 8: 1188, 11: 743, 12: 769; DTS 1: 319, 6(4): 206; GR p. 150; Hortus 3: 1206;
Rehder 5: 899-900; SK 1: 558; Urban-Berl. p. 316, 408.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 52: 62 (returns to Europe), 461 (will go to Philippines); Garten–
	flora 12: 27. 1863 (under contract with Linden to collect in Brazil).
Linden, J., Illustr. hortic. 22: 11-12. 1875 ("mon ex-collecteur Wallis" on his services to
	Linden); Gard. Chron. ser. 2. 3: 279-280. 1875 (id.).
Mossen, E., ed., <em>in</em> Belg. hortic. 1881: 172-190 (transl. of Wallis diary and notes of trip in
	Venezuela 1868).

	126-132, 150-156, 174-176, 180-182, 185-188. 1870 ("Gustav Wallis. Eine
	biographisch-naturgeschichtliche Skizze").
Otto, E., Hamb. Gart. Blumenzeit. 33: 433-440. 1878, French transl. Belg. hort. 1879: 1-
	19 (portr., biogr.).
Prance, G., Acta Amaz. 1(1): 63. 1971.

also 1881: 172-190].

Wallis, John (1714-1793), Britsh clergyman, county historian and naturalist; MA
Oxford 1740, curate at Simonburn c. 1746-1772, at Billingham 1776-1792. (<em>J. Wallis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> in N.J. Winch corr. at LINN.

Wallnöfer, Anton (<em>fl</em>. 1888), Austrian bryologist in Klagenfurt. (<em>Walln</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Had a large bryophyte herbarium (40.000 specimens), which
was offered for sale by him in 1905 (Rev. bryol. 32(1): 16. 1905. – Some material by him
is at BM (until 1969 at K) and QK.

BIBLIOGRAPHY and BIOGRAPHY: CSP 19: 457.

(Druck von F. v. Kleinmayr) 1889. Oct. (<em>Laubm. Kärnt.</em>).

<em>Ref</em>.: Geheeb, A., Bot. Centralbl. 39: 317-318. 10 Sep 1889 (rev.).

Wallroth, [Carl] Friedrich Wilhelm (1792-1857), German (Prussian Saxony)
botanist; studied medicine at Halle (with K.P.J. Sprengel); Dr. med. Göttingen 1815;
physician in the Hannover army 1815; practicing physician in Heringen 1816; regional
physician 1822, from 1825 in Nordhausen. (<em>Wallr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PR (phan., some crypt.), STR (fungi, Cladoniac.), JE (part of
phan.). – Other material in B (mainly destr.), BR, G, G-DC, GOET, HAL, KIEL, LE,
LZ (destr.), MW, WRSL. – Kützing (1857) remarks that Wallroth kept the localities of
his new species secret and that, on purpose, no localities were cited of rare or new
species, even on his herbarium sheets. – <em>Letters</em> at G, HAL (to D.F.L. v. Schlechtendal),
HU, UPS-UB. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: A series <em>Lichenes florae Germ. exs.</em> of 6 fasc. is mentioned by
Sydow (fide T. Ahti), but is not known to exist.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 40: 766-768; AG 6(2): 28; Ainsworth p. 96, 313,
348; Backer p. 621; Barnhart 3: 455 (b. 13 Mar 1792, d. 22 Mar 1857); BM 5: 2259;
CSP 6: 254; De Toni 1: cxxviii, 2: cxix; Frank 3 (Anh.): 110; GR p. 52, cat. p. 73;
Hawksworth p. 186; Hegi 5(2): 1189; Herder p. 483 [index]; Hortus 3: 1206; IF p. 737;
IH 1 (ed. 6): 365, (ed. 7): 345; Jackson p. 142, 295, 296, 297, 304; Kelly p. 237;
Krempelh. 2: 158; LS 28265-28273; Moebius p. 457 [index]; MW p. 520; Nordstedt p.
31; PR 837, 9962-9971, ed. 1: 948, 10949-10958; Rehder 5: 900; SBC p. 134; Stevenson
p. 1262; TL-1/1384-1385; TL-2/451, 559, see F.C.G. Arnold; Tucker 1: 729; Urban-
Berl. p. 283, 292; Zander ed. 10, p. 729, ed. 11, p. 832.

<em>Copies</em>: B-S, G, HH, MO, NY, Teyler.
<em>Ref</em>.: Schlechtendal, D.F.L. von, Bot. Zeit. 3: 24-27. 1845 (rev.).

Walpers, Wilhelm Gerhard (1816-1853), German (Thuringian) botanist; studied at
the University of Greifswald (1836) and Breslau (1837-1838); Dr. phil. Greifswald 1839;
from then on independent scientist in Berlin; habil. Univ. Berlin 1848. (<em>Walp</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Walpers' own herbarium, containing many of the types of his
new taxa, was sold after his death. This herbarium contained about 3000 species in 53
portfolio's "fast ungeordnet". In addition to this personal herbarium Walpers owned a
collection of plants (1000 species) from Guadeloupe and Panama made by Duchassaing,
also containing many types, the Elkan herbarium with the Flora Borussica types (see
C.A. Patze et al., <em>Fl. Preuss.</em>, TL-2/7509) and collections of pharmaceutical plants and
preparations. All these collections were offered for sale but their present location is
unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal in HAL; other letters at G, UPS-UB.

PAGE: 46
HEADING: WALPERS

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Flora (36: 423. 1853): "Am 18. Juni d. J. entleibte sich durch einen Pistolenschuss
zu Köpenick bei Berlin der Privatdocent Dr. Walpers, bekannt als Verfasser des
Repertorium und der Annales botanices systematicae wie mehrerer anderer botanischer
Schriften und Abhandlungen. Gekränkter Ehrgeiz und andere bittere Lebenserfahrun-
gen sollen den Unglücklichen zu diesem traurigen Schritte vermocht haben, von wel-
chem er Tags vorher auch der Redaction dieser Blätter schriftliche Nachricht gab, mit
der Bitte nachstehende Anzeige zu veröffentlichen". (Follows a summary of his her-
baria: Collection Guadeloupe by Duchassaing; herbarium Elkan (4.500); Walper's own
herbarium with his types; herbarium medicinale; pharmacological collection).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 40: 769-770; AG 2(1): 730; Backer p. 663; Barnhart
3: 455 (b. 26 Dec 1816, d. 18 Jun 1853); BM 5: 2260; CSP 6: 254-255; Frank 3 (Anh.):
110; GR p. 150-151; Herder p. 143; Hortus 3: 1206; Jackson p. 117, 118, 350; Lasègue
p. 526; LS 28274; MW p. 520; PR 1112, 6143, 9972-9974, ed. 1: 933, 2242, 10960-
10961; Rehder 5: 900; RS p. 147; SBC p. 134; TL-1/1386-1387; TL-2/5895, see indexes;
Tucker 1: 729; Zander ed. 10, p. 729, ed. 11, p. 832.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 1: 134, 137, 143, 160 (list herb. etc. from W.'s estate), 197,
	207, 256. 1853, 2: 41. (plea to continue <em>Annales</em>), 268 (cogn. Leopoldina Hill). 1854;
	Bot. Zeit. 6: 112. 1848 (habil. Berlin), 7: 568. 1849 (appointment to two State Com-
	missions), 11: 512. 1853 (d.); Flora 31: 254. 1848 (habil.), 36: 423. 1853 (descr. of
	death, reasons, list herbaria); G.W. Walpers Botanische Bibliothek welche am I. Juni
	1854 in Berlin ... versteigert werden soll, Berlin 1854. Friedländer (enclosed with
	Linnaea 26(2) Apr 1854); Österr. bot. W. 3: 237, 254. 1853 (d.).
Asen, J., Gesamtverz. Lehrkörp. Univ. Berlin 1: 209. 1955 (Privatdozent für Botanik 7
	Jan 1848).

	(obit., bibl.) 1853, 2: 163-166, 176-178. 1854 (letters Walpers to Seemann).
Stafleu, F.A., <em>in</em> Essays in biohistory (Regn. veg. 71) 317, 318, 327, 328, 331, 340. 1970.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Translation, <em>Über die geometrische Anordnung der Blätter und der Blüth-
enstande</em> von L. und A. Bravais, Breslau 1839 (originally published in Ann. Sci. nat., Bot.
with additional material; for further details see Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 217: 729-
730. 1973). – Also W.G. Walpers, <em>Verzeichniss der in meiner Übersetzung der Bravais' schen
Arbeit über Blatt- und Blüthenstellung befindlichen Irrthümer</em>, Berlin 1840 (n.v.).
(2) <em>Cruciferas, Capparideas, Calycereas</em> et <em>Compositas</em>, quas Meyenius in orbis circumnavigat-
ione collegit enumerat novasque describit G. Walpers, <em>in</em> F.J.F. Meyen, <em>Observ. bot.</em> Dec
1843, TL-2/5895, Nova Acta Leop. 17(2) [19(1)], 247-296. Also repaginated p. [1]-48
as part of a large reprint p. [1]-247 [<em>copy</em>: G] corresponding with p. 249-495 of the
Meyen publication, in which Meyen also treated Dicotyledoneae Thalamiflorae on p.
297-424.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Walpersia</em> Reissek ex Endlicher (1840, <em>nom. rej.</em>); <em>Walpersia</em> W.H. Harvey
(1862, <em>nom. cons.</em>).

16.603. <em>Animadversiones criticae in Leguminosas capenses</em> herbarii regii berolinensis. Disser-

16.604. <em>Repertorium botanices systematicae</em> ... Lipsiac [Leipzig] (sumtibus Friderici Hofmeis-

16.605. <em>Annales botanices systematicae</em> ... Lipsiae [Leipzig] (Sumptibus Friderici Hofmeis-
ter) 1848-1871, 7 vols. (<em>Ann. bot. syst.</em>).

HEADING: WALPERS

vol.	part	pages	dates	vol.	part	pages	dates
------------------------------------------------------------------------
	6	961-1125	12-15 Mai 1852		4	481-640	Jan-Jul 1863
3	1	1-192	30 Jun-2 Jul
			1852		5	641-800	Jan-Mar 1863
	2	193-384	27-28 Jul 1852		6	801-960	Mar-Dec 1864
	3	385-576	24-25 Aug 1852		7	961-1120	1865
	4	577-768	28-29 Sep 1852		8	1121-1309	Jul-Dec 1865
	5	769-960	22-24 Nov 1852	7	1	1-160	Jan-Aug 1868
	6	961-1168	13-14 Jan 1853		2	161-320	Aug-Dec 1868
4	1	1-160	Mai 1857		3	321-480	Jan-Aug 1869
	2	161-320	Aug 1857		4	481-640	Oct-Dec 1869
	3	321-480	Nov 1857		5	641-800	1870
	4	481-640	Jan-Feb 1858	6	801-960	Jan-Jun 1871

The above dates are those of receipt by Hinrichs (1848-1853) or based on reviews in
Botanische Zeitung, Bonplandia, Bull. Soc. bot. France, Kew Journ. Bot., Oest. Bot.
Wochenbl., Ann. Journ. Sci., some of which were assembled by Barnhart, as well as on
information contained in Walpers's correspondence. The dates for vols. 4-7 are con-
jectural; more precise information can be obtained from Hinrich's lists for the years
1857-1871 (not available to us). In general it is more likely that the parts appeared
towards the end of the periods indicated than towards the beginning. Walpers commit
ted suicide in 1853. The Annales were then continued by Carl Mueller. For critical
notes by Walpers on some of his reviewers see his notes on the covers of Heft 1 and 5 of
volume 3 of the Annales. Walpers had already decided before his death not to continue
the "Annales" beyond volume 3. In his letters to Seemann he wrote "Lass sich einmal
ein Anderer dabei machen diese undankbare Arbeit fortzusetzen; ich habe mir damit
anstatt Freunde, Feinde gemacht; ich habe die Sache herzlich satt; der Verleger wird
reich, ich arm dabei .."

<em>Ref</em>.: Seemann, B., Bonplandia 2: 87-88, 123-124, 163-166, 176-178. 1854.

Walter, Hans Paul Heinrich (1882-x), German (Prussian) botanist; studied at Halle
1902-1904, Freiburg i.Br. 1904, Halle 1904-1906; Dr. phil. Erlangen 1906; collaborator
of A. Engler 1906-1909. (<em>Ha. Walter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.).

	1936-1942 which are by Heinrich W. (b. 1898)).

Walter, Heinrich [Karl] (1898-x), German (Odessa-born) botanist; studied at Jena;
assistant, lecturer and professor of botany Heidelberg Univ. 1920-1932; director of the
Botanical Institute of the Stuttgart Technical Univ. 1932-1941; director of the Institute
of general botany Posen Univ. 1941-1945; director of the Botanical Institute Stuttgart-
Hohenheim from 1945; travelled widely in Africa, Australia, and New Zealand; out-
standing plant geographer.
(<em>He. Walter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HOH, M, WIND. – Further material in BR. – The herbarium of
Erna Walter (b. 1893, wife of H. Walter), containing much material collected by "H. u.
E. Walter" is at M (rd. 1980).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 456 (b. 21 Oct 1898, Odessa); BFM p. 324
[index]; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9729-9731; GR p. 151; Hirsch p. 315; Moebius p. 259;
Tucker 3: 325.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 72: 231. 1932 (e.o. prof. bot. and dir. bot. gard. Techn.
	Hochsch. Stuttgart); Österr. bot. Z. 81: 160. 1932 (app. Stuttgart).
Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's ed. 10. 1678. 1935.

Kliemann, H.G. &amp; S.S. Taylor, Who's who in Germany ed. 1: 1217-1218. 1956, ed. 2:
	1507. 1960, ed. 3: 1817. 1964.

Walter, Thomas (1740-1789), British-born botanist in North America; emigrated to
South Carolina 1768; planter, merchant and politician. (<em>Walter</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM. – In 1840 Walter's herbarium was in the hands of the
family of John Fraser (A. Gray, Am. J. Sci. 40(1): 1-18. 1840) to whom it had been
given by Walter himself. John Fraser's son gave it to the Linnean Society in 1849 which
kept it until 1863 when it was sold to BM (15 shillings!). The herbarium contains a great
many of the plants from the <em>Flora caroliniana</em>, often, however, in mediocre condition. –
Some further material in BR, H. – Photographs of the 122 sheets of the herbarium at
GH. – <em>Letters</em> at K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 621; Barnhart 3: 456 (d. 18 Jan 1789); BB p.
315; BM 5: 2261; DAB 19: 396-399 (Maxon); Desmond p. 638; Dryander 3: 186; Frank
3 (Anh.): 110; Henrey 2: 173-175, 382, 383, 3: 1476; Herder p. 227; Hortus 3: 1206; IF
p. 737; Jackson p. 362; IF p. 737; LS 28280; ME 1: 237, 3: 356; PR 9978, ed. 1: 10966;
Rehder 1: 317; RS p. 147; SO add. 725a; Stevenson p. 1262; TL-1/1388; see J. Fraser;
TL-2/see J. Fraser; Zander ed. 10, p. 729, ed. 11, p. 832.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Who was who Amer., Hist. vol. 559. 1963.
Barnhart, J.H., J. New York Bot. Gard. 10: 177-190. 1909, 23: 162. 1922, 24: 152. 1923,
	29: 149. 1928; Torreya 9: 246. 1909.

	carol.).

	1843; Memorials John Bartram and Humphrey Marshall, Philadelphia 1849.
Dayton, W.A., Rhodora 54: 67-79. 1952 (tree names).

Ewan, J., Taxon 28: 345-346. 1979 (handwriting, illustrated; "addenda"); <em>in</em> F. Pursh,

	grasses).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Taxon 28: 346. 1979.

16.613. <em>Flora caroliniana</em>, secundum systema vegetabilium perillustris Linnaei digesta;
characteres essentiales naturalesve et differentias veras exhibens; cum emendationibus
numerosis: descriptionum antea evulgatarum: adumbrationes stirpium plus mille cont-
inens: nec non, generibus novis non paucis, speciebus plurimis novisq. ornata ...
Londini [London] (Sumptibus J. Fraser ...) 1788. Oct. (in 4-s) (<em>Fl. carol.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Jun 1788, p. [i]-viii, [1]-263, <em>1 pl</em>. (fold out). <em>Copies</em>: B, G, HH, MICH, NY,
	PH, USDA; IDC 5420. - The New York copy has an index p. [i-viii]. Such a copy is
	also mentioned by H. Lubrecht (1967).
<em>Index</em>: see D.H. Rembert Jr., Huntia 6(2): 129-140. 1986.
<em>Facsimile ed</em>.: Arnold Arboretum, 1946. <em>Copies</em>: BR, FAS, HH.
<em>Note</em>: Walter brought the manuscript to London where he arrived in the course of
	March 1788. The book was published before July (cf. Analytical review 1: 381. Jul
	1788). - The designation <em>Anonymos</em> (on p. 2, 4, 9 etc.) is a word applied to 28 different
	genera by Walter to indicate that they were without names. <em>Anonymos</em> cannot be
	regarded as a generic name (see ICBN Art. 20.4(a); combinations such as Anonymos
	aquatica (p. 230) are not validly published (Art. 43).

Walther, Alexander Wilhelm Hannibal Franz (1813-1890), German
(Bavarian/Oberfranken) physician and botanist at Bayreuth. (<em>Al. Walther</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M; further material in B (partly extant), IBF, WRSL.

Walther, [Edward] Eric (1892-1959), German (Saxonian), later American horticul-
turist; student of the Crassulaceae; to the United States 1909; connected with Golden
Gate Park, San Francisco from 1918-1957; ultimately first director of the Strybing
Arboretum. (<em>E. Walther</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CAS. - Further material in A.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 456 (b. 14 Oct 1892, d. 2 Jul 1959); Bossert
p. 425 (Edward Eric W.); Hortus 3: 1206; IH 1 (ed. 1): 85, (ed. 2): 108, (ed. 3): 138,
(ed. 4): 153, (ed. 5): 164; Langman 789-790; Tucker 3: 325; Zander ed. 10, p. 729, ed.
11, p. 832.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 452-453. 1969 (bibl.).
Bullock, A.A., Bibl. S. Afr. bot. 1978.

16.622. <em>Botanische Erinnerungen aus dem Feldzug</em> 1940 ... Sonderdruck aus den "Mitteilun-
gen des Thüringischen Botanischen Vereins ..." 1940 [i.e. 1941]. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 20 Jan 1941 (t.p. reprint states publ. 20 Jan 1940; the paper, however, deals with
	botanical reminiscenses of the campaign of 1940, i.e. of the German attack on W.
	Europe 10 Mai-25 Jun 1940; the journal volume is for 1941), p. 151-154. <em>Copy</em>: B. -
	Reprinted or preprinted from Mitt. Thür. bot. Ver. ser. 2. 47: 151-154. 1941.
	"Während des Feldzuges im Westen, der mich mit einer vollmotorisierten Frontein-
	heit innerhalb von 46 Tagen durch Holland, Belgien, ganz Nordfrankreich,
	Ostfrankreich bis zur Schweizergrenze ... brachte, war es nur in bescheidenem Masse
	möglich zu botanisieren". [The senior author of TL-2 and the author of this account
	did not meet: the latter was too much in a hurry].

professor of botany at Glasgow 1930-1962. (<em>J. Walton</em>).

Wangenheim, Friedrich Adam Julius von (1749-1800), German (Sachsen-Gotha)
soldier and forester; joined the army corps of the Duke of Hessen-Kassel in 1776; with
this corps in the United States 1777-1783 as first lieutenant, from 1779 as staff captain;
with the Hessian forest service 1784-1787; forester in Prussian Lithuania 1787, from
1788 as Prussian "Oberforstmeister" (forester-in-charge) of the Lithuanian directorate
general at Gumbinnen of the Lithuanian "Kriegs-und Domänenkammer" (Prussian
military territorial administration); also in charge of the re-afforestation of the Polish
provinces of Bialystock and Plock 1799-1800. (<em>Wangenh</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 41: 148-149 (R. Hess); Backer p. 663; Barnhart 3:
457 (b. 8 Feb 1749, d. 25 Mar 1800); BM 5: 2262; Bossert p. 425; Dryander 3: 209, 270,
277, 320, 325, 5: 480 (index); Frank 3 (Anh.): 111; GF p. 80; Herder p. 382; Hortus 3:
1206; ME 3: 352, 355; Moebius p. 395; NI 2105; PR 9990-9991, ed. 1: 10977-10978;
Ratzeburg p. 157-158; Rehder 5: 901; Tucker 1: 730; Zander ed. 11, p. 832.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Applet. Cyc. Amer. biogr. 6: 346. 1889.
Darlington, W., Reliq. Baldw. 163. 1843; Memorials 467. 1849.
Hess, R., Lebensbild. hervorrag. Forstmänn. 394-396. 1885 (biogr., sources).

Meusel, J.G., Lex. teut. Schriftst. 14: 408-409. 1815 (bibl.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wangenheimia</em> Moench (1794); <em>Wangenheimia</em> F.G. Dietrich (1810).

Wangerin, Walther [Leonhard] (1884-1938), German (Prussian-Saxony) botanist;
studied mathematics and natural sciences at Halle University; Dr. phil. ib. 1906; assist-
ant to A. Engler in Berlin-Dahlem 1906; high school teacher at Burg in Magdeburg
1909, id. in Königsberg 1911; lecturer in botany at the Technical College of Danzig

PAGE: 57
HEADING: WANGERIN

1913, later extraordinary professor of botany ib. and, from 1920 divisional director of
the Danzig Museum of Natural History and Prehistory. (<em>Wanger</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (probably destroyed at Danzig); the types of the work
for the Pflanzenreich were at B. – Ferns at B (extant). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 663; Barnhart 3: 457 (b. 15 Apr 1884, d. 19
Apr 1938); BFM 150, 191, 192, 1636; Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9741-9742; BJI 2: 186; BL 2:
563, 730; BM 5: 2262; Bossert p. 425; Hirsch p. 315; Hortus 3: 1206; KR p. 750; LS
suppl. 29292-29293; MW p. 521; TL-2/1713, 11.174, see E.O.O. Kirchner, C. Schröter;
Tucker 1: 730; Zander ed. 10, p. 730, ed. 11, p. 832.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 125: 320. 1914 (app. Danzig); Hedwigia 55: (72). 1914

Wann, Frank Burkett (1892-1954), American botanist; A.B. Wabash Col. 1914; Dr.
phil. Cornell 1920; teaching fellow Shaw School Bot. 1914-1915; instructor in botany
Cornell 1915-1923, nat. research fellow in biology 1923-1926; associate professor of
botany, Utah State Agr. Coll., Logan, Utah 1926-1946; professor of botany and (from
1952) head of the Department of botany and plant pathology 1946-1954. (<em>Wann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UTC. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: with Walter Conrad Muenscher (1891-1963)

ib.; fasc. 2 (nos. 51-100?) 1926, Ithaca. Sets at BPI, CM, CU, CUP, FH, IA, MICH,
NY, NYS, TRTC, WISC. – For full details see J. Stevenson (1971).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 457 (d. 16 Apr 1892); Hirsch p. 315; Kelly
p. 237; TL-2/see W.L.C. Muenscher.

Wanner, Stefan (<em>fl</em>. 1885), Swiss botanist and high school teacher at Zürich. (<em>Wanner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Warburg, Edmund Frederic (1908-1966), British botanist; MA Cambridge 1934;
assistant lecturer Bedford College, London 1938-1941; curator Druce herbarium Oxford
1948-1966. (<em>E. Warb.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OXF; other material at BCW, BM (Euphrasia, Sorbus, incl.
types), CGE, DBN, EGBH, K, NMW.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 1422-1424; BL 1: 87, 323, 2: 216, 217, 730; Bossert

2/15.398, see T.G. Tutin; Zander ed. 10, p. 730, ed. 1, p. 833.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) With E.R. Clapham and T.G. Tutin, <em>Flora British Isles</em>, 1952 (ed.
2, 1962; rev. Kew Bull. 17(3): 471-472. 1964) and <em>Excursion flora of the British Isles</em> 1959
(ed. 2, 1968), rev. Kew Bull. 23: 521-522. 1969).
(2) Editor, <em>Census Catalogue of British mosses</em>, 1963.
(3) Editor, <em>Watsonia</em> 1949-1960.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) E.F. Warburg's father, Oscar Emmanuel Warburg (1876-1937) was an
amateur floristic botanist, interested in Quercus, Cistus and Sorbus. He published with
his son e.g. <em>Preliminary study of genus Cistus</em>, J.R. Hort. Soc. 1930: 1-52. See Desmond p.
639.
(2) Warburg's nickname "Heff" [also "Hep"] was derived from the Winnie the Pooh
character Heffalump, outstanding because of his appetite; the nickname was acquired at
one of the Sunday tea parties given by Gilbert Carter at the Cambridge botanical
garden.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Warburg Nature Reserve</em>, Henley-on-Thames (see V.N. Paul 1980).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Fl. males. ser. I. 1: clii. 1950.

16.641. <em>Taxonomy and relationship in the Geraniales</em> in the light of their cytology ... Cam-
bridge (at the University Press) 1938. Oct. 

[<em>1</em>]: 29 Apr 1938, cover-t.p., p. [i, recto of 130], [130]-159. <em>Copies</em>: B, NY. - Reprinted
	and to be cited from New Phytologist 37(2): [130]-159. 1938.
[<em>2</em>]: 28 Jun 1938, ib. 37(3): 189-210. 1938.

Warburg, Otto (1859-1938), German (Hamburg) botanist; studied at Bonn, Berlin
and Hamburg; Dr. phil. Strassburg (with A. de Bary) 1883; worked at Univ. München
1883-1884 and Tübingen 1884-1885; travelled in S.E. Asia, Oceania and Australia
1885-1889; lecturer ("Privatdocent") Berlin Univ. 1891; lecturer at the Oriental semi-
nary ib. 1894, from 1898 as professor; director of the Agricultural Research Station of
the Zionist Organisation in Palestine 1921; from 1925 professor of botany and director of
the Institute of Natural History of Palestine, Hebrew Univ., Jerusalem, maintaining a
residence in Berlin; member of the Zionist Executive from 1905, president World Zionist
Organisation 1911-1920. (<em>Warb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (other material at A, C, E, FH, GH, H, K, MANCH, P,
TUR-V (lich.). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 345; Backer p. 621; Barnhart 3: 458 (b. 20
Jul 1859, d. 10 Jan 1938); Biol.-Dokum. 18: 9744-9745; BJI 1: 61, 2: 186; BL 1: 23, 117,
120, 121, 323; BM 5: 2262-2263, 8: 1393; Bossert p. 426; CSP 11: 747, 19: 467; Hegi
5(1): 585; Hirsch p. 315; Hortus 3: 1206; LS 28288-28290, suppl. 29295-29299; MW p.
521; Rehder 5: 902-902; SBC p. 134; SK 1: 559-561, cxxiv, 4: clxi [index]; TL-2/1713,
10.288, 10,710, 10.891, 15.687; Tucker 1: 82, 730, 2: xxxix, 3: 326; Urban-Berl. p. 269,
283, 316, 408; Zander ed. 10, p. 730, ed. 11, p. 833.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 48: 366. 1891 (habil. Berlin); Bot. Zeit. 50: 48. 1892
	(habil. Berlin); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 252: 773-774. 1965; Cat. gén. livr.
	impr. Bibl. natl. 218: 239-242. 1973; Der Tagesspiegel 19 Jul 1959 (comm. birth 20
	Jul 1859); Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 454. 1969; Nature 141: 150. 1938 (d.);
	Nat. Nov. 20: 213. 1898 (tit. prof. Univ. Berlin).

Ward, Francis [Frank] Kingdon (1885-1958), British plant collector, traveller and
author; studied at Christ's College, Cambridge; teacher at the Shanghai Public School
1906; travelled in W. China 1909-1910; professional plant collector from 1911-1956,
active in China 1911, 1913, 1921-1923; North Burma 1914, 1919, 1926, 1930-1931,
1937, 1938-1939, 1942, 1953; South East Tibet 1924, 1933, 1935; Assam 1927-1928,
1935, 1938, 1946, 1948, 1949; French Indo-China 1929; Thailand 1941; East Manipur
1948; Assam-Tibet 1950; Mount Victoria, West Burma 1956; Veitch memorial medal
1934; O.B.E. 1952; son of Harry Marshall Ward. (<em>F.K. Ward</em>).

PAGE: 64
HEADING: F.K. WARD.

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM; material in A, CGE, DPU, E, F, GB, K, MO, NY. – <em>Field
notes</em> e.g. at NY.

Ward, Harry Marshall (1854-1906), British botanist; B.A. Christ's College Cam-
bridge 1879; cryptogamic botanist to the Ceylon Government (coffee leaf disease) 1880-
1882; assistant lecturer Owens College, Manchester 1883-1885; professor of botany,
Royal Indian Engineering College, Coopers Hill 1885-1895; professor of botany, Univ.
Cambridge 1895-1906. (<em>H.M. Ward</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: CGE, E, K, NMW. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, K.

GR p. 418; Jackson p. 170; Kelly p. 237, 259; KR p. 750; LS 28292-28348, 40407-
40429a; Morren ed. 10, p. 76, 151; Rehder 5: 902; Tucker 1: 731, 3: 324, 326.

Ward, Lester Frank (1841-1913), American botanist, philosopher and sociologist; in
the Union army 1862-1864; with the U.S. Treasury Department, Washington, D.C.
1865-1881; A.B. Columbian College [later George Washington Univ.] 1869, A.M. ib.
1872; turned to botany in 1872; assistant geologist with the United States Geological
Survey 1881, geologist ib. 1883, palaeontologist ib. 1892; from ca. 1881 also active as a
sociologist, pioneer of evolutionary sociology in the United States. (<em>Ward</em>)

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US. – Other material in A, AK, BH, BUF, CGE, CM, F, GH,
ILL, K, MO, NA, NY, PH. – <em>Manuscript</em> material, books and letters at Brown Univers-
ity, Library of Congress, Smithsonian Institution and U.S. Geological Survey; <em>further
letters</em> e.g. at FH, G, GH, NY. – Personal diary destroyed except for 1860-1870 period
(see Ward 1935).

Apr 1913); BJI 1: 61; BL 1: 172, 323; Bossert p. 426; CSP 11: 748, 12: 769-770, 19: 470;
DAB 19: 430-432. 1936 (J.Q.D.); Ewan ed. 1: 331-332, ed. 2: 232; IH 1 (ed. 6): 365,

PAGE: 67
HEADING: L.F. WARD

Ward, Nathaniel Bagshaw (1791-1868), British physician and botanist; inventor
(1829) of the Wardian case; examiner in botany to the Society of Apothecaries 1836-
1854; master (1854) and later treasurer of this Society; co-founder of the Microscopical
Society; practicing in London; in retirement at St. Leonard's, Sussex. (<em>N.B. Ward</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (p.p.; purchased from estate 1869), OXF (p.p.); further
material in DBN, E, FRS, GL, K, NMW, WAR. – <em>Letters</em> at G, GH, K, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 621; Barnhart 3: 458 (d. 4 Jun 1868); BB p.
