<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, ed. 3 (1869) and ed. 4 (1887) of <em>Naturgeschichte des
Pflanzenreiches nach dem Linnéschen System</em> [based on G.H. von Schubert <em>Lehrbuch der Natur-
geschichte</em> ...], see TL-2/11.202.
(2) Editor, F. Loscos, <em>Series inconfecta plantarum ... Aragoniae</em> 1863, see TL-2/5011.
(3) G. Kunze, <em>Chloris austro-hispanica</em> 1846 (TL-2/4042) is based on Wilkomm's collect-
ions. [G. Kunze induced W. to make his first trip to Spain].
(4) Edited and amended E.A. Rossmässler, <em>Der Wald</em>, ed. 2, 1870-1871 and ed. 3, 1880-
1881, see TL-2/9584.
(5) Introduction and methodological essay to Aglaia von Enderes, <em>Frühlingsblumen</em> 1882,
see ÖbZ 32: 174. 1882 (came out in 12 Lieferungen, all in 1882).
(6) Collaborator, W.D.J. Koch, <em>Syn. deut. schweiz. Fl.</em> ed. 3 (by E. Hallier) 1890 [-1895],
see TL-2/3804.

17.853. <em>Die mikroskopischen Feinde des Waldes</em>. Naturwissenschaftliche Beiträge zur Kennt-
niss der Baum- und Holzkrankheiten, für Forstmänner und Botaniker, bearbeitet und in
zwanglosen Heften herausgegeben ... Erstes [-Zweites] Heft ... Dresden (G. Schönfeld's

Willmott, Ellen Ann (1858-1934), British horticulturist, had gardens at Warley Place,
Essex, Aix-les-Bains and on the Riviera. (<em>E. Willm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: K (Herb. Warleyense), 30 Rosac. in BR. – Original drawings for
<em>The genus Rosa</em> are in the Lindley Library (R. Hort. Soc), London. - <em>Letters</em> at G.

Wilms, Friedrich, Junior (1848-1919), German (Westphalian) pharmacist, botanist
and plant collector; pharmacist in Münster until 1882; id. in S. Africa 1882-1896, e.g. at
Lydenburg, Transvaal, later in Berlin, some time assistant (1904, 1910-1913) at the
Botanical Museum and Herbarium. (<em>Wilms</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MSTR (incl. herb. F. Wilms Sr.); other material at B (mainly
destroyed), BP, BR, BM, E, G, GH, GOET, GRA, H, JE, K, L, M, MO, NU, PH, PR,
PRE, SI, W, WRSL, Z. - <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 502; CSP 12: 785, 19: 643; Zep-Tim p. 118.

	(Transvaal plants for sale).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wilmsia</em> Körber (1865).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wilm's father, Friedrich Heinrich Wilms 1811-1880, pharmacist at Münster, as-
sembled a major herbarium which was offered for sale by the son in 1908-1909
(Herbarium 8: 63. 1909, ÖbZ 59: 40. 1909) and by Th. Weigel in 1909 (Herbarium 50:
521. 1919). The collection had been continued by F. Wilms junior and contained 40.000
phanerogams. The bryophytes were combined by Weigel with those of Sydow, and
offered for sale separately (Herbarium 52: 15. 1920). Both collections are now at
MSTR. Other material of Wilms sen. is at B (mainly destr.) and M. Biography of Wilms
sen.: H. Landois, Jahresber. Westfäl. Prov.-Ver. Wiss. Kunst 8: 164-172. 1880; see also
GR p. 154.

Wilpert, Hubert (1901-x), German (Silesian) botanist and pharmacist; studied at the
University of Breslau; pharm. state exam. 1927; Dr. phil. Breslau 1928; assistant at the
Pharmaceutical Institute, Breslau from 1928. (<em>Wilpert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

census, indicating its distribution through the 112 Watsonian vice-county divisions of
Great Britain, and R. Lloyd Praeger's 40 county divisions of Ireland, also the Channel
Islands ... Berwick-on-Tweed (Martin's printing works Ltd., ...) 1930. Oct. (<em>Census cat.

17.880. <em>The flora of Westmorland</em> an account of the flowering plants, ferns and their allies,
mosses, hepatics and lichens so far known to occur in the county. With particulars as to
their localities, usual habitats, grade of citizenship, distribution in the six river basins,
altitudinal range, time of flowering, first records &amp;c. Also description of the physical
geography, topography, geology, climate and botanical features, a bibliography, and a
short account of some early pioneers of Westmorland field botany ... Arbroath (printed

Wilson, Ernest Henry (1876-1930), British-born American botanist, plant collector
and traveller; Kew gardener 1897-1899; collected in China for Veitch &amp; Son 1899-1902,
1903-1905; to U.S. 1906, collecting in China on behalf of Arnold Arboretum 1906-1909,
1910-1911, in Japan 1914, 1917-1919; assistant director Arnold Arboretum 1919-1927,
in Far East, India and Africa 1920-1921; keeper Arnold Arboretum 1927-1930,
"Chinese Wilson", Sc.D. h.c. Trinity College, Hartford, Conn. (<em>E. Wils.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: A; other material at AAH, AMES, B (mainly destr.), BM, C,
CAS, CGE, DBN, DPU, E, F, GH, HK, K (major set), MO, NY, P, PC, PNH, US, W.
- <em>Field notes and manuscripts</em>: A (including Veitch letters). - <em>Letters</em> at G, HH, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 627; Barnhart 3: 503; BJI 2: 192; BL 1: 119,
324; BM 8: 1441; Bossert p. 438; DAB 20: 321-322 (J.G.Jack); Dawson p. 666 (b. 15
Feb 1876, d. 15 Oct 1930); Hortus 3: 1207; IH 1 (ed. 2): 63, (ed. 7): 41, 78, (ed. 6): 366,
(ed. 7): 346; Langman p. 807; Lenley p. 437; MW p. 530-532 (main bibl.), suppl. 395;

Wilson, Guy West (1877-1956), American botanist; M.Sc. DePauw 1903; professor of
biology Mount Union College 1903-1904; high school teacher Lafayette, Indiana 1904-
1905; Dr. sci. Purdue 1906; aide New York Botanical Garden 1906-1907; professor of
biology Upper Iowa Univ. 1907-1910; assistant plant pathology North Carolina Expt.
Station 1910-1912; assistant professor of mycology Iowa 1914-1916; associate botanist
Clemson College 1918-1919; professor of biology Upper Iowa Univ. 1919-1927, at Penn
College 1927-1930; from 1930 onward engaged in private research. (<em>G.W. Wils.</em>).

<em>Exsiccatae</em>: with F.J. Seaver, (1877-1970), <em>Ascomycetes and lower fungi</em>, fasc. 1-4, nos. 1-100,

Wilson, Percy (1879-1944), American botanist; at the New York Botanical Garden
from 1899-1944; as assistant 1899, briefly stationed on Cuba in 1904; administrative
assistant 1907, docent 1910, assistant curator and docent 1911, assistant curator 1912-
1913, associate curator 1914-1939, research associate 1940-1944; assistant to N.L.
Britton, collected widely in the West Indies. (<em>P. Wils.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY. – Other material at A, B (mainly destr.), CUP, DPU,

Wiltshear, Frederick Gilbert (1882-1917), British botanical bibliographer; with the
Botanical Department of Botany of the British Museum from 1896 as boy-attendant,
from 1905 as librarian; with the King's Royal Rifles on active service in World War I;
died "of wounds" in France 1917. (<em>F. Wiltshear</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 505; BB p. 331; BL 2: 484, 733; Desmond p.
669; GF p. 88; NI 2164; SK 4(5): clxxxvii; SO 454.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Not. 1918: 168 (d.); J. Bot. 56: 32 ("23"). 1918.
Britten, J., J. Bot. 56: 117-118. 1918 (obit., b. 15 Jan 1882, died in France 23 November
	1917).

to botany</em> 1760, 1765 and glossary], J. Bot. 53: 66-67, 112. 1915.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Contributed bibliographical notes to J. Bot. 1909, 1912-1915 (see e.g. Taxon 14:

and G.S. Boulger, Biogr. index Brit. Irish bot. ed. 2. 1931.

Wiltshear, Samuel Paul (1891-1967), British mycologist; M.A. Cambridge; Dr. phil.
Bristol 1913; mycologist Long Ashton Research Station 1919-1922; assistant director,
Imperial Bureau of Mycology, Kew 1924-1939, director 1940-1956. (<em>S. Wiltshear</em>).

Wimmer, Franz Elfried (1881-1961), Austrian botanist and roman-catholic clergy-
man; studied theology and natural sciences at the Universities of Vienna and Graz;
ordained priest 1907; professor of natural history at St. George's College, Istanbul 1905-
1918; priest at several localities in and around Vienna 1918-1958, also unofficial re-
search associate of the Vienna Natural History Museum, ultimately "correspondent" of
that institution. (<em>F.E. Wimm.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; other material in B (extant), G (incl. some types), K (incl.
some types), MICH (incl some types), NY, US (incl. some types).

Wimmer, [Christian] Friedrich [Heinrich] (1803-1868), German (Silesian) bota-
nist and high school teacher; studied philology and natural sciences at the University of
Breslau 1821-1826; teacher at the Friedrichs-Gymnasium Breslau 1826; professor's title
1835, director 1843-1863; municipal school inspector ("Schulrath") charged with the
reform of the Breslau school system 1863-1868; actively interested in plant taxonomy of
the classics as well as in the flora of Silesia and the genus Salix; Dr. phil. h.c. Breslau
1853. (<em>Wimm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL. – Further material in AUT, B (mainly destr.), BM,
GFW, HBG, K, KIEL, LE, LI, LZ (destr.), MANCH, MW, OXF, P, PR, REG, W. -
Material outside WRSL mainly <em>Herbarium Salicum</em>.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Herbarium Salicum</em>, Sammlung getrockneter Weidenarten, Abarten und Bas-
tarde zunächst in Schlesien. Herausgegeben von Wimmer und Krause [Ernst Krause, d.
1858]. Erstes Heft, Nro. 1-12, see Flora 32: 495-496. 1849; series continued until decas
12, 1-12, 1849-1858. Sets (see above). – <em>Letters</em> G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 43: 319-321 (E. Wunschmann); AG 2(2): 93, 4:
310, 12(3): 368; Andrews p. 349; Backer p. 627; Barnhart 3: 505 (b. 30 Oct 1803, d. 12

767; LS 29052-29054; PR 244, 3626, 8126, 9201-9203, 10309-10316, ed. 1: 294, 3944,
10.167, 11.282; Rehder 5: 925; RS p. 149; TL-1/1434-1435; TL-2/see H.R. Goeppert;

17.921. <em>Wildwachsende Bastardpflanzen</em>, hauptsächlich in Schlesien beobachtet ... [Breslau
(Verlag von Josef Max &amp; Komp.) 1853]. Qu. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1853, p. [143]-182. <em>Copies</em>: BR, HH, MO. – Reprinted [or tearsheets?] and to be
	cited from <em>Denkschrift zur Feier ihres fünfzigjährigen Bestehens</em> herausgegeben von der
	Schlesischen Gesellschaft für vaterländische Kultur, Breslau 1853, p. [143]-182. -
	Review of Denkschrift, with notes on W.'s contribution, Bonplandia 2: 77-78. 15 Mar
	1854.
<em>Note</em>: Wimmer published several papers on Salix hybrids from 1841 onward. His first

PAGE: 362
HEADING: F. WIMMER

	paper on hybridization, however, was on <em>Digitalis</em>, Uebers. Arb. Veränd. Schles. Ges.
	vaterl. Kult. 1832: 61-62, 1835: 85, followed by a discussion of the "Bastardnatur" of
	<em>Geum intermedium</em>, ib. 1838: 135. The first paper on Salix hybrids <em>Ueber 6 Weidenbas-
	tarde</em>, appeared ib. 1841: 93-94, followed by a more general <em>Ueber die Hybridität im
	Pflanzenreiche</em>, ib. 1843: 208-209. For the summary of his research on <em>Salix</em> see <em>Salices
	europaeae</em>, below (1866).

Winch, Nathaniel John (1768-1838), British botanist; in Newcastle from 1786; long-
time secretary to the Newcastle Infirmary in Newcastle; travelled in France and S.
Europe 1790-1791. (<em>Winch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (plants corr.), CGE, FI, HAMU (herb.), K, LINN (Rosa
and Salix retained; herb., corr. and mss. originally left to LINN but major parts passed
on to BM and HAMU; herb. specimens also in LINN-Smith). – <em>Letters</em> at G, LINN (see
Davies &amp; Leathart 1986).

Winchell, Newton Horace (1839-1914), American botanist and geologist; studied at
the University of Michigan 1858-1866; M.Sc. 1869; volunteer collector for the Michigan
Geological Survey 1859-1860, collector id. 1869-1870; with the Ohio Geological Survey
1871-1872; state geologist of Minnesota 1872; with the University of Minnesota 1872-
1900. (<em>Winchell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: [NO specimens collected in Michigan in MICH].

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 506 (17 Dec 1839, d. 3 Mai 1914); BM 5:
2336, 8: 1443-1444; ME 1: 241; Merrill p. 536, 567, 715; PH 301, 567; Quenstedt p. 463;
SIA see index; Tucker 1: 145, 749.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Science ser. 2. 39: 719. 1914 (d.).
Bain, H.F., Economic Geology 11(1): 51-62. 1916 (on W. and the American Geologist).
Clarke, J.M., Science ser. 2. 40: 127-130. 1914 (obit.).
Schuchert, Ch., Amer. J. Sci. 187: 566. 1914 (obit.).
Upham, W., Bull. Geol. Soc. Amer. 26: 27-46. 31 Mar 1915 (obit., portr., bibl.);
	Economic Geology 11: 63-72. 1916 (on W.'s work on glacial geology and archeology).
Voss, E., Contr. Univ. Mich. Herb. 13: 34, 35, 36, 37, 39, 46-47, 63-64, 85. 1978.
Wilson, J.G. &amp; J.F., eds., Appleton's Cycl. Amer. biogr. 6: 560. 1889.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Catalogue of phanerogamous and acrogenous plants</em> found growing <em>in the
lower peninsula of Michigan</em> and the islands at the head of Lake Huron, <em>in</em> Alexander
Winchell, Rep. State Geol. Surv. Michigan 1861(3): [243]-330.
(2) <em>List of trees and shrubs, in</em> W. Ludlow, Rept. reconn. Black Hills Dakota 1875, 67-73.
(3) Main founder and editor of the <em>American Geologist</em> 1888-1905.

HEADING: WINCHELL

Alex. Winchell, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, U.S.A. (see below).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Winchell's brother, the geologist Alexander Winchell (1824-1891) published a
<em>Catalogue of plants found growing without cultivation in the vicinity of Amenia seminary</em>, Rep. New
York State Cabinet nat. Hist. 1851: 256-279. – For further information on Alexander
Winchell's botanical activities (he was professor of geology, zoology and botany at Ann
Arbor (Univ. Michigan) 1854-1873) see K.C. Jones, Michigan Academ. 9: 268, 272.
1977, and E.G. Voss, Contr. Univ. Mich. Herb. 13: 34, 35, 46, 58, 62, 69, 87. 1978. A
small collection of plants collected by A. Winchell in Alabama is at US. For further
information see ME 1: 241, 3: 679, and J.G. Wilson &amp; J. Fiske, eds., Appleton's Cycl.
Amer. biogr. 6: 560. 1889.

Winge, Øjvind (1886-1964), Danish botanist; Mag. sci. (bot.) 1910; assistant at the
physiological department of the Carlsberg laboratories, Copenhagen. 1911-1921; Dr.
phil. Copenhagen 1917; professor of genetics at the Agricultural College 1921-1933;
lectured in genetics at Copenhagen University 1929-1935; professor at the Carlsberg
laboratories and director of the physiological department 1933-1956; interested in my-
cological systematics, cytology, genetics and hybridization. (<em>Winge</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Some material in C. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, G.

Winkelmann, Johannes (1842-1921), German (Berlin) high school teacher, botanist
and conservationist; ultimately professor at the Schiller-Realgymnasium in Stettin.
(<em>Winkelmann</em>).

<em>Ref</em>.: Warnstorf, C.F.E., Bot. Centralbl., Beih. 3(5): 371-372. 1893.

Winkler, [Karl Gustaf] Adolf (1810-1893), German (Silesian) military administrator
and botanist, pseudonym A. Carex; studied law and military administration in Berlin;
"Intendantur-Assessor" [assistant military administrator] at Koblenz 1840-1843,
Frankfurt a.O. 1843-1844; in Berlin id. 1844-1848, administrator 1848-1857, senior ad-
ministrator ("ältester Rat") Breslau 1857-1860; from 1860 in Berlin; administrator of
the third Prussian army corps in the Franco-Prussian war 1870-1871; from 1871 in
retirement as "Geheimer Kriegsrat"; brother of Moritz Winkler; treasurer of the
Botanischc Verein der Provinz Brandenburg 1870-1890. (<em>A. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (seedling herbarium left to B on his death; main herbarium via
P. Ascherson also to B; this material mostly destr., but a significant number of specimens
extant in herb. Ullepitsch), GOET (Koblenz material), WRSL (in herb. M. Winkler). –
<em>Library</em> left to the Bot. Ver. Prov. Brandenburg (now destr.). – <em>Letters</em> at G, Sondershau-
scn (see Müllerott (1980)), UPS-UB. – <em>Manuscripts</em>: 20 vols. of drawings of seedlings
were at B (rd. 1910 from A. Magnus; destr. 1943).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 507 (b. 27 Nov 1810, d. 29 Nov 1893); Biol.-
Dokum. 19: 10084-10085; CSP 6: 395, 11: 824, 12: 786-787, 19: 661-662; Morren ed. 10,
p. 7; Rehder 5: 926; Urban-Berl. p. 411; Zep-Tim p. 181.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Jahrb. 18 (Beibl. 43): 47. 1893 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 44: 80. 1894
	(d.); Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 35: [iii*], lxxviii. 1894 (death notice, d. 29 Nov
	1893).
Ascherson, P., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenburg 35: xxxii-xxxvii. 1894 (obit., bible.); Ber.
	deut. bot. Ges. 12: (11)-(13). 1894 (obit.).
Lack, H.W. &amp; D. Wagner, Willdenowia 14: 432. 1984 (coll. B).
Milde, J., Verh. bot. Ver. Brandenb. 3-4: 290-295. 1862 (note on W.'s paper on the
	Silesian Flora in id. 2: 107-115. 1860).
Müllerott, M., Hoppea 39: 62. 1980 (letters to Th. Irmisch).
Natho, G., Gleditschia 12: 171-179. 1984 (Am Rande. A. Carex [= A. Winkler] und
	seine Karikaturen; further biogr. and bibl. documentation).

	see also Taxon 25: 651-652. 1976.
<em>Note</em>: Natho reproduces also the t.p. of <em>Illustrationen zur deutschen Flora in Feder-Zeichnungen
	</em>von A. Carex, zweite vermehrte Ausgabe, Berlin (id.), 1870, and mentions in the text
	the first edition of this title of 1864. Dr. H.W. Lack found a copy of the original 1864
	edition for us in B: <em>Illustrationen zur deutschen Flora</em> gezeichnet von A. Carex. Berlin (Für
	die Mitglieder des botan. Vereins gedruckt). 1864, a manuscript reproduced by litho-
	graphy consisting of 41 unnumbered leaves carrying handcoloured botanical illustrat-
	ions without text).

Winkler, Constantin [Konstantin] Georg Alexander (1848-1900), Russian botanist
of Baltic German origin; studied botany at Dorpat 1871-1874; assistant botanical garden
Dorpat 1874-1879; curator of the herbarium of the St. Petersburg botanical garden
1879-1897; head botanist ib. 1897-1899; from 1899-1900 in Wesenberg. (<em>C. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE. – Further material possibly at TU. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 1: 64; Bret. p. 1076; CSP 11: 825, 12: 787; De Toni
1: cxxxii; DTS 1: 329; Herder p. 485 [index]; Hortus 3: 1207; LS 29075-29077; Morren
ed. 10, p. 95; MW p. 533; Rehder 5: 926; TR 1604-1605; Tucker 1: 750.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 1-2: 320. 1880 (app. St. Petersburg), 55: 262. 1893 (coll.
	LE), 80: 240. 1899 (leaves St. Petersburg); Hedwigia 38: 297. 1899 (leaves St.
	Petersburg).
Lipschitz, S., Florae URSS fontes no. 275. 1975.
Welding, O. et al., Deutschbalt. biogr. Lex. 1710-1960. 870. 1970 (b. Velikie Luki 14
	Jun 1848, d. 3 Feb 1900).
Winkler, C., S.B. Dorpat naturf. Ges. 4(1): 29-35. 1876 (a report on the contents of the
	herbarium of the Dorpater Gesellschaft, now at TU).

Naturforscher-Gesellschaft) 1877. Oct.

Winkler, Eduard (1799-?), German author of botanical-pharmaceutical illustrated
works in Eutritzsch near Leipzig. (<em>E. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2338; Herder p. 414; Jackson p. 201; NI 1114,
2167-2169 (b. Leipzig); Plesch p. 461; PR 10326-10334, ed. 1: 11296-11307; Rehder 5:
926; Sotheby 815-817; TL-2/4040; Tucker 1: 750.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print, books 381-382. 1965.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor, with A. Weinlig, of <em>Pharmaceutisches Central-Blatt</em> 1839-
1844.

PAGE: 370
HEADING: E. WINKLER

(2) Contributed plates to G. Kunze, <em>Farrnkräuter</em> 1840-1851, TL-2/4040.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Our coverage of the products of this industrious botanical artist of modest genius
is incomplete. His books seem to be rather rare and have now only historical value.

HEADING: HA. WINKLER

<em>Publ</em>.: 1846, p. [1]-108. <em>Copies</em>: HH, MO.
<em>Note</em>: Text accompanying <em>Getreue Abbildung aller in den Pharmacopöen Deutschlands aufgenom-
	menen officinellen Gewächse</em> ... published in Lieferungen 1840-1844. Came out in various
	"editions", in all with 270 pl. (in 54 Lieferungen of 5 plates each), of which we saw
	"eds." 4 and 6 in HH. Hinrichs cites the first edition of this work as "Handbuch"
	published in 54 Lieferungen between 20-26 Dec 1840 and 3-6 Apr 1844 (incomplete
	copy at NY).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1844-1857 (in Lieferungen), p. [i]-viii, [1]-12, [i]-xxiv, [1-2], <em>pl</em>. [<em>1-190</em>] (with
	text). <em>Copy</em>: MO (col. copp.). – May have come out also earlier, PR 10332 mentions
	1844-1851, Leipzig, Schäfer. The preface (p. viii) is dated 20 Aug 1844. Hinrichs cites
	the publication of the 2. Lieferung 27 Feb-1 Mar 1845. – Junk, cat. 206, 1977, no. 329
	offered a copy dated 1852, 2 vols., viii, 12, <em>189 pl</em>., which may represent the (almost
	completed) first issue, not seen by us.

Winkler, Hans Karl Albert (1877-1945), German (Sachsen) botanist; studied at Kiel
1895; Leipzig 1895-1898; Dr. phil. ib. 1898; hon. lecturer botany Tübingen 1901-1905;
travelled to Ceylon, Java, New Guinea, New Zealand, Samoa and North America 1903-
1904; extra-ordinary professor of forest botany Tübingen 1905-1912; head of the
scientific division of the Hamburg botanical institutes and professor of botany 1912-1945
(director Inst. Allg. Bot. Univ. Hamb. from 1919); in Central Borneo 1924-1925; died in
Dresden. (<em>Ha. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG. – Other material in BM, E, G, K, TUR-V. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 507; Biol.-Dokum. 10087-10089; BJI 2: 192;
BM 8: 1445; CSP 19: 663; Hirsch p. 326; Hortus 3: 1207; IH 1 (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7): 346;
Lenley p. 439; LS 40647; Moebius p. 157, 458 [index]; SK 1(4): clxi, 578-579 (itin.,coll.,
portr.), 4(2): cxlvi, 5: cccxxxiii, 8: cviii; TL-2/see indexes; Tucker 3: 338.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 87: 160. 1901 (habil. Tübingen), 93: 336. 1903 (to
	Buitenzorg), 96: 416. 1904 (back from Buitenzorg), 99: 96. 1905 (titular e.o. prof.),
	101: 432. 1906 (regular e.o. prof), 120: 320. 1912 (app. Hamburg), 140: 368. 1919
	(dir. Inst. allg. Bot. Hamburg); Bot. Zeit. 64: 128. 1906 (regular e.o. prof. Tübingen),
	68: 136. 1910 (prize Vahlbruchstiftung); Hamburger Nachrichten 4 Apr 1925 (ac-
	count trip Borneo); Hedwigia 40: (175). 1901 (habil.), 42: (350). 1903 (to
	Buitenzorg), 45: (38) (e.o. prof. forest. bot. Tübingen), (161) (regular e.o. prof.
	applied bot., ib.) 1906, 53: (96), (235). 1912 (app. Hamburg); Nat. Nov. 23: 471.
	1901 (habil. Tübingen), 27: 427, 460. 1905 (e.o. prof. forest botany Tübingen), 41:
	80. 1919 (dir. Inst. allg. Bot. Hamburg); Österr. bot. Z. 55: 372. 1905 (e.o. prof.
	Tübingen), 62: 351. 1912 (app. Hamburg), 68: 292. 1919 (ord. prof.).
Bergdolt, E., Karl von Goebel ed. 2. 262 [index]. 1941.
Biermann, K.R. &amp; G. Dunken, Deut. Akad. Wiss. Berlin, Biogr. Index Mitgl. 128. 1960
	(b. 23 Apr 1877, d. Dresden 22 Nov 1945; corr. memb. Akad. 1927).

	Allg. Bot. Hamburg 11: 7-8. 1957 (obit.).

PAGE: 374
HEADING: HU.WINKLER

Winkler, Hubert [J.P.] (1875-1941), German (Prussian/Brandenburg) botanist;
studied at Breslau University 1895, at first theology, later botany; Dr.phil. Breslau 1905
with F.A. Pax; assistant with the "Landwirtschaftskammer" Breslau 1900-1901; assis-
tant at the Botanical Garden and Museum Breslau 1901-1902; with the Botanical
Museum Berlin 1902-1904; regional botanist Botanical Garden, Victoria, Cameroon
1904-1906; habil. Breslau 1906; with the Breslau Botanical Museum from 1906, assistant
and lecturer 1906-1912, titular professor 1912; travelled in Borneo, Java, Malaysian
Peninsula and Singapore 1908, in East Africa 1910; on active service in World-War I
1914-1919; extraordinary professor of plant geography 1921, from 1927 ordinary prof.
also for systematic botany. (<em>Hu. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.) and WRSL. – Further material at BM, C, G,
K, L, MO, NY, P, PC, PRE, WRSL, Z. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 408; Backer p. 628; Barnhart 3: 507 (b. 13 Feb
1875, d. 10 Jun 1941); Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10089-10090; BJI 2: 192; BM 8: 1445; Bossert
p. 439; DTS 6(4): 208; Futak-Domin p. 660; Hirsch p. 326; Hortus 3: 1207; Langman p.
808; Moebius p. 147, 376; SK 1: cxxiii, 579-580 (itin., coll. portr.), 4: cl, 5: cccxxxiii; SO
2947a, 2960, 3690; TL-2/1711, 1713, 2364, see F.A. Pax; Urban-Berl. p. 270, 284, 292,
317, 411; Zep-Tim. p. 118-119.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 102: 592. 1906 (habil. Breslau); Hedwigia 41: (207).
	1902 (asst. Berlin), 46: (144). 1907 (habil. Breslau), 52: (155). 1912 (app. prof.); Nat.
	Nov. 23: 425. 1901 (first asst. Breslau), 28: 627. 1906 (habil. ib.); Österr. bot. Z. 62:
	247. 1912 (titular prof. Breslau).
Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's ed. 8. 1705. 1922, ed. 9. 1705. 1928.
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 000. 1984.
Leeuwenberg, A.J.M., Webbia 19(2): 863. 1965 (dupl. of holotypes B).
Letouzey, R., Fl. Cameroun 7: 60. 1968 (coll.).
Pax, F., Publ. schles. Bot. 11, 30, 69, 136, 141, 142, 144, 147, 148. 1929.
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 348. 1914.
Unruh, M., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 59: (145)-(169). 1941 (obit., portr., bibl.).
Winkler, Hu., Tropenpflanzer 10: 167-172. 1906 ("1st der Botanische Garten in Victoria
	überflüssig?"), 12: 357-372, 558-568. 1908 (report visit Java experiment stations).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 4: 478. 1938.

of <em>Musaceae</em>, 1: 19-20, <em>maps 11-12</em>. 1927. See TL-2/17.993.
(2) <em>Betulaceae, in</em> A. Engler, ed., <em>Pflanzenreich</em> 4 [61] (Heft 19): [i], 1-149 [150], <em>pl. 1-2</em>. 17
Jun 1904. – See also his <em>Der gegenwärtige Stand der Betula-Systematik</em>, Mitt. deut. dendrol.
Ges. 43: 36-40. 1930; see TL-2/1713.

&amp; F. Pax) 8: 1-6. 15 Jan 1910.

(5) With F. Pax, <em>Vegetationsbilder aus den Südkarpathen, in</em> G. Karsten and H. Schenck,
<em>Veg.-Bild.</em> 15(8). 1924.
(6) <em>Musaceae, in</em> Engler and Prantl, <em>Nat. Pflanzenfam.</em> ed. 2. 15a: 505-541. 1930. See TL-
2/1711.
(7) <em>Cannaceae, in</em> id. 15a: 640-654. 1930. TL-2/1711.

<em>Editors</em>: Emil Hannig (1872-1955) and Hubert Winkler. – <em>Collaborators</em>: Friedrich Ludwig
	Emil Diels (1874-1945, TL-2/1: 646-647); Gunnar Samuelsson (1885-1944, TL-2/5:
	23-25). – Authors of separate maps mentioned on covers of Hefte.
<em>Erste Reihe</em>: 1926-1928, 8 Hefte, preface material [p. i-iv] containing contents:
	<em>1</em>: 1926, cover, <em>maps 1-10</em>, text p. [1-18].
	<em>2</em>: 1926, cover, p. [i-ii], 19-34, <em>maps 11-20</em>.
	<em>3</em>: 1927, cover, 35-44, <em>maps 21-30</em>.
	<em>4</em>: 1927, cover, p. 45-50, <em>maps 31-40</em>.
	<em>5</em>: 1927, cover, p. 51-62, <em>maps 41-50</em>.
	<em>6</em>: 1927, cover, p. 63-72, <em>maps 51-60</em>.
	<em>7</em>: 1927, cover, p. 73-82, <em>maps 61-70</em>.
	<em>8</em>: 1928, cover, p. 83-96, <em>maps 71-80</em>.
<em>Zweite Reihe</em>: 1928-1930, 8 Hefte, preface material p. [i-iv].
	<em>1</em>: 1928, cover, p. 1-12, <em>maps 1-10</em>.
	<em>2</em>: 1928, cover, p. 13-17, <em>maps 11-20</em>.
	<em>3</em>: 1928, cover, p. 19-25, <em>maps 21-30</em>.
	<em>4</em>: 1929, cover, p. 27-34, <em>maps 31-40</em>.
	<em>5</em>: 1929, cover, p. 35-42, <em>maps 41-50</em>.

Winkler, Moritz (1812-1889), German (Silesian) land steward and factory manager at
Giessmanndorf nr Neisse in Silesia; active amateur floristic botanist; brother of [K.G.]
A. Winkler; travelled and collected in Central and Southern Europe; assembled a large
and rich European herbarium. (<em>M. Winkl.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WRSL. – Further material in B (extant, large set), BR, C, E, G,
GB, GH, JE, M, MW, OXF, STU, WB (destr.), WRSL. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB. -
<em>Library</em> at WRSL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 139; Barnhart 3: 507 (b. 13 Feb 1812, d. 21
Dec 1889); Bossert p. 439; Clokie p. 266; CSP 6: 397, 8: 1252, 11: 825, 12: 787, 19: 663
(bibl.); Futak-Domin p. 660; Klásterský p. 205; Maiwald p. 123, 124, 172-173, 187;
Rehder 1: 421; Urban-Berl. p. 411.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 25: 193. 1886 (herb. to WRSL); Bot. Not. 1890: 46 (d.);
	Österr. bot. Z. 36: 106. 1886 (herb. to WRSL), 40: 36. 1890 (d.); Ann. Bot. 2: 494.
	1890 (list publ.).

Winkler, Wilhelm (1842-1927), German (Silesian) teacher and botanist; teacher at
Schreiberhau (Siles.) 1861-1903; in retirement at Görlitz; student of the flora of Sude-
tenland, of folklore and history of Silesia, and reformer of the local schoolsystem. (<em>W.
Winkl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Winslow, Andreas Peter [Pettersson] (1835-1900), Swedish botanist and teacher;
studied at Lund Univ. 1855-1862; Dr. phil. 1862; high school teacher at Göteborg 1865-
1900; especially interested in Rosa. (<em>Winslow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GB. Further material at AK, C, E, F, K, MANCH.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Folkskoleherbarium</em>, 100 [i.e. 102] i ekonomiskt hänseende vigtiga svenska
växter. Göteborg 1870, for text see KR p. 768, nos. 1(a), 1(b).
(2) <em>Herbarium rosarum Scandinaviae</em> fasc. 1, nos. 1-40 (all publ.). Göteborg 1880. Sets at G,
GB, H, MANCH. Published notes: <em>Rosae Scandinaviae</em>, Bot. Not. 1880: 186-191. For list of
species see Bot. Centralbl. 3-4: 1439. 1880.

Winslow, Charles Frederick (1811-1877), American geologist, seismologist and
physician; M.D. Harvard 1834; V.S. consul in Payta, Peru from 1862; visitéd the
Hawaiian Islands, later in California and Utah. (<em>C. Winslow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Winter, [Heinrich] Georg (1848-1887), German (Sachsen) mycologist, son of the
publisher Adolph Winter; trained to succeed his father as publisher in Leipzig and
Giessen; studied natural sciences at the University of Leipzig 1870-1872; id. München
1872-1873 and Halle 1873; Dr. phil. Leipzig 1873; lecturer for botany at the Zürich
Polytechnic 1876-1883, habil. ib. 1878; editor of Hedwigia 1879-1887; from 1883 in
Leipzig in charge of the publication of the fungi for the second edition of Rabenhorst's
Kryptogamenflora. (<em>G. Wint.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (partly extant). – Material in most herbaria in series of exsic-
catae, see below. – Important sets of material in GOET, GFW, HAL, K, MSTR, PC,
WRSL.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) With Johannes Kunze (x-1881, TL-2/2: 705) <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati</em> 1876-
1880, nos. 1-400, 501-600. Sets at B (mainly destr.), BERN, BPI, K (BM), C, DBN, FH,
H, HBG, M, PRE, S, UPS. – For details see D. Pfister, Fung. exsicc. (in press). Nos.

PAGE: 381
HEADING: G. WINTER

301-400 and 501-600 are identical with Fungi helvetici 1-100 and 101-200. Nos. 401-500
never published. – See also IH 2: 396.
(2) <em>Fungi helvetici exsiccati</em>, cent. 1-2, nos. 1-200 and suppl. 1-100 (1880) (nos. 1-200 also
as <em>Fungi selecti exsiccati</em>, see above). Sets at B, FH; for sets of cent. 1-2 only see also above.
(3) <em>Fungi europaei et extraeuropaei exsiccati</em>, cent. 27-36, 1881-1886, see D.H. Pfister, Myco-
taxon 23: 65-67. 1985 (no. v).
(4) Published fasc. 28-29 of <em>G.L.</em> Rabenhorst, <em>Bryotheca europaea</em>, see TL-2/4: 465.
(5) Published decades 258-260 of G.L. Rabenhorst, <em>Die Algen Europa's</em>. See TL-2/4: 465.
(6) <em>Schweizerische Kryptogamen</em> ed. B. Wartmann &amp; G. Winter, nos. 1-750, fasc. 1-15,
1862-1882.
<em>Letters</em> at FH, UPS-UB.

and <em>Winterana</em> Linnaeus (1759) all honor John Winter who travelled with Sir Francis
Drake on his first voyage to Virginia in 1577.

Winter, John Mack (1899-1964), American botanist; Dr. phil. Univ. Nebraska 1932;
assistant in botany Univ. Nebraska 1926-1928; instructor in botany Northwestern Univ.
1928-1930, professor of biology Univ. Nebraska 1930-1932; id. Peru State Teachers
College 1932-1946; at South Dakota University, Brookings 1946-1948, id. at Vermillion
S.D. 1948-1963. (<em>J.M. Wint.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SDU (1200-1500, South Dakota; 700-1000 Turkish plants coll.
1961-1963. – <em>Letters</em> at NY (Barnhart).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world nos. 177, 178. 1984.
Van Bruggen, Th., Letter to P.K. Holmgren 26 Jul 1985 (in TL-2 files; d. 12 Jan 1964).

	Conserv. Dept., Univ. Nebraska; Contr. Bot. Surv. Nebraska no. 10.

PAGE: 384
HEADING: WINTERBOTTOM

Winterbottom, James Edward (1803-1854), British botanist; studied at St. John's
College, Oxford ca. 1821-1828; travelled on the Continent, in England, Scotland and
Ireland 1834-1845; left England 1846 for an Indian tour, Java, Singapore, China, India
and Tibet, part of the time accompanying Richard Strachey on the Tibetan Boundary
Commission; in Great Britain 1849-1854; died on a trip in the Near East. (<em>Winterbottom</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM, CAL, K (main set). – Further material in BR, DBN, E,
GH, LE, NMW (British mat.), P, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 508; BB p. 331; Bret. p. 802; Desmond p.
670 (b. 7 Apr 1803, d. 4 Jul 1854); Ewan ed. 1: 316; SK 1: 581;, 5: cccxxxiii, 8: cviii;
TL-2/13.219, see R. Strachey.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 2: 265. 1854 (obit. not.); Bot. Zeit. 13: 144. 1855 (d.); Bull.
	misc. Inf. Kew 1900: 19-20 (dispersal of herb.; brief sketch of activities); Proc. Linn.
	Soc. 1: 418-419. 1855 (obit.).
Burkill, I.H., Chapt. hist. bot. India 82, 83, 84, 89, 191. 1965.
Hemsley, W.B., J. Linn. Soc. 35: 136-140. 1902 (descr. itin. Tibet 1848).
Hooker, J.D. &amp; Th. Thomson, Fl. ind. 1: 65-66. 1855.
Hooker, W.J., J. Bot. Kew Gard. Misc. 6: 307-308, 345-349. 1854.
Kent, D.H. &amp; D.E. Allen, Brit. Irish herb. 277. 1984 (British herb. not traced).
King, G., J. Bot. 37: 462-463. 1899.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed collections to R. Strachey, <em>Catalogue of plants of Kumaon,
</em>see R. Strachey (1906) and to E.I. Atkinson, <em>Economic products of N.W. Provinces</em> 4: 403-
670. 1876.

Winterl, Jacob Joseph (1739-1809), Austrian botanist, chemist and physician; Dr.
med. et phil. Wien 1767; professor of medicine at the University of Tyrnan (W.
Slovakia); in charge of the botanic garden of Ofen (Buda/Budapest) from 1771-1809,
from 1771 or 1775-1802 ordinary professor of botany at the University of Pesth (Budapest). (<em>Winterl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W (fide Bonplandia 1862: 312). – Further material at GOET
(see Wagenitz 1982). – <em>Letters</em> to N.J. Jacquin at UPS-UB, to J. Banks at BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 717, 7: 50; Backer p. 628; Barnhart 3: 508 (b. 15
Apr 1739); Bossert p. 439; Dawson p. 878; Futak-Domin p. 660; Herder p. 160; Kanitz
P. 38-39 (no. 52); Plesch p. 461; PR 10.339, ed. 1: 11311; Rehder 1: 65; Sotheby 818;
TL-2/see H.J.N. von Crantz; Tucker 1: 750, 3: 338; WU 57: 89-91.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 259: 564. 1965; Encykl. slovenska 6:
	474. 1982; Gen. cat. impr. Bibl. natl. 225: 181. 1976.
Arnim, M., Mitgl.-Verz. Ges. Wiss. Göttingen 1751-1927. 182. 1928 (b. 15 Apr 1732,
	err.).
Becherer, A., J. Bot. 66: 201-202. 1928 (on W.'s species "novae"; the Winterl com-
	binations such as Geranium "novum" are not validly published under the Internat-
	ional Rules, "novum" not being an epithet used as part of a <em>name</em>).

Wirtgen, Ferdinand Paul (1848-1924), German (Prussian/Rheinland) pharmacist
and botanist; studied pharmacy in Koblenz and St. Johann a.d. Saar (Saarbrücken),
state examination Bonn 1873; pharmacist at Eltenheim, Baden 1873-1875, from 1875
again in St. Johann a.d. S., from 1879-1889 as owner of the Frötsch pharmacy; from
1889 in Bonn dedicating himself mainly to botany; son of Philipp Wirtgen. (<em>F. Wirtg.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Main herbarium donated to Ver. preuss. Rheinl. Westfalen (now
BHU), ferns in P (herb. Bonaparte); Musci to Haussknecht (now JE). – Further
material in BR, E, GOET, FR and M. – Duplicate Pteridophytes were still offered for
sale in Herbarium 73: 300. 1928.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Pteridophyta exsiccata</em>, Lieferung 1-16, 1897-1915 (cont. W. Krieger), sets at
B (extant), BHU, M, P, PH, SI.
(2) <em>Herbarium plantarum criticarum select. hybr. Florae Rhenanae</em> (edit. nov.), fasc. 1-6, nos. 1-
300, ca. 1930-1931, published by H. Andres; collections by F. Wirtgen but also by P.W.
Wirtgen. – Sets at FH, NY, PC. – For Heinrich Andres (1883-1970), see TL-2/1: 49.
<em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 628; Barnhart 3: 508 (b. 7 Jan 1848, d. 26 Jan
1924); BFM 326 (index); BJI 2: 193; Bossert p. 439; DTS 6(4): 208; Morren ed. 10, p.
16; Rehder 1: 390; Tucker 1: 750; Urban-Berl. p. 323.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 4: 16. 1898 (Pteridophyta exsiccata Lief. 1), 5: 34-35 (id. 3-
	4), 6: 32. 1900 (id. 5), 7: 40. 1901 (id. 6), 8: 72. 1902 (id. 8): 9: 76. 1903 (id. 8-9), 10:
	143. 1904 (id. 10), 11: 60. 1905 (id. 11), 12: 88. 1906 (id. 12), 13: 139. 1907 (id. 13):
	15: 18. 1909 (id. 14), 15: 48. 1909 (continued by Voigtländer-Tetzner); Allg. bot. Z.
	28/29: 56 (112). 1925 (d.); Herbarium 39: 369. 1915 (Pter. exs. Lief. 16, nos. 1-54.
	1915); J. Bot. 10: 159. 1872 (herb. of his father for sale).

	herb. in BHU).

	portr., bibl.).
Wagenitz, G., Index coll. princ. herb. Gott. 182. 1982 (coll.).

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Wiss. Z. Humboldt Univ. Berlin, Math.-Nat. R. 19(2-3): 297. 1970.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wirtgenia</em> H. Andres (1914).

18.032. <em>Anweisung</em>. Naturhistorischer Verein der Preuss. Rheinlande und Westfalens

Fl. Westdeutschland</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1908, p. [1], [1]-1 7. <em>Copy</em>: B.

<em>Authorship</em>: F. Wirtgen senior author, edited and completed by Heinrich Andres (b.

	bot. zool. Ver. Rheinl. Westfalen 1925: 57-76. 1926. -A continuation of earlier public
	cations with the same title in S.B. bot.-zool. Ver. Rheinl.-Westfalen 1912: 1-7, 1913:
	1-7, 1914: 1-6. (n.v.).

Wirtgen, Philipp Wilhelm (1806-1870), German (Prussian/Rheinland) teacher and

PAGE: 387
HEADING: WIRTGEN

botanist; trained as a primary school teacher at Neuwied's teachers college; teacher at
Remagen 1824, idem at Winningen 1824-1831; idem at Koblenz 1831-1835 ("evangel-
ische Elementarschule"), 1835-1870 at the "evangelische höhere Stadtschule"; student
of the flora of Rheinland; Dr. phil. h.c. Bonn 1853. (<em>Wirtg</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: General herbarium at E; Rheinland herb. and critical plants at
MSTR. – Further material in A, AWH, B (extant), BM, BR, C, DBN, E, FR, GE, JE,
LAU, LG, LZ (destr.), OXF, REG, W.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Herbarium Ruborum rhenanorum</em>, 200 nos. 1854-1856, ed. 2. 1859, ed. 3. 1870.
- Sets at GOET, LG, NCY, P, W.
(2) <em>Herbarium Mentharum rhenanarum</em>, 1-68, 1854-1856; Erläuterungen 16 p., 1855. Ed. 2.
1861, nos. 1-75. Ed. 3. 1862-1864, nos. 1-105. – Sets of various eds. at E, GOET, GFW,
K, LG, NCY, P.
(3) <em>Herbarium plantarum selectarum, criticarum, hybridarumque florae rhenanae</em>, ca. 1200 nos.
1842-X. – Sets at BM, FH, GFW, HAL, HEID, M. A new edition was issued by H.
Andres 1928-1933.
(4) <em>Ökonomisch-technische Pflanzen</em>, 400 nos.
(5) <em>Forst und Holzgewächse</em>, 200 nos.
(6) <em>Schulherbarium</em>, 400 nos.
(7) <em>Giftpflanzen</em>, 31 nos.
(8) <em>Herbarium der seltern oder weniger bekannten Pflanzen Deutschlands der Flora des Mittel- und
Niederheins</em> (1847), with Michael Bach (1808-1878).
(9) <em>Herbarium der deutschen Arzneipflanzen</em> und ihren wichtigsten Verwechslungen, 330 nos.
(10) <em>Herbarium der rhein. Verbasken</em> und ihrer Hybriden, nos. 1-12, ann. Flora 14 Nov
1853, nos. 1-18 by 1856. – Sets at P, W. – <em>Letters</em> at G, HAL, U, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 43: 525-527; AG 1: 290, 12(3): 326; Backer p. 628;
Barnhart 3: 508 (b. 4 Dec 1806, d. 7 Sep 1870); BFM 304, 305, 979; Biol.-Dokum. 19:
10104; BM 5: 2340; Bossert p. 440; Clokie p. 260; Frank 3 (Anh.): 114-115; Futak-
Domin p. 660; Hegi 6(1): 18, 6(2): 1272; Herder p. 6, 190; Jackson p. 295, 309; LS
29164-29165; PR 10344-10352, ed. 1: 11317; Quenstedt p. 464; Rehder 5: 927; Stev-
enson p. 1263; TL-2/see H. Andres, M. Bach, J.F. Sehlmeyer; Tucker 1: 750; Urban-
Berl. p. 411.

Wirth, Carl (1883-?), Swiss botanist; studied at the teacher's seminary.at Küsnacht
1899-1903; teacher at Zürich 1905; studied botany at the University of Zürich with
Hans Schinz; Dr. phil. ib. 1914. (<em>Wirth</em>).

<em>Ref</em>.: Irmscher, E., Bot. Centralbl. 128: 476-478. 1915 (rev.).

Wirz, Johannes (1850-1915), Swiss botanist and high school teacher; studied at Basel
and Lausanne; teacher in Donnersberg, Pfalz, Schiers and, from 1881-1912, at
Schwanden. (<em>Wirz</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Wirzén, Johan Ernst Adhemar (1812-1857), Finnish botanist, traveller and physic-
cian; mag. filos. 1832; travelled in Russia and Finland 1832-1835; med. kand. 1836, dr.
med. 1840; from 1839 medical adjunct and botanical demonstrator at the University
Helsinki; travelled in Sweden, Denmark and Germany 1846-1847. (<em>Wirzén</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: H.

11320-11322; Rehder 5: 927; Saelan 510; TR 1606-1609; Tucker 1: 750.

Wislizenus, Friedrich [later: Frederick] Adolph (1810-1889), German-born
(Schwarzburg-Rudolstadt/Thuringian) American traveller, physician and author;
studied natural sciences at Jena, Göttingen, Zürich and Paris; to the United States in
1835; settling as country physician at Mascoutah, Illinois; travelled in the Middle West
1839; settling as physician in partnership with Georg Engelmann in St. Louis 1839;
travelled to Northern Mexico and the Gulf region 1846-1847; from 1850-1852 in Europe
and California, again in St. Louis from 1852. (<em>Wisl</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MO. – Other material in BG, GH, K, WB (destr.). – <em>Letters</em> to J.
Torrey at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 4: 33; Barnhart 3: 509 (b. Mai 1810, d. 22 Sep
1889); BM 5: 2342; DAB 20: 430-431; Ewan ed. 1: 5, 8, 28, 299, 338-339, 2: 241-242;
Herder p. 63; Hortus 3: 1207; Langman p. 808; Lenley p. 472; ME 1: 242, 3: 41-42, 680
[index]; Merrill p. 256-257, 398, 715; PR 10356; Render 1: 331; SO 2868; Tucker 1: 14,
750, 3: 339.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 259: 737. 1965; Who was who Amer.,
	Hist. vol. 592. 1963.
Benson, L., Cact. Succ. J., U.S. 46: 74. 1974, 47: 40-43. 1975 (notes on date of publ.
	Memoir N. Mexico).

	1983.

	Burrage, Arner. med. biogr. 1248. 1920.

	p., map.

Wislouch, Stanislav [Michailovic] (1875-1927), Russian botanist (hydrobiolo-
gist); studied at the forestry institute of St. Petersburg; assistant at the seed testing
station at the Botanical Garden of St. Petersburg 1906-1908; assistant at the chair of
botany at the Institute of gynaecology 1908-1919; professor of systematics of cryptogams
at the St. Petersburg Agricultural Institute 1918; from 1922 in exile in Poland; professor
of botany at the pharmaceutical faculty, Warsaw 1922-1927. (<em>Wislouch</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 509 (b. 24 Jan 1875, d. 10 Jul 1927); Bossert
p. 440; MW p. 533.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Allg. bot. Z. 33: 64 (288). 1928 (d.).
Hryniewiecki, B., Acta Soc. bot. Polon. 8(3-4): 253-260. 1931 (obit., portr., bibl. 33
	nos).
Issatschenko, B.L., Bull. Inst. Hydrol. 21: 7-10. 1928 (fide Bot. Centralbl. ser. 2. 14: 192.
	1928); Bull. Jard. bot. U.S.S.R. 26: 653-654. 1927.
Nadson, G., Arch. russ. Protist. 7: 139-141. 1928.
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmid. Univ. 553. 1984.
Sieminska, J., Wiad. bot. 19: 2115-218. 1975 (biogr., list 39 publ.).

Wisniewski, Tadeusz (1905-1943), Polish bryologist, phytogeographer and traveller
(born in Taganrog, to which city his father had been deported); from 1919 living in
Warsaw; from 1928-1943 assistant at the Josef Pilsudski University, Warsaw; Dr. phil.
ib. 1930; also working for the Polish botanical Society; excecuted as a hostage in
Warsaw 30 Nov 1943. (<em>Wisn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WA; other material in BM, C, JE, K, KRAM, LWD (herb.
Lobarzewski, see Wisniewski 1924), W. – <em>Letters</em> to F. Verdoorn with FAS; other letters
at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Futak-Domin p. 660; Hirsch p. 326; Quenstedt p. 464;
SBC p. 135.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Rev. bryol. lichénol. 16: 131. 1947 (obit. not.).
Hryniewiecki, B., Acta Soc. bot. Polon. 19(2): 275-282. 1948 (obit., portr., bibl.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 3: 2, 223. 1937, 4: 63. 1938, 6: 310. 1941.
Vitt, D.H. et al., Compendium of bryology 223. 1985.

HEADING: WIS´NIEWSKI

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) For Norbert Wisniewski (1927-1976), German-Polish herpetologist and bota-
nist (orchidologist), see Gleditschia 6: 5-8. 1978; Jahresber. nat. Ver. Wuppertal 29:
161-162. 1977; Niederlaus. flor. Mitt. 8: 60-61. 1977; Mitt. Arbeitskr. heim. Orch. 7: 7-
9. 1977; Naturschutzarbeit Berlin Brandenburg 12(3): 96. 1976.
(2) For Piotr [Peter] Wisniewski (1881-1971), Polish botanist; director of the Botanical
Garden and the Botanical Institute Stefan Batory at Wilna (1919-1939), professor of
general botany at Lublin 1944-1960, see Wiad. Bot. 14(1): 65-67. 1970, 17(2): 75-77.
1973.
(3) For the paleontologist and geologist Tadeusz Wisniowski (1875-1933), see Bull.
Service géol. Pologne 8: 16-28. 1937.

18.053. <em>Musci frondosi halicienses</em> quos collegit Hyacinthus J.C. Strzemie Lobarzewski ...
We Lwowie [Lwow, Lemberg] (Nakladem Muzeum Im. Dzieduszyckich ...) 1924. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1924, p. [1]-23. <em>Copy</em>: H. – Reprinted from Acta Musaei Dzieduszyckiani 5(9): 67-
	85. 1923 [1924].
<em>Note</em>: Jan Kanty Lobarzewski (1816 [not 1815]-1862 (also Hyacinth Strzemie von -
	Lobarzewski), the first Polish bryologist, was professor of botany at Lemberg ['Lwow]
	1839-1862; for details see this publication by Wisniewski (e.g. French summary on p.
	7-8) and TL-2/3: 129. The Lobarzewski collections are [were?] at LWD; another set
	was at B until 1943 of which the material of several genera is still extant. –
	"Halicienses": from Galicia. – Lwow [Polish], (Lemberg [German], Lvov [Russian]),
	was part of the Austrian empire at the time of Lobarzewski; Polish at the time of
	Wisniewski and under U.S.S.R. sovereignty [Ukraine] from 1945.

Wit, Hendrik Cornelis Dirk de (1909-x), Dutch botanist; studied at the University of
Amsterdam 1931-1937 and at Pretoria, M.Sc. 1938, Dr. phil. 1941; agricultural research
officer, Dept. Agriculture, Pretoria 1938-1940; botanist at the Botanical Garden
Buitenzorg (Bogor) 1941-1946; botanist with the Flora malesiana foundation 1946-1953;
also high school teacher at Bussum and Amsterdam 1951-1953; lecturer at the Univers-
ity of Leiden 1953-1959; lecturer at the Agricultural University Wageningen 1953-1959,
ordinary professor of plant taxonomy and plant geography of the tropics and subtropics
ib. 1959; also director of the laboratory of plant taxonomy and plant geography from
1969-1980. (<em>de Wit</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: WAG, also L. – Further material and types in BO. – <em>Letters</em> in G,
IAPT-files.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BFM 1288; Bossert p. 440; Hortus 3: 1191; IH 1 (ed. 2):
70, 125, (ed. 3): 88, 161, (ed. 4): 96, 179, (ed. 5): 99, 195, (ed. 6): 289, (ed. 7): 304; MW
suppl. p. 395; NI suppl. 20, 22, 44, 59, 67; Roon p. 124; SK 1: 582 (coll., itin.), 8: cix;
Zander ed. 10, p. 651-652, 733, ed. 11, p. 741.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Rijnstreek, Wageningen 24 Oct 1979 (interview; anecdotes. <em>Copy</em>: FAS).
Arditi, J., ed., Orchid biology 1: 296 [index]. 1977 (on p. 47-94 commentary on
	Rumphius' orchids).

	1980 (curr. vit., portr.).

	1980, 100 p., Veenman, Wageningen ("non sine pugna", informal sketches on
	H.C.D. de Wit).

	on WAG).

Witasek, Johanna (1865-1910), Austrian botanist and teacher in Vienna; teacher at a
girl's high school from 1891; working also with R. von Wettstein at the Botanical
Institute of the University from 1899-1910. (<em>Witas</em>.).

Witham, Henry Thomas Maire (né Silvertop) (1779-1844), British geologist and
palaeobotanist; married Eliza Witham of Headlam 1800; sheriff of County Durham;
from 1801-1826 living at Larbington, subsequently living in Edinburgh; founder, 1829,
of the Natural History Society of Northumberland. (<em>Witham</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 350; Barnhart 3: 509; BB p. 331-332; BM 5:
2343; GSP 6: 404; Desmond p. 670 (b. 28 Mai 1779, d. 28 Nov 1844); DSB 14: 462-463
(A.G. Long) (further sec. lit.); Jackson p. 176, 181; PR 10357-10359, ed. 1: 11324-
11326.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Andrews, H.N., Fossil hunters 76-79. 1980.
Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 259: 784. 1965.
Rackham, R.A., Newsletter Soc. Hist. nat. Hist. 19: 9-10. 1983.
Scott, D.H., <em>in</em> F.W. Oliver, Makers Brit. Bot. 243-260. 1913.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Withamia</em> Unger (1842); <em>Withamia</em> A.C. Seward (1895).

18.074. <em>Observations on fossil vegetables</em>, accompanied by representations of their internal
structure, as seen through the microscope ... Edinburgh (William Blackwood), London

Withering, William (1741-1799), British physician, botanist and mineralogist; studied
at the University of Edinburgh, M.D 1766; practicing physician at Stafford 1767-1775;
idem at Birmingham 1775-1799. (<em>With</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (orig. herb., from LINN; also alg., bryoph., lich.); further
material at BR, K, and BM (incl. alg., bryoph., lichens), LINN (in herb. J.E. Smith;
orig. herb. now at BM), LIV, UPS-Thunb. – <em>Manuscripts</em> see Bridson (1980); <em>letters</em> and
R. Brown's notes on his herbarium (crypt.) at BM; to J.E. Smith at LINN, at Royal
Society of Medicine, London.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 78, 186, 300; Backer p. 664; Barnhart 3:
510 (b. 28 Mar 1741, d. 6 Oct 1799); BB p. 332; BL 2: 472; BM 5: 2343; Bossert p. 440;
Dawson p. 878; Desmond p. 670-671; DNB 62: 268 (21: 739-741); Dryander 3: 14, 131,
510-511; DSB 14: 463-465 (W.F. Bynum); Frank 3 (Anh.): 115; GR p. 386, cat. p. 73;
Henrey 2: 748 [index], 3: nos. 1505-1519; Herder p. 171; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p.
234, 237; LS 29169-29170; Plesch p. 461-462; PR 10360, ed. 1: 11329-11331; Rehder 5:
928; SBC p. 135; SO 675b-d; Sotheby 819-820; Stevenson p. 1263; TL-1/1437-1440;
TL-2/5173, 12.324, see J. Hull, E. Robson, J. Shepherd, J.E. Smith, C.P. Thunberg;
Tucker 1: 14, 751, 2: xl, 3: 339; Zander ed. 10, p. 733, ed. 11, p. 837.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Witheringa</em> L'Héritier de Brutelle (1789); <em>Witheringia</em> Miers (1849).

18.077. <em>A botanical arrangement of all the vegetables</em> naturally growing <em>in Great Britain</em>. With
descriptions of the genera and species, according to the system of the celebrated Lin-
naeus. Being an attempt to render them familiar to those who are acqainted with the
learned languages. Under each species are added, the most remarkable varieties, the
natural places of growth, the duration, the time of flowering, the peculiarities of
structure, the common English names; the names of Gerard, Parkinson, Ray and
Bauhine [sic]. The uses as medicines, or as poisons; as food for men, for brutes [i.e.
animals], and for insects. With their applications in oeconomy and in the arts. With an
easy introduction to the study of botany. Shewing the method of investigating plants,
and directions show to dry and preserve specimens. The whole illustrated by copper
plates and a glossary ... Birmingham (printed by M. Swinney), London (for T. Cadel
and P. Elmsley ...) 1776. Oct. (<em>Bot. arr. veg. Gr. Brit.</em>).

<em>1</em>: 1776, p. [i*], <em>pl. 1</em>, [i]-xviii, xvii-xcvi, [1]-383, <em>pl. 2</em>.
<em>2</em>: 1776 (Lond. Rev. 4: 474-475. Dec 1776, rev.), p. [i-iv], 385-784, 783-838, <em>pl. 3-12</em>
	(uncol. copp.). Some copies have preface matter p. [i, t.p.] only.

Witte, [Bror Otto] Hernfrid (1877-1945), Swedish agricultural botanist; Dr. phil.
Uppsala 1906; with the Svalöv seed experiment station 1907-1921, with the Swedish
"mosskulturföreningen" in Jönköping 1921-1925; with the Swedish State Seed Testing
Station, Stocksund 1925-1944. (<em>Her. Witte</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GB; further material in C.

770, no. 23).
(2) <em>Viktigare svenska vallväxter</em>, Svalöv 1909, nos. 1-35, set at GB; ed. 2, 1910.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 510; BL 2: 733 [index]; BM 5: 2344; Bossert
p. 440; GR p. 504; Hirsch p. 327; KR p. 769-770 (b. 13 Jul 1877); LS 40658-40659;
Nordstedt suppl. p. 17; TL-2/9750; Tucker 1: 751.

Witte, Eduard Theodoor (1865-1936), Dutch gardener, curator at the Leiden Botan-
ical Garden 1898-1930; editor of the Maandschrift der Nederlandsche Maatschappij
voor Tuinbouw en Plantkunde; son of Heinrich Witte. (<em>E. Witte</em>).

	172, 175, 177. 1938.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 53. 1936.
Vuyck, L., Afscheid en welkom, Leiden 1898, 20 p. (reprinted from Sempervirens
	27(14): 145-151. 1898).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Witte published several popular books on house and garden plants, usually based
on German originals, such as <em>Handleiding tot het kweeken van planten in huis</em>, Zwolle 1896, x,
283 p. (based on L.H. Riese, <em>Wohnungsgärtnerei</em>); <em>Kamerplanten</em>, Leiden [1896-] 1897 [in 6
Lieferungen], viii, 510 p. (based on Hesdörffer, <em>Handbuch der praktischen Zimmergärtnerei</em>),
id. ed. 2, 1909, ix, 420 p., and <em>Een keur van vaste planten</em>, Leiden 1900, 114 p., <em>48 pl</em>. (based
on Hesdörffer, <em>Die schönsten Stauden</em>, Berlin 1900).

Witte, Heinrich (1825-1917), Dutch gardener; student gardener in the Hortus botan-
icus Rotterdam; subsequently assistant curator at the Leiden botanical garden; head-
curator ib. 1855-1898. (<em>Witte</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 510; BM 5: 2344; Herder p. 149, 152;
Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 48, 51, 52, 55, 86, 147, 324; JW 1: 451, 2: 204, 3: 376;
Morren ed. 2, p. 28, ed. 10, p. 91; MW p. 533; NI 2174-2175; Plesch p. 462; PR 10365-
10367; Rehder 5: 928; Sotheby 821; TL-2/11.960; Tucker 1: 751.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Gard. Chron. ser. 3. 18: 429. 1895 (jubilee), ser. 3. 61: 67. 1917 (obit.
	not.); Gartenflora 44: 552, 574-575. 1895 (40 years "hortulanus").

Witte, E.Th., Jaarb. Gesch. Oudheidk. Leiden Rijnland 15: xli-liv. 1918 (obit., b. 10
	Mai 1829, d. 9 Jan 1917).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) Editor of the Dutch horticultural journals <em>Sempervirens</em> (1872-1875,
1884-1897), <em>Nederlandsch Tuinbouwblad Sempervirens</em> (1897-1905), <em>Sieboldia</em> (1875-1884).
(2) Collaborator, C.A.J.A. Oudemans, <em>Neerl. pl.-tuin</em> 1865-1867, TL-2/7148.
(3) Translated C.J. Petzold, <em>Die Rose</em>, ihre Geschichte, 1874 into Dutch: <em>De Roos</em>, hare
geschiedenis, ... Leiden, E.J. Brill, 1877, 86 p.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Witte was a successful and prolific popularizer of botany and horticulture; a list of
47 titles of books and brochures is given in <em>Onze Tuinen</em> 20 Jan 1917; he also published
several novels and travelogues and published widely in daily journals and periodicals.

Wittmack, [Marx Carl] Ludwig (1839-1929), German (Hamburg) botanist; studied
natural sciences at Jena 1864-1865, and Berlin 1865-1867; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1867; in
charge of the setting up of a new Agricultural Museum in Berlin 1867-1871, curator of
this museum 1871; assistant teacher at the Berlin Agricultural Institute 1874; extra-
ordinary professor at Berlin University 1880-1913; ordinary professor at the new Agric-
ultural University 1881-1913; scientific director of the botany dept. of the Agricultural
Museum 1881; rector of the Agricultural University 1889-1891; Geh. Regierungsrat
1891. (<em>Wittm</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (mainly destr.). – <em>Letters</em> at FH, G, UPS-UB. – Seed collection
offered from estate in Herbarium 83: 359. 1930.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(1): 688 (err. birth date); Barnhart 3: 511 (b. 26
Sep 1839, d. 2 Feb 1929); Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10118-11119; BJI 1: 65, 2: 193; BL 2: 346,
733; BM 5: 2344-2345; Bossert p. 460; CSP 8: 1257, 11: 834, 12: 789, 19: 678-679; Frank
3 (Anh.): 115; Herder p. 485 [index]; Hirsch p. 327; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 196;
Langman p. 809; LS 29175-29189, 40660-40661, 41846, suppl. 30213-31214; Moebius p.
384; Morren ed. 2, p. 1, ed. 10, p. 5, 68; MW p. 533-534; PR 10369; Rehder 5: 928-929;
SO 2871; TL-2/6761, see A. Maurizio, O.E. Ulbrich; Tucker 1: 751, 3: 39; Zander ed.
10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 837.

Wittrock, Veit Brecher (1839-1914), Swedish botanist; studied at the University of
Uppsala 1857-1865; Dr. phil. and lecturer ib. 1886; high school teacher at a private
school in Uppsala 1865-1878, extraordinary professor of botany Uppsala 1878; professor
and curator of the botanical collections at the Stockholm Riksmuseum 1879-1904, also

PAGE: 407
HEADING: WITTROCK

"Professor Bergianus" and director of the Bergianska trädgårdsskolan 1879-1914; also
botany teacher at Stockholms högskola 1879-1883. (<em>Wittr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: S. – Other material in C, GB, H, K, S, UPS (types algae). –
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Erythraeae exsiccatae</em>, fasc. 1-4, nos. 1-64. Stockholm 1884-1890 (25 sets
publ., see KR p. 776, no. 66). Sets at BM, GB, H, K, LD, MANCH, MPU, WRSL. –
See also Bot. Not. 1884: 110-118 (presentation fasc. 1, nos. 1-12, 27 Mar 1884, 1886: 65-
71 (nos. 13-32), 1899: 272-281. 15 Dec 1899).
(2) With Carl Fredrik Otto Nordstedt (1838-1924) and (fasc. 26-34) Nils Gustaf Lager-
heim (1860-1926): <em>Algae aquae dulcis exsiccatae</em> praecipue scandinavicae, quas adjectis
algis marinis chlorophyllaceis et phycochromaceis distribuerunt, fasc. 1-20, 22-34 (nos.
1-1612) and fasc. 21, 35 (text only) 1877-1903. For details see KR p. 776, no. 64 and
below (treatment of text). Sets at B, BM, BP, C, CGE, FH, GOET, H, K, L, LD, LG,
M, MANCH, NY, PC, UPS, US, W, WRSL. – <em>Letters</em> G, GH, NY, UPS-UB. <em>Autobio-
graphical manuscript</em> in Archives K. Sv. Vet.-Akad., Stockholm.

64, 2: 193; BM 5: 2345, 8: 1447; Bossert p. 440; De Toni 1: cxxxii-cxxxiii, cxxxix, 2:
cxxiii, 4: lx; DTS 1: 330; Frank 3 (Anh.): 115; GR p. 504, <em>pl</em>. [<em>40</em>]; Hegi 5(1): 616;
Herder p. 485 [index]; Hortus 3: 1207; IH 1 (ed. 1): 91; Jackson p. 157, 158, 192, 331,
332, 337; Kleppa see index; Langman p. 809; Lenley p. 440; LS 29190-29192; Morren

	Stockholm); Nat. Nov. 1: 57. 1879 (app. Stockholm), 28: 653. 1906 (Bayr. Akad.

Wittstein, Georg Christian (1810-1887), German (Hannover) pharmacist; studied
pharmacy in various Hannoverian pharmacies; student, later assistant at the Phar-
maceutical Institute, Univ. München 1835-1850; Dr. phil. München 1840; teacher at a
technical school in Ansbach 1851-1853; in charge of a private school for chemistry in
München 1853-1879. (<em>Wittst</em>.).

<em>Note</em> (<em>1</em>): The preface matter [i-viii], was set up in new type; the erratum for p. vii is no
	longer necessary because the error had been corrected. The main text was reproduced
	from the main text because all mistakes and broken letters in 1852 occur also in 1856.
<em>Note</em>(<em>2</em>): Wittstein's etymology is often erroneous and the book should be used with the
	greatest care, see Hugo von Mohl's reviews and comments in Bot. Zeit. (1852-1854)
	and D.F.L. von Schlechtendal's note on "ed. 2" ib. 12: 268-269. 1856.

Wodehouse, Roger Philip (1889-1978), Canadian botanist, palynologist and allergist;
A.B. Univ. Toronto 1913, A.M. Harvard 1916; Dr. phil. Columbia 1927; came to the
U.S.A. 1930; naturalized U.S. citizen 1942; protein chemist with J.L. Goodale in Boston
1915-1916; botanist on hayfever and asthma P.B. Brigham Hosp., Boston 1916-1917;
director Hayfever Lab., Arlington Chem. Co. Yonkers, N.Y. 1911-1944; id. Lederle
Laboratories, Pearl River 1944-1957; on active service in Royal Air Force in World War
I. (<em>Wodehouse</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at Hunt Institute, Smithsonian Institution
and in Verdoorn archives (with FAS).

Bossert p. 440; Langman p. 809-810; MW p. 534; SIA see indexes; TL-2/12.170, see
C.J.F. Skottsberg; Tucker 3: 339.

Woerlein, Georg (1848-1899), German (Bavarian) soldier and botanist; studied at the
Nürnberg Polytechnic; in the Bavarian Army 1866-1876; from 1876 in München
(Nymphenburg), sometime Bavarian paymaster ("königlicher Zahlmeister"). (<em>Woerl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: M. – Other material in B (extant in herb. Ullepitsch). – <em>Letters</em> at
G, UPS-UB.

661; Morren ed. 10, p. 20; Rehder 5: 930; Tucker 1: 752.

	12, portr. 1900 (obit., portr.).
Hertel, H., Mitt. Bot. München 16: 455. 1980 (lich. at M, d. 1900).

Wohlfarth, Rudolf (1830-1900), German (Sachsen-Anhalt) botanist; originally insur-
ance agent, later rector of a school in Neu-Weissensee nr. Berlin. (<em>Wohlf</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

schweiz. Fl.</em> ed. 3, vols. 1-2, 1890-1902. – Lief. 12-13, 1901-1902 possibly finished off by
August Brand. Wohlfarth's name appears also on the covers of Lief. 3-18; however,
according to Ascherson (1894) W. also took care of Lief. 1-2; Lief. 14-18 (vol. 3) were
definitely edited by Brand.

Wohltmann, Ferdinand [Friedrich Wilhelm] (1857-1919), German (Hannover)
botanist and colonial traveller; studied agriculture, natural sciences, law and economy;
Dr. phil. Halle 1886; travelled in Europe and W. Africa 1886-1888; for the "Hamburger
Kolonialisationsverein" to Dona Franziska in Santa Catharina, Brazil ca. 1890-1891;
habil. Halle 1891; e.o. professor at Breslau University 1892-1894; travelled in N.
America 1894; professor at Bonn-Poppelsdorf 1894-1905; travelled in Cameroon 1896,
German East Africa 1897-1898, Togo and Cameroon 1899-1901, Samoa 1903; from
1905-1917 at the Agricultural Institute, Halle, from 1909 as director. (<em>Wohltmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 512 (b. 20 Oct 1857, d. 10 Apr 1919); BM 5:
2347; CSP 19: 683-684; LS 29203, 40668; Moebius p. 392; Rehder 5: 930; TL-2/see J.G.
Kühn.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 81: 192. 1900 (Geh. Regierungsrath), 111: 640. 1909
	(dir. Halle); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 260: 58. 1965; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl.
	natl. 226: 60-62. 1977; Deut. biogr. Jahrb. Überleitungsband 2: 1917-1920, p. 737.
	1928 (documentation); Deut. Zeitgenossenlexikon 1590. 1905; Hedwigia 49: (134).
	1910 (dir. Halle succeeding Julius Kühn), 61: (114). 1919 (d. 10 Apr 1919).
Degener, H.A.L., Wer ist's eds. 6-8. 1912-1922.
Fruwirth, C, ed., Z. Pflanzenzüchtung 7(1): 77-78. 1919 (obit. not., portr. in group).
Schmid, B. &amp; C. Thesing, Biol.-Kalend. 1: 349. 1914 (bibl.).
Wohltmann, F., Landwirthschaftliche Reisestudien über Chicago und Nord-Amerika.
	Breslau 1894, 440 p.; Pflanzung und Siedlung auf Samoa, Beihefte Tropenpflanzer 5:
	i-v, 1-164, <em>pl. 1-20.</em> 1904 (data on economic plants).

Wojinowic, Welislaw P. (1864-1892), Serbian botanist; studied mathematics and
natural sciences at Belgrado 1882-1887; student of J. Pancic; at the University of Breslau
with J. Cohn 1887-1890; Dr. phil. ib. 1890; from 1890-1892 active in floristics and
mycology in Serbia; died of tuberculosis. (<em>Wojinowic</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 1: 64; BM 5: 2347.

Cohn, F., Bot. Centralbl. 50: 64. 1892 (obit. not.).

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wojnowicia</em> P.A. Saccardo (1899).

philosophischen Fakultät der Universität Breslau behufs Erlangung der Doktorwürde
Dienstag den 12. August 1890 Mittags 12 Uhr in der Aula Leopoldina ... öffentlich
verteidigen wird Welislaw P. Wojinowic aus Serbien [Breslau 1890]. Oct. (<em>Beitr.

Wolf, Carl Brandt (1905-1974), American botanist; studied at Occidental College
1921-1926 (and worked one year with the Theodore Payne Nursery, Los Angeles); A.B.
1926; M.Sc. Stanford 1927, Dr. phil. ib. 1930; teaching assistant Stanford 1927-1930;

HEADING: C. WOLF

Land and Water Company, Fillmore, Calif. 1945-1967. (<em>C. Wolf</em>).

Wolf, Ferdinand Otto (1838-1906), German (Thüringian)-born Swiss botanist and
musician; educated as choir and solo church singer in Ellwangen; teacher at Feldkirch
1856-1858; to Wallis (Switzerland) 1858; teacher of music and natural history at Brig
1858-1861; organist and music teacher at Sion from 1861; student of the flora of the
Wallis Alps; one of the founders and later president of the Société Murithienne. (<em>F.O.
Wolf</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Z. – Further material in A, B (extant, herb. Ullepitsch), BAS,
BIRM, C, E, GB, GOET, IBF, KIEL, LAU, MANCH, NA, W. – <em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-
UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 452-453, 12(3): 21; Barnhart 3: 512 (b. 11 Oct
1838, d. 27 Jun 1905); BL 2: 586, 733; BM 5: 2448; Rehder 5: 930; Saccardo 2: 114;
Urban-Berl. p. 411.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Jahrb. 38, Beibl. 87: 42. 1906 (d.); Hist.-biogr. Lex. Schweiz 7: 584.
	1934.
Besse, Ch.M., Verh. schweiz. naturf Ges. 104(2): 13-32. 1923.

Wolf, Frederick Adolph (1885-1975), American mycologist and plant pathologist;
studied at the University of Nebraska 1903-1908, M.Sc. 1908; at the University of Texas
1909-1910; Dr. phil. Cornell Univ. with G.F. Atkinson; plant pathologist Alabama
Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn 1911-1915; plant pathologist at the Agricul-
tural Experiment Station at North Carolina State College, Raleigh 1915-1925; plant
pathologist USDA at Orlando, Florida 1925-1927; professor of botany Duke University,
Durham, North Carolina 1927-1954; emeritus professor from 1954. (<em>F.A. Wolf</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Material at BPI, CUP, DPU, TEX. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, NY.

HEADING: WOLF

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 512; BM 5: 2348; Bossert p. 441; Kelly p.
243; Lenley p. 440; LS 40669-40672, suppl. 1447, 30235-30289; Moebius p. 372; Stevenson p. 1263; Tucker 1: 752, 3: 340.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 3-11. 1921-1967; Index Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4:
	565-567. 1969 (bibl.); Who's who Amer. 17-29. 1932-1956; Who was who Amer. 7:
	623. 1977-1981 (b. 25 Jun 1885, d. 7 Nov 1975).

	1976 (id.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Main works outside our period, with his son Frederick Taylor Wolf [b. 1915], <em>The
fungi</em>, 2 vols. 1947 (other printing 1949); facsimile reprint Hafner Publishing Company.,
New York and London 1969. - See also his <em>Tobacco diseases and decays</em>, Durham, N.C.
1936.

Graduate School of Cornell University for the degree of doctor of philosophy by Frede-
rick Adolph Wolf, June, 1911. Oct.

Wolf, Nathaniel Matthaeus von (1724-1784), German (West-Prussian, Danzig)
physician, astronomer and botanist; studied at the Universities of Leipzig, Halle and
Erfurt; practicing physician at Warsaw, Posen and Konitz; ca. 1769-1772 in Dirschau
and, from 1772, in Danzig. (<em>Wolf</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: von Wolf presented his herbarium and library in 1780 to the
Naturforschende Gesellschaft, Danzig. Present location unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 513; BM 5: 2349; Bossert p. 441; Dryander
3: 33, 42; Herder p. 143; Hortus 3: 1207; PR 10380, ed. 1: 11341; Rehder 1: 77, 258;
TL-1/1441-1443; TL-2/456; Zander ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 837.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 260: 136. 1965.
Bridson, G.D.R. et al., Nat. hist. mss. res. Brit. Isl. 278.47. 1980.

Mansfeld, R., Repert. sp. nov. 48: 267. 1940.

Poggendorff, J.C., Biogr.-lit. Handw.-Buch 2: 1356-1357. 1863.
Ross, R., Acta bot. neerl. 15: 147-161. 1966 (extensive historical and nomenclatural
	study).

HEADING: WOLF

Stafleu, F.A., <em>in</em> G.H.M. Lawrence, ed., Adanson 1: 307. 1963.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 147. 1903.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wolfia</em> Schreber (1791, <em>nom. rej.</em>) and <em>Wolfia</em> K.P.J. Sprengel (1824) both prob-
ably honor this author but no etymology was given.

18.167. <em>Genera plantarum</em> vocabulis characteristicis definita ... [Danzig] 1776. Oct. (<em>Gen.
pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1776-1780 (t.p. date is 1776, but p. [149] of the Concordantia is dated 1780. The
	<em>Genera</em> itself can be regarded to have been published in 1776, the Concordantia in
	1780), p. [1]-8, chart, [1]-177, [178, err.]. <em>Concordantia botanica</em>: [1-149]. <em>Copies</em>: G,
	MO, USDA; IDC 5821.
<em>Note</em>: The monomial nomenclature in code form introduced in these books (i.e. incl. the
	<em>Gen. sp. pl.</em> below) runs parallel to the Linnaean nomenclature and is alternative to it,
	not replacing it. The ordinary Latin names of genera in this publication have normal
	standing in nomenclature. [e.g. Vincetoxicum on p. 130]. Fuchs' statement that the
	Latin names are merely synonyms of the technical monomials is not supported here.
	Wolf's parallel nomenclature was intended to obtain a code-designation based on
	characters (see the title of the book). See Ross 1966 for an extensive commentary.

18.168. <em>Genera et species plantarum</em> vocabulis characteribus definita. In Marienwerder
(Typis Joan. Jac. Kanteri ...) 1781. Oct. (<em>Gen. sp. pl.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1781, p. [1]-454, chart, [455-462, err.]. <em>Copy</em>: PH; IDC 5821. - See above, <em>Gen. pl.</em>
	(1776) for a note on the nomenclature used in this work.

Wolf, [Franz] Theodor (1841-1921), German (Württemberg) geologist and botanist;
professor of geology and mineralogy Univ. Quito 1870, state geologist of Ecuador 1875;
from 1891 private scientist at Dresden-Plauen. (<em>Th. Wolf</em>).

Wolff, [Karl Friedrich August] Hermann (1866-1929), German (Braunschweig,
Brunswick) veterinarian and botanist; studied veterinary medicine in Berlin 1885-1890;
municipal veterinarian in Berlin from 1894; Dr. phil. Berlin 1925; travelled widely in
S.E. Europe and the Near East; student of the Umbelliferae. (<em>H. Wolff</em>).

Wolff, [Jacobus Otto] Reinhold (1845-?), German (Silesian), agriculturist and myco-
logist; Dr. phil. Halle 1874; habil. Halle 1875; attended agricultural schools in Würlitz
nr Kreuzburg (Schles.) and Proskau (Schles.); studied at Halle with e.g. Knoblauch, de
Bary, Solms-Laubach; ultimately teacher at the Polytechnical School of Riga, Latvia.
(<em>R. Wolff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Wolle, Francis (1817-1893), American botanist (algologist) and educator; did educat-
ional work in the Moravian church, teacher at Nazareth Hall and Bethlehem Pa.; vice-
principal Young Ladies Seminary, Bethlehem, Pa., 1857, principal 1861-1881; in retire-
ment continuing his algological work. (<em>Wolle</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PH (see also Sayre 1975 and Drouet 1939, p. 18). - Further
material at BUF, CAS, DPU, F, FH, GH, NY, OXF. - <em>Letters</em> at FH, G, GH, NY. -
<em>Manuscripts, correspondence and drawings</em>: PH.

p. 777; Lenley p. 440; Morren ed. 10, p. 129; NAF ser. 2. 6: 81; NI 2178-2180; Nord-
stedt p. 18; PH see Guide; TL-2/13.171.

Wollenweber, Hans Wilhelm (1879-1949), German (Westphalen) mycologist and
parasitologist; trained as a gardener at the horticultural school Wildpark, Potsdam;
garden-technician in Hannover 1902-1903; studied at the Universities of Göttingen and
Berlin 1906-1909; Dr. phil. Berlin 1909; collaborator in the phytopathological labora-
tory of the Biologische Reichsanstalt, Berlin-Dahlem 1909, from 1919 in charge of the
mycological laboratory ib. (<em>Wollenweb</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BSB; further material in B (p.p. extant).
<em>Fusaria culta et Fusaria culta excludenda</em>, cent. 1, nos. 1-100, date unknown. Sets at B, BPI,
LD, W. - For full details see J. Stevenson, Beih. Nova Hedw. 36: 514-515. 1971.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 514; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10169-10171; BJI 2:
194; BL 2: 476, 733; BM 8: 1450; Bossert p. 441; GR p. 55, cat. p. 73; Hawksworth p.
186 (herb. BSB); Hirsch p. 328; Kelly p. 243; LS 30611, suppl. 1086-1088, 30325-30365;
MW p. 535, Suppl. 395; Stevenson p. 1263; TL-2/12.959.

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 132. 1935, 2: 144. 1936, 3: 123. 1937.

18.184. <em>Fusaria autographice delineala</em>. Collectio specierum ex herbariis variis selectarum et
ab auctore lectarum cultarumque synonymis et excludendis additis quas determinavit,
in sectiones digessit, comparavit cum Hypocreaceis analogis praemissis ad methodi
naturalis normas et culturae purae experientiam H.W. Wollenweber ... Berolini
[Berlin] 1916 [-1935]. Card index. (<em>Fusaria autogr. delin.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1916-1935, numbered fiches (16.5 x 10.5 cm) with lithographed text and figures;
	each fiche treats a single species, includes drawings and notes, often indicates her-
	barium specimens and herbaria. Effective publication. <em>Copies</em>: BR, MICH, NY, Stev-

Wolley-Dod, Anthony Hurt (1861-1948), British soldier and botanist; Royal Military
Academy at Woolwich 1879; commissioned Royal Artillery 1881; captain 1889, retired
with rank of major 1901; It.-colonel during World War I; collected in S. Africa (1900-
1901), Gibraltar (1913-1914), California (1921). (<em>Wolley-Dod</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (ca. 10.000; rd. 1948); Rose herbarium, 2000, rd. 1938);
further material in B (mainly destr.), BOL, CGE, E, GRA, K, NH, NMW, NOT,
OXF, RTE, SAM, TLS. - <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 514; BB p. 332; BL 1: 28, 324, 2: 270, 486,
733; BM 8: 1450; Bossert p. 267, 441; Desmond p. 672 (b. 17 Nov 1861, d. 21 Jun 1948);
Hortus 3: 1207; Tucker 1: 752, 3: 340; Urban-Berl. p. 411.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 54: I. 1960 (sub Dod).
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 618. 1984.
Ingwersen, W.E.Th., Quart. Bull. Alpine Gard. Soc. 16(3): 239-240. 1938 (obit. not.).

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 4: 533, 566. 1938, 5: 124, 314. 1939.
Wilmott, A.J., Watsonia 1(5): 331-334. 1950 (obit.).

<em>Authorship</em> although listed as "editor" Wolley-Dod was entirely responsible for the text;
the nomenclature was brought up to date by A.J. Wilmott; A.B. Rendle "went through
the text" (J. Bot. 76: 60. 1938).
<em>Publ</em>.: 24-31 Dec 1937 (fide J. Bot. Feb 1938), p. [i]-lxxiii, 1-571, <em>pl. 1-6</em>, 2 maps. <em>Copies</em>:

	Wallace, E.C., Rep. Bot. Soc. Exch. Club Brit. Isl. 11: 609-614. 1938 (rev.).

Woloszcak, Eustach (1835-1918), Galician (Polish) botanist; studied law at the Univ-
ersity of Budapest; id. medicine and natural sciences at the University of Vienna; Dr.
phil. ib.; volunteer assistant with Eduard Fenzl at the Vienna Natural History Museum,
later botanical assistant at the University; assistant with A. Kerner in the Vienna Botan-
ical Institute; professor of botany at the Lemberg Polytechnic 1884 (incl. zoology from
1891) from 1900 as ordinary professor; after his retirement living in Vienna. (<em>Woloszack</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W (16.787); further material in B (extant in herb. Zool. bot. Ges.
Wien), BP, KRAM. - We have no information on material in LW.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: With A. Rehmann (TL-2/4: 655; IH 2(5): 745) <em>Flora polonica</em> cent. i-xi, ca.
1893-1904. Sets at B (mainly destr.), BM, C, E, K, KRAM, OXF, W, WRSL. - Contri-
buted to <em>Fl. Exs. Austro-Hung. - Letters</em> at G.

HEADING: WOLOSZAK

Woloszynska, Jadwiga (1882-1951), Polish botanist (algologist); studied botany at
Lemberg (Lwow) with M. Raciborski; Dr. phil. Lemberg 1912, assistant at the Biolog-
ical and botanical institute of Lemberg University 1912; high school teacher 1920-1921;
algological assistant at the Wigry lake hydrobiological station 1921-1923; assistant to W.
Szafer at the University of Cracow 1924; assistant professor for pharmaceutical botany
ib. 1930-1932; e.o. professor 1932-1946, regular professor 1950-1951. (<em>Woloszynska</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KRA (presumably).

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Wielka encykjl. powszechna pwu 12: 485. 1969.
Hryniewiecki, B., Acta Soc. Bot. Polon. 21(3): 295-310. 1952 (obit., portr., bibl.; french
	summary).

PAGE: 432
HEADING: WOLOSZYNSKA

Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmid. Univ. 229, 557-559. 1984 (bibl.).

VanLandingham, S.L., Cat. Diat. 4: 2383. 1971, 6: 3602. 1978, 7: 4239-4240. 1978.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 1: 239, 366. 1935, 2: 255. 1936, 3: 220. 1937.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Woloszynskia</em> R.H. Thompson (1951).

18.217. <em>Das Phytoplankton einiger javanischen Seen</em> mit Berücksichtigung des Sawa-Planktons

<em>Publ</em>.: 16 Sep 1912 (date printed on cover p. 4; journal issues for Jun and Jul 1912),

Wolpert, Josef [Johann Baptist] (1881-?), German (Franconian) botanist; Dr. phil.
München 1909; assistant at the botanical division of the Kön. forstliche Versuchsanstalt,
München 1911. (<em>Wolpert</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 515 (b. 26 Jun 1881); LS 40685.

	192. 1911 (app. München); Öster. bot. Z. 61: 159. 1911 (app. München).
