einem Beitrag zur Mycorrhizenfrage. Inaugural-Dissertation zur Erlangung der Doktor-
würde der Hohen philosophischen Fakultät (II. Sektion) der Kgl. Bayer. Ludwig-
Maximilians-Universität zu München ... Jena (Verlag von Gustav Fischer) 1909. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 8 Nov 1909 (in journal), p. [1]-33, <em>pl. I. Copy</em>: B. – Reprinted and to be cited from
	Flora 100(1): 37-67. <em>pl. I.</em> 1909.

Wood, Alphonso (1810-1881), American botanist and teacher; studied at Dartmouth
College 1831-1834 and at Andover theological Seminary; teacher of Latin and natural
science Kimball Union Academy, Meriden, N.H. 1835-1849; civil engineer in the con-
struction of a railway between Rutland, Vt. and Albany, N.Y. 1849-1851; president of
the Female Seminary, Cleveland, Ohio 1851-1857; professor at Terre Haute female
College, Indiana 1858-1860; principal of the Clinton female seminary, Brooklyn 1861-
1865, travelled to and along the Pacific Coast 1865-1866; in retirement at West Farms,
N.Y. from 1867. (<em>A. Wood</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NY (originally at New York College of Pharmacy, see Rusby
1936). – Other material at GH, PH, YU. – <em>Letters</em> at GH, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 515 (b. 17 Sep 1810, d. 4 Jan 1881); BM 5:
2352; CSP 6: 432 ("Wood, A."), 8: 1267, 12: 792; Ewan ed. 1: 49, 50, 51; GR p. 199;
Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 43, 357, 487; Lenley p. 440, 472; ME 1: 242, 3: 680 (index);
PH 1-B; PR 10394; Rehder 5: 931; TL-1/1444; Tucker 1: 752-753, 2: xli, 3: 340; Zander
ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 837.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Appleton's Cycl. Amer, biogr. 6: 591. 1889 (b. 17 Sep 1810, d. 4 Jan
	1881); Bot. Centralbl. 5: 255. 1881 (d.), 7: 223-224. 1881 (obit. not.); Bot. Gaz. 6(2):
	168. 1881 (obit. not.); Bronx Borough Record and Times 19 Apr 1903, 2 p. (biogr.

	sketch, portr.); Bull. Torrey bot. Club 8(1): 12. 1881 (obit. not.); Natl. Cycl. Amer.

Wood, Horatio C (1841-1920), American physician, entomologist and botanist; M.D.
Pennsylvania Univ., Philadelphia 1862; practicing physician from 1865; professor of
botany Pennsylvania 1866-1876; professor of diseases of the nervous system 1875-1902,
id. of materia medica &amp; therapeutics 1876-1906; emeritus professor from 1906. (<em>H.C.
Wood</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (Pennell 1943).

Jan 1820); BM 5: 2352; DAB 20: 459-460; De Toni 1: cxxxiv; DNB 14: 495-497; Jackson
p. 359; Kelly p. 243; LS 29238; ME 1: 243, 3: 680 (index); Morren ed. 10, p. 130; NI
2181; Nordstedt p. 34; PH 247, 450, 567; Rehder 5: 931. SIA see index; Tucker 1: 753,
3: 340.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Allibone, S.A., Crit. dict. Engl. lit. 3: 2819. 1880, suppl. 2: 1543. 1891.
Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 1-3. 1906-1921; J. Amer. med. Assoc. 74(2): 120. 1920 (id.);
	Natl. Cycl. Amer. biogr. 13: 569-570. 1906; Science 51: 106-107. 1920 (obit.); Who's

<em>Note on name</em>: In his youth Horatio C Wood Jr., later Horatio C Wood Sr. as distinct

PAGE: 438
HEADING: H.C. WOOD

from his son's name Horatio Charles Wood Jr. (1874-?). The "C" was a compromise: his
father wanted Curtis, his mother Charles.

Wood, John Bland (1813-1890), British physician and bryologist; studied at Dublin,
Edinburgh and London; practicing physician at Broughton nr Manchester; ultimately
in retirement at Withington. (<em>J.B. Wood</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MANCH (bryoph.); Further material at DBN, HFX (1400, see
Kent &amp; Allen 1984), K, NMW, OXF, SWN, WAR. – <em>Letters</em> at BM, K, MANCH,
OXF. – For his correspondence see Wm. A. Lee (1920).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 516; BB p. 333; BM 5: 2352; Clokie p. 267;
CSP 6: 433; Desmond p. 673; Jackson p. 256; PR 10395; Tucker 1: 753.

Wood, John Medley (1827-1915), English-born South African botanist; in the East
Indian merchant service ca. 1845-1852; emigrated to South Africa 1852; trading store
owner Inanda, Natal 1852-1882; curator of the Natal Botanic Garden, Durban 1882-
1908; director of the Natal Garden and Herbarium 1900; director of the Natal
Herbarium 1913; D.Sc. h.c. Univ. Cape Good Hope 1913. (<em>J-M. Wood</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NH. – Further material at A, B (mainly destr.), BM, BOL, BR,
C, DPU, E, F, G, K, LCU, M, MANCH, MIN, MO, P, PH, PRE, SAM, UPS, US,
VT, W. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Woodruffe-Peacock, [originally Peacock] Edward Adrian (1858-1922), British
clergyman and botanist; studied at St. John's College, Cambridge 1877, at Durham
University 1879; ordained 1881 (dean), 1883 (priest) curate at Long Benton, Northum-
berland 1881-1884; Barkingside, Essex (1884-1886), Harrington, Northamptonshire
1886-1890; from 1891 vicar at Cadney (<em>Woodr.-Peacock</em>).

Woods, Albert Fred (1866-1948), American botanist; B.Sc. Univ. Nebraska 1890,
M.A. ib. 1892; assistant ib. 1890-1893; with USDA as pathologist in the Division of
vegetable Physiology and Pathology 1893-1900, and the Bureau of Plant Industry 1900-
1910; dean of Minnesota State Agricultural College and director of its Experimental
Station 1901-1917; president of Maryland State College 1917, from 1920-1926 id. of the
University of Maryland; director of scientific work USDA 1926-1934, director of its
graduate school 1926-1941, educational adviser 1941-1947. (<em>A.F. Woods</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NEB. - <em>Letters</em> at HI.

Woods, Joseph (1776-1864), British architect and botanist; architect in London until
1833; from then on living at Lewes in retirement and dedicating himself to botany. (<em>J.

Woods, Julian Edmund Tenison [Tenison-Woods] (1832-1889), British clergyman,
naturalist and botanist; studied at Oxford; to Tasmania 1854 as a lay chaplain; to
Australia 1855, working as a journalist and completing his theological studies; ordained
priest Rom. Cath. Church 1857; parish priest of Penola, S. Australia 1857-1867; director
of Catholic education for Australia 1867-1871; missionary in New South Wales and
Queensland 1872-1883, from 1883 dedicating himself fully to natural history; pioneer
Australian geologist. (<em>Ten.-Woods</em>).

HERBARIUM and TYPES: MEL. - Further material BRI, NSW and presumably CAL
(Malaysian material see SK 1: 519). - <em>Drawings</em> at Mitchell LibrarySydney.

Oct 1889); BB p. 298, 334; BL 1: 69, 324; BM 5: 2355; Bossert p. 396, 442; CSP 6: 436,
8: 1270, 11: 564-566, 12: 724, 19: 54; Desmond p. 604; DNB 62: 410 (21: 881); HR; IF
p. 733; Jackson p. 510, 511; LS 26417-26419; Quenstedt p. 425; Rehder 5: 932; SK 1:
518-519, 5: cccxxvi; TL-2/see W. Trelease; Tucker 1: 753, 3: 341.

Woodson, Robert [Everard], Jr. (1904-1963), American botanist; studied at Was-
hington University, St. Louis, Missouri; M.S. ib. 1927; M.A. Harvard 1928; Dr. phil.
Washington Univ. 1929; instructor in botany ib. 1929-1935, assistant professor 1935-
1942, associate professor 1942-1945, regular professor 1945-1963; assistant herbarium
Missouri Botanical Garden 1928-1937, asst. curator 1937-1947, "curator" 1945-1955,
curator 1955-1956, 1959-1963. (<em>Woodson</em>).

HERBARIUM and TYPES: MO. - Other material at A, C, DPU, F, GH, U, US, VT, W. -
<em>Field notes</em> and <em>manuscripts</em>: MO. - <em>Letters</em> at G, IAPT, NY, US.

p. 536; NW p. 61; PH 209; SIA see index; TL-2/781, 12.172; Tucker 3:341; Zander ed.
10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 838.

Woodville, William (1752-1805), British physician and botanist; studied at Edinburgh
Univ., M.D. 1775; practicing physician at Papcastle and Denbigh, Scotland; from 1782
in London as physician to the Middlesex dispensary; physician to the smallpox and
inoculation hospitals at St. Pancras 1791-1805. (<em>Woodv</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 518; BB p. 334-335; BM 5: 2355; Bossert p.
442; Desmond p. 675-676 (d. 26 Mar 1905); DNB 62: 417 (21: 888-889); Dryander 3:
401; DU 334; GF p. 81; Henrey 2: 748 [index]; Herder p. p. 414; Hortus 3: 1207; HU
2(1): clxii, 2(2): no. 716, 3: no. 3, 1521-1524; Jackson p. 201; NI 2183; Plesch p. 463; PR
10398, ed. 1: 11358, 11578; Rehder 3: 55; SO 743, 745; Sotheby 823, 824; TL-1/1046
(H. Woodville); TL-2/8755 (H. Woodvillc; see W.J. Hooker, J. Sowerby); Tucker 1:
753-754.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 260: 800. 1965.
Gibbs, W., Dedicated, a novel, 1960 (fiction: also as Two doctors, a novel, 1959).
Hoeffer, ed., Nouv. biogr. gén. 46: 830. 1866.
Munk, W., Roll R. Coll. Physicians London ed. 2. 2: 345. 1878.
Redgrove, H.S., Gard. Chron. 97: 306-307. 1935 (modern evaluation).
Thornton, R.J., Phil. bot. 3: <em>pl. 23.</em> 1806 (portr.).
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(2): 99. 1903.

by "H. Woodville", are possibly by William Woodville (see also Mabberley, Taxon 32:
80. 1983).

Woodward, Robert (1877-1915), British barrister and horticulturist; educated at
Radley College and Christ Church, Oxford; called to the Bar at the Inner Temple;
practiced on the Oxford circuit; lieutenant in the South Wales Borderers. 1914, died in
action in Northern France 9 Mai 1915; heir to Arley Castle. (<em>R. Woodw.</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 518; Desmond p. 676; Tucker 1: 145, 754,
780.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1945: 263-264; Gard. Chron ser. 3. 57: 279. 1915
	(portr., obit. not.).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1909 (p. 6), cover ("Hortus arleyensis"), p. [1]-88. <em>Copy</em>: USDA.

Woodward, Thomas Jenkinson (1745-1820), British country gentleman of leisure
and botanist; LLB Cambridge 1769; magistrate and deputy-lieutenant for Suffolk, later
Norfolk; lieutenant-colonel of the Diss volunteers; F.L.S. 1789. (<em>Woodw</em>.).

Woolls, William (1814-1893), British-born Australian school teacher, journalist and
botanist; Dr. phil. Göttingen 1870 (in absentia, not h.c); emigrated to Australia 1832;
assistant master at The King's School, Parramatta 1832-1836, journalist and private
teacher at Sydney 1836; classical master at Sydney College, later in charge of a private
school at Parramatta until 1865; took holy orders in the Church of England 1873;
episcopal minister, later dean at Richmond 1873-1883; retirement at Sydney. (<em>Woolls</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: NSW. - Further material at GOET, MEL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 520; BB p. 335; BJI 1: 64; BL 1: 67, 324; BM

1893); Herder p. 230; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 6, 63, 398, 399; LS 29261; PR 10399;
Rehder 5: 932; Tucker 1: 754, 3: 341.

Woolsey, Theodore Salisbury, Jr. (1880-1933), United States forester and botanist;
AB Yale Univ. 1901, Master of Forestry Yale 1903; with the United States Forestry
Service 1908-1915; lecturer in forestry Yale ca. 1912, 1916-1917; on active service in
Europe 1917-1919; from 1919 consulting forester in New Haven. (<em>Woolsey</em>).

Woolson, Grace A. (1856-1911), American pteridologist and gardener; sometime
school teacher at Pittsford, Vermont. (<em>Woolson</em>).

Woolward, Florence Helen (1854-1930), British botanist and botanical artist.

Wooster, David (ca. 1824-1888), British nurseryman, sometime associated with J.C.

Wooton, Elmer Ottis (1865-1945), American botanist; studied at Earlham College,
B.S. 1889, A.M. 1896; in charge of botany New Mexico State College 1890-1896;
studied at Columbia University and the New York Botanical Garden 1896-1898; profes-
sor of botany Agricultural College and Experiment Station, New Mexico 1898-1900, of
biology 1900-1911; in various functions with USDA 1911-1935; in retirement at
Arlington, Va. (<em>Woot</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: US (main herb.), NMC ("apparenty second set", inf. IH ed. 7);
further material at ARIZ, B (mainly destr.), BM, E, GH, ILL, IND, K, MIN, MO
(large set), NY (large set), P, POM, RM, US (large set), WELC, WVA.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>New Mexico plants</em>, collected 1897, sold in sets of ca. 400-500 specimens (see
Ewan ed. 2, 243-244). <em>List</em>: <em>New Mexico plants</em>, p. [1]-4. <em>Copy</em>: NY, s.l.n.d. [ca. 1897]. –
<em>Letters</em> at G, NY (e.g. in Barnhart corr.), SIA.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 519, 520 (b. 19 Sep 1865); BL 1: 199, 324, 2:
194; BM 5: 2361; Bossert p. 442; Ewan ed. 1: 64, 267, 312, 341-342, ed. 2: 243-244;
Hortus 3: 1207; IH 1 (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7): 346; Langman p. 812; Rehder 1: 327, 2: 299;
SIA see index; TL-2/12.752, see P.C. Standley; Tucker 1: 754, 2: xli, 3: 341; Urban-Berl.
p. 411; Zander ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Amer. men sci. eds. 1-8. 1906-1949; Bot. Centralbl. 76: 111. 1898 (app.
	New Mexico); Cat. gen. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 227: 142-143. 1977; Index Amer. bot.

Woronin, Michael [Stephanovitch] (1838-1903), Russian botanist, and mycologist
(phytopathologist); studied natural sciences at the University of St. Petersburg 1854-
1858, at Heidelberg 1858-1859, at Freiburg i.Br. with A. de Bary 1859-1860; at Antibes
with G.A. Thuret 1860; Mag. bot. St. Petersburg 1861; Dr. phil. h.c. Odessa 1874;
private scientist working mainly at St. Petersburg from 1861; member of the Imp. Akad.
Sci. St. Petersburg 1898; Foreign member Linn. Soc. 1895. (<em>Woronin</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown, some marine algae at FR and GOET; further
material at MW. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Ainsworth p. 62, 117, 283; Barnhart 3: 521; Biol.-
Dokum. 19: 10186; Bossert p. 443; CSP 6: 439, 8: 1274, 11: 723, 19: 405-406; De Toni 1:
cxxxiv; Frank 3 (Anh.): 115; GR p. 568-569; Herder p. 127, 247, 255; Jackson 84, 157,
163, 172; Kelly p. 259; KR p. 777; LS 1894, 1900a, 8288, 29263-29317, 40708-40712;
Moebius p. 100, 242; Morren ed. 10, p. 96; MW p. 536; PR 455, 457; Rehder 5: 932;
Stevenson p. 1263; TL-2/9597; TR 1615-1622; Tucker 1: 754.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Ainsworth, G.C., Dict. fungi ed. 6. 622. 1971.
Anon., Acta Horti bot. Univ. imp. jurjev. 1: 47-51. 1900 (biogr. sketch.; list 60 publ.);
	Allg. bot. Z. 4: 188. 1898 (ord. member Acad. Sci. St. P.); Bot. Centralbl. 64: 432.
	1895 (hon. memb. Deut. bot. Ges.), 76: 111. 1898 (ord. member Acad. Sci. St. P.),
	92: 288. 1903 (d.); Bot. Zeit. 45: 663. 1887 (address); Bull. Acad. Sci. St. Pétersbourg
	ser. 5. 18: iv-x. 1903 (list publ., 64 nos.); Nat. Nov. 25: 243. 1903 (d.); Österr. bot. Z.
	53: 311. 1903 (d.); Proc. Linn. Soc. London 116: 37-38. 1904.
Borodin, I., Acta Horti bot. Univ. imp. jurjev. 4: 286-293. 1903 (obit.).
Cavillier, F., Boissiera 5: 94. 1941.
Chupp, Ch., <em>in</em> M. Woronin, Plasmidiophora Brassicae 1934, p. 5-8.
Famintzin, A., Trav. Mus. bot. Acad. St. Pétersb. 2: 1-13. 1915 (obit., portr., list 65
	publ.).
Mägdefrau, K., Gesch. Bot. 174. 1973.

	Feb 1903).

Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 361. 1936, 4: 276. 1938.
Whetzel, H.H., Outline hist. phytopath. 88-90, 125. 1918.
Wittrock, V.B., Acta Horti Berg. 3(3): 190, <em>pl. 122.</em> 1905.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The text of Woronin's <em>Plasmidiophora Brassicae</em>, Urheber der Kohlpflanzen-Hernie,
originally published in Jahrb. wiss. Bot. 11: 548-574, <em>pl. 29-34.</em> 1884, reprinted p. [1]-27,
<em>pl. 29-34</em> (<em>copies</em> FH, Stevenson) was issued in an English translation in the series Phy-
topathological classics, no. 4, American Phytopathological Society 1934 (cover, portr.,
p. [1]-32, <em>pl. 29-34</em>) with a biographical sketch of Woronin by Charles Chupp.

Laubach (1867).

Worsdell, Wilson Crosfield (1867-1957), American-born British horticulturist and
botanist; studied horticulture in Holland and England; sometime demonstrator in
botany at University College of London and working at the Jodrell Laboratory; acting
professor of botany S. African College, Cape Town 1909-1910; lecturer in botany
Victoria College, Stellenbosch 1912-1913; subsequently working at the Jodrell Laborat-
ory and the Royal Botanic Gardens Kew. (<em>Worsdell</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BIRM (S. Afr. pl.); British plants at BDK, BM(K, alg.), GLW,
K, NMW and QMC (see Kent &amp; Allen, 1981).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 521; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10187; BJI 2: 194;
Bossert p. 443; CSP 19: 716-717; Desmond p. 677 (b. 15 Sep 1867, d. 29 Oct 1957);
Langman p. 812; Moebius p. 146, 209; Rehder 5: 932; TL-2/12.808; Tucker 2: xli.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bull. misc. Inf. Kew 1909:22 (deputy prof. bot. S. Afr. Coll., Cape
	Town, replacing H.H.W. Pearson); Gard. Chron. 142: 378. 1957 (obit.); Index
	Amer. bot. lit. 1886-1966. 4: 582. 1969; Nat. Nov. 31: 241. 1909 (interim prof. bot.
	Cape Town).

lived in Isleworth, Middlesex from 1894; specialist on Amaryllis. (<em>Worsl</em>.).

Wortmann, Julius (1856-1925), German (Westfalen) botanist; studied natural
sciences at the University of Berlin 1875-1877 (especially with L. Kny), id. Würzburg
1877-1879 with J. Sachs; Dr. phil. Würzburg 1879; assistant with A. de Bary in Strass-
burg 1880-1884; habil. Strassburg 1883; lecturer ib. 1883-1891; head of the plant physic-
ological experiment station at Geisenheim a. Rh. 1891-1895; from 1895-1925 with the
title professor, ultimately as director of the station. (<em>Wortmann</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 522 (b. 15 Aug 1856, d. 28 Jun 1925); BM 5:
2363; CSP 11: 851, 12: 793, 19: 718-719; Frank 3(Anh.): 115; Jackson p. 81; LS 29318-
29350a, 40716-40723, suppl. 30453-30455; Morren ed. 10, p. 28; Rehder 5: 933.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 44: 416. 1890 (app. Geisenheim), 105: 16. 1907 (call to
	Berlin-Dahlem declined), 105: 160. 1907 (Geh. Regierungsrat); Bot. Zeit. 39: 131.
	1881 (asst. Strassburg), 41: 423. 1883 (habil. Strassburg), 48: 803. 1890 (app.
	Geisenheim as of 1 Feb 1891), 53: 328. 1895 (professor's title); Nat. Nov. 17: 641.

Wossidlo, Paul (1836-?), German (Posen) high school teacher and botanist; Dr. phil.
Breslau 1860; teacher at the Breslau High School (Realschule), from 1870 director of a
similar school in Tarnowitz (Upper Silesia). (<em>Wossidlo</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown (possibly, if any, WRSL).

Wóycicki, Zygmunt (1871-1941), Polish botanist; studied at the University of
Warsaw; professor of botany at the University of Lemberg (Lwow) 1913; later professor
of general botany at the University of Warsaw. (<em>Wóycicki</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 522 (b. 5 Sep 1871); Hirsch p. 329; LS

	(bibl.).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: Wóycicki's son Stanislaw Wóycicki (1897-1970) was a horticulturist at Warsaw
University, long-time head of its Department of decorative plants; director of the
Warsaw municipal gardens and long-time editor of <em>Acta Agrobotanica</em>. – For a biography
and bibliography see H. Chmiel, Acta Agrobot. 23(1): 5-9. 1970.

Woynar, Heinrich Karl (1865-1917), Austrian botanist; studied pharmacy at the
University of Innsbruck 1887-1889; from 1900 living at Graz as private scientist.
(<em>Woyn</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GZU. – Further material in GB, GJO, STU. — <em>Letters</em> at UPS-
UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 522; Hortus 3: 1207; IF suppl. 2: 39; Zander
ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Österr. bot. Z. 67: 1184. 1918 (d. 7 Aug 1917).
Widder, F.J. &amp; H. Teppner, Phyton 20(3-4): 207-213. 1980 (biogr., bibl., coll., b. 3 Jun
	1865, d. 8 [not 7] Aug 1917).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For H.K. Woynar's father, Johann Woynar (1829-1900), practicing pharmacist
at Innsbruck, who also published on the flora of Tirol, see Widder &amp; Teppner (1980). —
Collections in GZU (and B, herb. Ullepitsch, E, GOET); letters e.g. at UPS-UB.

<sm>HANDWRITING</sm>: Phyton 20: 212. 1980.

18.336. <em>Bemerkungen über Farnpflanzen Steiermarks</em> ... Graz (Verlag des Naturwissenschaftli-

<em>Publ</em>.: 1913, p. [i], [120]-200. <em>Copy</em>: NY. – Reprinted and to be cited from Mitt. Naturw.
	Ver. Steiermark 49: [120]-200. 1912.

Wredow, Johann Christian Ludwig [Ludewig] (1773-1823), German
(Mecklenburg-Schwerin) clergyman, teacher, cantor and botanist; teacher at the
"Herzogliche grosse Schule" at Parchim; ultimately pastor at Parum. (<em>Wredow</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: "Landschullehrer-Seminar" Ludwiglust (fide E. Boll, 1860; pre-
sent location not known); see Wredow (1805) for the announcement of the publication
of various sets of exsiccatae.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 523; BM 5: 2363; Herder p. 190, 367; PR
10406-10407, ed. 1: 11363-11365; Rehder 5: 933.

	Ludwigslust).

nach der Blüthenzeit geordneten, Verzeichnisse aller in Mecklenburg wildwachsenden,

18.338. <em>Oekonomisch-technische Flora Meklenburgs</em>; oder Beschreibung nicht allein aller in

Wretschko, Matthias [Ritter von] (1834-1914), Austrian teacher and naturalist;
studied in Graz and Wien, teacher's examination 1857; Dr. phil. Wien 1859; teacher at
a Gymnasium in Pesth (Budapest) 1859-1861; idem in Laibach (Ljubljana) 1861-1865;
at the Academic Gymnasium in Wien 1865-1869; habil. Wien 1866; regional supervisor
for natural sciences and mathematics in the high school system of S.E. Austria at Graz
1869-1877; idem for lower Austria in Wien 1877; ennobled 1883. (<em>Wretschko</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal at HAL.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BM 5: 2363; CSP 8: 1276; Jackson p. 86, 91, 486; PR
10408-10410; Rehder 1: 90, 5: 933; WU 58: 204-207.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 27: 504. 1869 (app. Graz); Flora 52: 393. 1869 (app. Schul-
	inspektor S.E. Austria, stationed at Graz); Neue Freie Presse, Wien, 2 Feb 1904
	(biogr. sketch); Wiener Zeit. 12 Nov 1918 (d. 9 Nov 1918).

Wright, Albert Allen (1846-1905), American geologist and naturalist; studied at
Oberlin College, A.B. 1865; two years at Union Theological Seminary; degree theology
Oberlin Seminary 1870; Ph.D. School of Mines, Columbia Univ. 1875; teacher in
Cleveland Institute 1865-ca. 1867, at Berea College, Kentucky 1870-ca. 1872; professor
of geology and natural history Oberlin College 1874-1905. (<em>A.A. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: OC. – <em>Letters</em> at GH.

PAGE: 464
HEADING: A.A. WRIGHT

Quenstedt p. 469; Rehder 1: 315; Tucker 1: 755.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Entom. News 16(5): 160. 1905 (obit. not.); Amer. men sci. ed. I. 364.

	USDA. – Laboratory Bulletin Oberlin College no. 1, Supplement.

Wright, Charles (1811-1885), American botanical collector; studied at Yale College
1831-1835; private teacher at Natchez, Mississippi 1836-1837; teacher in Zarvala and
Rutersville, Texas 1837-1847; volunteer in the U.S. Army 1847-1848 during the
Mexican war, collected for Asa Gray in the Mexican Boundary Region; 1849-1850 with
the U.S. Army from San Antonio to El Paso on the Rio Grande; teacher in Central
Texas 1850-1852; botanist and surveyor on the Graham Boundary Survey 1851-1852;
returned to Cambridge, Mass.; on the North Pacific Exploring Expedition under capt.
Ringgold and comm. J. Rodgers 1853-1855; visited Nicaragua 1855; collected in Cuba
on various trips 1856-1867; working at Cambridge 1867-1871; visited Sto. Domingo
1871; working in Cambridge from 1871-1876; in retirement at Wethersfield, Conn.
1876-1885. (<em>C. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GH (general colls.), US (Mexican Boundary Survey, Ringgold
Exp.).
<em>Duplicates of Texas collections</em>: DPU, FI, G, K, MO, OXF, PH, SMU, YU. – For labelling
of Texas plants see Ewan (ed. 1: 342), Wooton (1906) and Shaw (1987).
<em>Duplicates from Ringgold and Rodgers N. Pacific Expl. Exp.</em>: FH, K, LE, PH.
<em>Duplicates from New Mexico</em>: BM, CGE, F, FI, G, MO.
<em>Duplicates from Mexico</em>: FI, G, L.
<em>Duplicates from Nicaragua</em>: GOET, K, MO, US.
<em>Duplicates from Cuba</em>: B (mainly destr.), BM, BP, BR, BREM, BRU, BUF, CGE, DPU,
E, F, FH, G, G-DC, GOET (impt. set), HAB (impt. set), HAC, K, L, LE, MA, MO,
NY, P, PH, S, TCD, US, W, WELC.
<em>Mosses</em> (Cuba): BM(BM-K), FH, G, H.
<em>Lichens</em> (Cuba): BM, G, H-Nyl., M, PC, TCD, TUR-V, WRSL.
<em>Fungi</em> (Cuba): B (destr.), BPI, BUF, FH, G, K(BM-K), LPS, PC, NY, NYS.
For <em>Fungi cubenses wrightianae</em> see Stevenson, Beih. Nova Hedw. 34: 526-527. 1971.
<em>Algae</em> (Cuba): FH, W.
<em>Ferns</em> (Cuba): IA.
<em>Santo Domingo</em>: GH, K, US (see Howard, R.A. 1961).
For more details see Shaw (1987) and the coming treatment in I.H. Vegter, <em>Index
Herbariorum Collectors Index</em>.
<em>Manuscripts</em>: GH. – <em>Letters</em>: GH (impt. set), NY, UPS-UB.

Wright, Charles Henry (1864-1941), British botanist; studied at Oxford University;
assistant Kew Herbarium 1884-1908, asst. keeper ib. 1908-1929; asst. examiner in
botany, S. Kensington 1899-1901; lecturer in botany 1905-1929. (<em>C.H. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: RAMM and K; further material in BM (bryoph.), NY. – <em>Letters
</em>at NY (incl. some mss. notes).

Lenley p. 442, 4183, 29363; MW p. 536; Rehder 2: 68; TL-2/1814, 2448, 7055, see T.
Cooke; TL-2/see E.F. Vallentin; Tucker 1: 755, 3: 341; Zander ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p.
838.

Wright, Edward Perceval (1834-1910), Irish naturalist; MA Dublin 1857, MD ib.
1862; lecturer in zoology Trinity College, Dublin 1858-1868; professor of botany ib.
1869-1904; keeper of TCD 1870-1910; collected on the Seychelles 1867, in Sicily and
Portugal 1868. (<em>E. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TCD. – Further material at BM (Seychelles), FRS, K (Seych-
elles), MO, OXF. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, G, K.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 523 (b. 27 Dec 1834, d. 4 Mar 1910); BB p.
376; BM 5: 2364; Clokie p. 268; CSP 6: 442, 8: 1277-1278, 11: 856-857, 19: 722;
Desmond p. 678-679; De Toni 1: cxxxiv-cxxxv; DSB suppl. 3: 709-710; Herder p. 214;
Jackson p. 157, 353; LS 29365-29369; Morren ed. 2, p. 23; Rehder 5: 933; Tucker 1:
755.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 113: 464. 1910 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print, books
	261: 363-364. 1965; Flora 52: 144. 1869 (prof. bot. TCD); Nat. Nov. 26: 253. 1904,

Wright, John (1811-1846), American physician and naturalist; studied at the Ren-
sselaer Polytechnic Institute (N.Y.) (with Amos Eaton); graduated in medicine at Yale
College 1833; practicing physician at Troy, N.Y.; with the Michigan geological survey
1838; professor of natural history in the Rensselaer Institute 1838-1845. (<em>J. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MICH (500); further material in NA (Mich. coll. via Martindale
Herb. from Zina Pitcher herb.; inf. E.G. Voss). – <em>Letters</em> at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 524 (b. 2 Feb 1811, d. 11 Apr 1846); BL 1:
204; BM 5: 2365; Hortus 3: 1207; IH 1 (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7): 346; Lenley p. 472; ME 1:
243, 2: 636, 639, 3: 422; Rehder 1: 313; TL-2/1614; Tucker 1: 755.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Jelliffe, S.E., Cycl. Amer. med. biogr. 532-533. 1912; <em>in</em> H.A. Kelly &amp; W.L.
	Burrage, Amer. med. biogr. 1269. 1920.
McVaugh, R., Mich. Botanist 9: 213-243. 1970 (on bot. results Mich. Geol. Survey;
	major source of information, coll.).
Meyer, F.G. &amp; S. Elsasser, Taxon 22: 383. 1973 (Mich. coll. NA).
Voss, E.G., Contr. Univ. Mich. Herb. 13: 22-25, 68. 1978.

HEADING: W. WRIGHT

	cited from Ann. Rep. State Geol. Surv. Michigan 2(app.): 17-44. 1839, but see also
	McVaugh (1970), p. 225, footnote 18.

Wright, William (1735-1819), British physician and botanist; studied medicine at
Edinburgh University; to Greenland 1757; surgeon's mate in the British navy 1758-
1763, visiting e.g. Jamaica; MD St. Andrews; practicing physician on Jamaica 1764-
1777; in London 1777-1779; regimental surgeon in the Jamaican regiment 1779; in
Spanish captivity 1779-1781; again in Jamaica 1781-1785, ultimately as physician-
general; settled in Edinburgh 1788 (1786?); visited Barbados 1796-1798; from 1798
again in Edinburgh. (<em>W. Wright</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM (major set in herb. Banks), E (3 vols.), and LIV (1 vol.). -
Further material in BR (identified by J.R. Brown), G, K, OXF. – <em>Letters</em> BM, DTC.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 629; Barnhart 3: 524 (b. Mar 1735); BB p.
336; BM 5: 2365; Clokie p. 268; CSP 6: 446; Dawson p. 882; Desmond p. 679-680 (d. 19
Sep 1819); DNB 63: 136-137; Dryander 3: 463, 476, 499, 513; Hortus 3: 1207; Plesch p.
464; PR 10411, ed. 1: 11366; Rehder 5: 933; Tucker 1: 755.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Memoir of the late William Wright, M.D., Edinburgh and London
	1828, 456 p. (copy at Natl. Libr. Medicine, Washington, D.C.).
[Cockerell, T.D.A.], J. Inst. Jamaica 2(2): 183. 1895 (text on portrait in Jamaica Por-
	trait Gallery).
Fawcett, W., J. Bot. 60: 330-334. 1922 (biogr. sketch, colls.).
Hall, T.B., Naturalist 4: 399. 1839 (plants from Jamaica in Liverpool Bot. Gard.).
Miller, H.S., Taxon 19: 545-546. 1970 (coll.; Lambert material, now at G?).
Stafleu, F.A., et al., <em>in</em> CL. L'Héritier, Sertum angl., facs. ed. 1963, p. lix, lxxiv, 6.
Stearn, W.T., J. Arnold Arb. 46: 272. 1965.
Stearns, R.P., Osiris 8: 116-117. 1948.
Urban, I., Symb. ant. 1: 59, 178-179. 1898, 3: 144-145. 1902 (coll.), 7(1): 77. 1911 (on
	erroneously labeled Barbados plants at BM and K).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: (1) See e.g. Urban, (1898) for the still relevant botanical publications by Wright
on Jamaican plants:
(a) <em>Description of the Jesuits bark tree of Jamaica and the Caribbees</em>, Phil. Trans. R. Soc.
London 67: 504-506, <em>pl. 10.</em> 1777.
(b) <em>Descriptions and use of the Cabbage-bark tree of Jamaica</em>, id. 67: 507-512, <em>pl. 10.</em> 1777.
(c) <em>An account of the medicinal plants growing in Jamaica</em>, London med. J. 8(3): 217-295.
1787. – Reprinted in <em>Mem. late William Wright</em>, London &amp; Edinburgh 1828, p. 183-245;
<em>Essai sur les plantes usuelles de la Jamaïque</em>, J. Phys. Hist. nat. 32(1): 347-361. Mai 1788,
401-419. Jun 1788.
(d) <em>A botanical and medical account of the Quassia Simaruba</em>, ... Trans. R. Soc. Edinburgh 2:
73-81, <em>pl. 1-2.</em> 1790, text also in London med. J. 11: 91-102. 1790.
(2) A manuscript "<em>Plants of Jamaica</em> by Willm Wright M.D. F.R.S." is kept in the Local
History Section of the Liverpool city Libraries. The introduction is dated London 29th
May 1786; the text is accompanied by 42 dried specimens (inf. Edmondson 25 Nov
1985).

Wuensche, Johann Georg (<em>fl</em>. 1804), German (Prussian-Saxony) physician and bota-
nist at Wittenberg. (<em>J. Wuensche</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

Wünsche, [Friedrich] Otto (1839-1905), German (Saxonian) botanist and high
school teacher; studied at the teachers college of Bautzen 1855-1859; teacher's examinat-
ion 1859; teacher at Bernbruch nr. Kamenz 1859-1860; at Zittau 1860-1867; teacher for
natural sciences and geography at the Zwickau Gymnasium 1867-1904; Dr. phil.
Leipzig 1871; professor's title 1891. (<em>O. Wünsche</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Location unknown (offered for sale Allg. bot. Z. 15 Feb 1906,
cover; ca. 5680 specimens). – Some material in GOET.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 525 (b. 19 Mar 1839, d. 6 Jan 1905); BFM
486; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10197; BL 2: 195; BM 5: 2366; CSP 19: 727, 8: 1282; DTS 1: 332;
Futak-Domin p. 663; GR p. 156; Herder p. 485; Jackson p. 164, 296, 310, 312; Kelly p.
243; LS 29383-29386, 40727-40729; Morren ed. 10, p. 23; PR 10414-10415; TL-2/2725,
4398, 16.290; Tucker 1: 755.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Abromeit, J., Natur und Schule 4: 238-239. 1905 (obit.); Ber. deut. bot. Ges.

HEADING: WÜSTNEI

Wüstnei, Karl Georg Gustav (1810-1858), German (Mecklenburg-Schwerin) high
school teacher, botanist and entomologist; from 1835 teacher for mathematics and
natural sciences at the high school in Schwerin; contributed to Rabenhorst's series of
exsiccatae. (<em>Wüstnei</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Owned a large herbarium which was offered for sale after his
death; present location unknown. – Some material in B ("Flora Suerin", mycol. herb.
extant), GOET (bryoph.), M (lich.), WRSL (bryoph., lich.). Further specimens in L.
Rabenhorst, <em>Hepaticae europaeae</em> and <em>Bryotheca europaea</em>, q.v.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: <em>Lebermoose Mecklenburgs</em>, 1 Heft 1851. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 525 (b. 18 Feb 1810, d. 12 Oct 1858); BM 5:
2367; CSP 6: 458; PR alph.; Urban-Berl. p. 284.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 7: 138. 1859 (obit, not.); Flora 42: 480. 1859 (d.).
Boll, E., Fl. Meklenburg 177. 1860.
Brockmuller, H., Bot. Zeit. 17: 192. 1859 (obit.), 19: 288. 1861 (herb, for sale).
Potztal, E., Willdenowia 3(1): 37. 1962 (mycol. herb. B, extant).

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: Contributed to C.F.B. Fiedler, <em>Syn. Laubm. Mecklenb.</em> 1844, TL-
2/1769, q.v.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wuestneia</em> Auerswald ex Fuckel (1863) probably was named for Wüstnei but
no etymology was given with the description of the genus.

Wuitner, Émile (1865-1946), French algologist, packer in a Paris department store;
inspector with the Paris gas-works, ultimately copy editor for scientific publications with
the firm of Paul Lechevalier; self-taught scientist. (<em>Wuitner</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Laboratory of the Muséum national d'histoire naturelle at
Biarritz.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Thonet, V. &amp; P. Jovet, Bull. Centr. Études Rech. sci. Biarritz 2(3): 351-355.
	1959 (biogr. sketch, bibl., notes on herbarium).

18.366. <em>Les algues marines des côtes de France</em> (Manche et Océan) ... Paris (Paul. Lechevalier ...) 1921. 18-mo. (<em>Alg. mar. France</em>).

<em>Ed</em>. [<em>1</em>]: 1921 (p. viii: 31 Jan 1921), p. [i]-cxiii, 1-129 [p. 1 on verso of cxiii], <em>pl. 1-112.
	Copies</em>: FH, G, NY. – The book is based on an unpublished and unfinished manuscript
	and a set of 96 col. plates by Charles Louis Gatin (1877-1916; fell at Verdun 26 Feb
	1916). – Plates <em>1-96</em> are coloured (by Gatin), <em>97-112</em> uncoloured, by Wuitner, who also
	made the 119 analytical drawings.
<em>Ed. 2</em>: 1947 (printing terminated 25 Jan 1947, see p. [131]), p. [i]-cxx, [1*, h.t.], [1]-
	129, [130, adv., 131, colo.], <em>pl. 1-112</em> (id.). <em>Copies</em>: BR, NY, US. – (Wuitner died 11
	Feb 1946).

18.367. <em>Flore algologique de Belle-Isle-en-Mer</em> (Morbihan) ... [Ann. Ass. Natural. Levallois-
Perret] 1931. Oct. (<em>Fl. alg. Belle-Isle-en-Mer</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1931, p. [1]-63, [1, err.]. <em>Copy</em>: BR. – Issued as Ann. Ass. Natural. Levallois-Perret
	20, 1914-1931 (publ. 1931).

Wulfen, Franz Xavier, Freiherr von (1728-1805), Austrian Jesuit, teacher and
botanist; noviciate at Vienna and Raab 1745-1749; studied philosophy and mathematics
at Vienna University; teacher at Görz 1755, Vienna 1756, Laibach 1762; monastic vows
1763; teacher of physics and mathematics at Klagenfurt 1764-1768; from 1769 onward
dedicating himself to natural sciences and philantropic work at Klagenfurt. (<em>Wulfen</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W (herb. rd. 1812; ca. 3800 specimens); further material at GJO
(impt. set), LINN, M (lich.), WU (alg., lich). – <em>Letters</em> to N.J. Jacquin UPS-UB; other

PAGE: 475
HEADING: WULFEN

letters at G. – <em>Manuscript</em>: <em>Flora norica</em> at W; see below for publication by Graf and Fenzl
(see also Riedl, 1981); also in W: <em>Icones pictae fungorum austriacorum</em> (113, col.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 44: 268-269; AG 2(1): 312, 5(2): 379, 6(2): 558;
Backer p. 630, 664; Barnhart 3: 525 (b. 5 Nov 1728, d. 16 Mar 1805); BM 5: 2367;
Bossert p. 444; CSP 6: 447; De Toni 1: cxxxv; Dryander 3: 153; DTS 1: 332-333, xxiv, 4:
xviii, 6(4): 209; Frank 3 (Anh.): 115-116; GR p. 443-444, <em>pl. 23</em>, cat. p. 73; Hawksworth
p. 187; Hegi 6(1): 64; Herder p. 149, 193, 255; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 113, 308;
Kanitz 57 (d. 17 Mar 1805); Lasègue p. 331; LS 29388-29391; NI see indexes; PR
10418-10420, ed. 1: 5449, 11372-11373; Quenstedt p. 470; Rehder 5: 234; Saccardo 1:
174, 2: 114, cron. p. xxxvi; Stevenson p. 1263; TL-2/14.884, see E. Fenzl; Tucker 1: 755;
WU 58: 265-269 (detailed biogr., sources, d. 17 Mar 1805); Zander ed. 10, p. 734, ed.
11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 10: 361. 1862 (cogn. Leopoldina Lycius II); Brit. Mus. gen.
	cat. print, books 261: 646. 1965; Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 227: 730-731. 1977;
	Flora 22(2): 671-672. 1839 (memorial at Klagenfurt); Portr.-Gallerie Aerzte Naturf.

	Doctor, ... Wien (in der Gassler'schen Buchhandlung) 1810, p. [i-viii], [1]-35 (<em>copies</em>:
	B-S, LD (biogr., portr.)).
Lack, H.H. &amp; CO. v. Sydow, Willdenowia 14: 446, 449. 1984 (letters to N.J. Jacquin).
Laundon, J.R., Lichenologist 11: 19. 1979 (lich. at M and possibly at W).

HEADING: WULFEN

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Wulfenia</em> N.J. v. Jacquin (1781).

<sm>NOTE</sm>: For remarks on Wulfen's descriptions on lichens published in N.J. von Jacquin,
Collectanea 2: 112ff. 1788, see J.E. Smith, Trans. Linn. Soc. 2: 10-14. 1 Mai 1794.

18.368. Xaveri de Wulfen abbatis klagenfurthensis <em>Cryptogama aquatica</em> ... Lipsiae
[Leipzig] (sumtibus bibliopolii Schaeferiani) 1803. Oct. (<em>Crypt. aquat.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1803, p. [i], [1]-64, <em>pl. 1</em> (uncol. copp. C. Melling). <em>Coples</em>: G, NY. – Preprinted or
	reprinted from J.J. Roemer, Arch. Bot. 3(1-2): 1-64, <em>pl. I.</em> 1803.

18.369. Francisci Xaverii Wulfen, ... <em>Plantarum rariorum descriptiones</em> ... Lipsiae [Leipzig]
(sumtibus bibliopoli Schaeferiani) 1805. Oct. (<em>pl rar. descr.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: Apr-Mai 1805 (or somewhat earlier as preprint), p. [i-iv], [1]-116. <em>Coples</em>: G, HH,
	NY; IDC 8764. – Preprinted or reprinted from J.J. Roemer, Arch. Bot. 3(3): 312-426.

18.370. Franz Xaver Freiherrn von Wulfen's <em>Flora norica phanerogama</em>. Im Auftrage des
Zoologisch-botanischen Vereines in Wien herausgegeben ... Wien (Druck und Verlag
von Carl Gerold's Sohn) 1858. Oct. (in 4-s). (<em>Fl. norica phan.</em>).

<em>Editors</em>: Eduard Fenzl (1808-1879), see TL-2/1: 823-824, and Rainer Graf (1811-1872).
<em>Publ</em>.: Apr 1858 (p. xii: 13 Jan 1858; ÖbZ 1 Mai 1858; Bonplandia 15 Mai 1858), p. [i]-
	xiv, [1]-816. <em>Coples</em>: G, H, HH, L, M, MO, NY, USDA; IDC 8765.
<em>Review</em>: Ign. Tomaschek, <em>Wulfen's Flora norica phanerogama</em>, Jahrb. nat. Hist. Mus.
	Kärnten 5: 57-70. 1862, repr. s.l.n.d. p. [1]-15. <em>Copy</em>: B.
<em>Noricum</em>: the classical Noricum corresponded roughly to the later Upper and Lower
	Austria, south of the Danube, Salzburg, Styria, Carinthia and parts of Tirol and
	Bavaria. Fenzl and Graf provide details in their introduction to the <em>Fl norica phan</em>.; for
	Wulfen the emphasis was on Carinthia. The mss. (at W) contains still further un-
	published parts, see Riedl 1981).

Wulff, Eugenii Vladimirovich (1885-1941), Russian botanist (plant-geographer);
Dr. phil. Univ. Wien 1910; ultimately curator of the Herbarium, Department of Geo-
graphy of Cultivated Plants of the U.S.S.R. Institute of Plant Industry. (<em>E. Wulff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LE, WIR. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 446 ("Vul'f b. 25 Mai 1885, d. 21 Dec
1941); BFM 1475, 2202, 2958; BJI 2: 195; GR p. 576; Hirsch p. 330; IH 1 (ed. 1): 55,
(ed. 2): 71, (ed. 3): 89, (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7) 346; MW p. 537, suppl. p. 396-397; TL-
2/3857, see N.I. Vavilov; Tucker 3: 342.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Asmous, V.C., Science ser. 2. 100: 43. 1944 (obit. not.; killed by a bomb frag-
	ment at Leningrad 21 Dec 1941); Chron. bot. 11(2): 112-113. 1947 (fontes hist. bot.
	ross).
Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 696. 1984.
Lipschitz, S.J., Eugène Wulff comme botaniste (1885-1941), <em>in</em> E.V. Wulff, Istor. geogr.
	rasten. Moskwa, Leningrad 1944, p. iii-xix (biogr., extensive bibl.); Fl. URSS fontes
	nos. 281-286. 1975.
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 286, 287. 1936, 3: 135. 1937, 5: 89, 94, 135, 138. 269,
	323. 1939, 6: 311. 1941.
Wulff, E.V., Intr. hist. pl. geogr. 223 [index]. 1943.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1)Contributed <em>Fagaceae. Fagus</em> to V.L. Komarov, Fl. URSS 5: 354-
359. 22 Jun 1936. TL-2/3857.

author: vols. 2-3, 1945-1969.

Wulff, Thorild (1877-1917), Swedish botanist and explorer; Dr. phil. Lund 1902; de-
monstrator Central Institute of Agricultural Research 1906-1909; lecturer in botany,
University College, Stockholm 1909; joined a Swedish-Russian exped. to Spltsbergen
1899; botanical exped. to India 1902-1903, Iceland 1911; travelled in China and Japan
1912-1914 (esp. collecting ethnographical objects); Greenland 1916-1917 (died while on
2nd Thule expedition). (<em>T. Wulff</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: LD (herb. rd. 1900). – Further material in C, GB, LD, W.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 526 (b. 1 Apr 1877, d. 29 Aug 1917); BJI 2:
195; BM 5: 2367; Bossert p. 444; Kleppa p. 292; KR p. 778-780 (main bibl.); LS 29394-
29396, 33025, 40733-40740.

Wulfsberg, Nils Gregers Ingvald (1847-1888), Norwegian physician and pharmaco-
logist; studied at the University of Kristiania [Oslo] 1864-1873; Cand. med. 1873; Dr.
med. Göttingen 1880; stipendiary pharmacology at Kristiania University 1877-1882;
physician at Kristiania 1882-1888. (<em>Wulfsb</em>.).

Wullschlaegel, Heinrich Rudolph (1805-1864), German (Russian-born, Wolga-
German in Moravian Brothers settlement Sarepta) teacher belonging to the Moravian
Brothers; theological education at Gnadenfeld, Silesia; teacher in Niesky, Ebersdorf
(Reuss) and Herrnhut 1826-1834; administrator community Neudietendorf (Gotha)
1834-1843; missionary in Antigua 1847-1849, Paramaribo, Suriname 1849-1855; direc-
tor of the community Berthelsdorf, Herrnhut 1855-1857, bishop ib. 1857-1864, con-
secrated 30 Aug 1857. (<em>Wullschlaegel</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BR (incl. Surinam originals) and M; further material in B
(mainly destr.), DR, GOET (incl. Surinam dupl.), K, P, U, W (herb. Reichenbach).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: IH 1 (ed. 2): 29, (ed. 3): 33, (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7): 346;
Urban-Berl. p. 328, 411.

Wurm, Franz (1845-1922), Bohemian naturalist, Piarist clergyman and school teacher;
studied at the Piarist college in Leipnick (Moravia); teacher's examination for biology
and physics 1873; teacher at various schools in Moravia; professor at the municipal high
school of Böhmisch Leipa 1874; ultimately teacher in Prague. (<em>Wurm</em>).

Wydler, Heinrich (1800-1883), Swiss botanist; studied medicine and natural sciences
in Zürich and Göttingen; sometime teacher at a private school; travelled in the West

PAGE: 482
HEADING: WYDLER

Indies at the request of A.P. de Candolle 1827; adjunct at the St. Petersburg botanical
garden 1828-1830; curator of the de Candolle herbarium 1830-1834; Dr. med. h.c. Basel
1933; high school teacher at Bern 1834, also e.o. prof. botany Bern 1835-1839, 1842-
1853, 1857-1874; from 1853 living as private scientist at Bern and Strasbourg. (<em>Wydl</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: G-DC. – Other material in B (mainly destr.), BR, DPU, E, FI,
G, H-Stev. (1 specimen), L, LZ (destr.), NCY, NY, OXF, P, W. – <em>Letters</em> at G (e.g. A.P.
de Candolle), HAL (D.F.L. von Schlechtendal), UPS-UB. – For letters (26) to Th.
Irmisch see Müllerott 1980. – <em>Manuscripts and drawings</em>: left by W. to A.W. Eichler at
Berlin (now destr.), see Bot. Centralbl. 18: 54. 1884.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: ADB 44: 392-393; Backer p. 630; Barnhart 3: 526 (b. 24
Apr 1800, d. 6 Dec 1883); BFM 2443; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10219-10222; BM 5: 2369;
Bossert p. 444; Clokie p. 268; CSP 6: 459-460, 8: 1284, 11: 865, 19: 733; Futak-Domin p.
664; Hegi 5(2): 1032; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 143; Lasègue p. 268, 306, 505; Moebius
p. 240; PR 10427, ed. 1: 11379-11380; Rehder 5: 935; SO 289a; Tucker 1: 755; Urban-
Berl. p. 412; Zander ed. 10, p. 734, ed. 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bonplandia 4: 59-60. 1856; Bot. Centralbl. 18: 54. 1884 (left his botan-
	ical mss. and drawings to A.W. Eichler); Bot. Zeit. 41: 874. 1883 (d.).
Attinger, V. et al., eds., Dict. hist. biogr. Suisse 7: 390. 1933.

Burdet, H.M., Candollea 34: 211-212. 1979.

	xxix. 1935.

Wylie, Robert [Bradford] (1870-1959), American botanist; B.S. Upper Iowa Univ-
ersity 1897; Dr. phil. Chicago 1904; professor of biology Morningside College 1897-
1899; assistant professor of botany University of Iowa, Iowa City 1906-1908, professor of
botany ib. 1908-1940, emeritus professor 1940-1959; on U.S. kelp. exp., Alaska 1913; on
Univ. Iowa Fiji-New Zealand exp. 1923; LL.D. Upper Iowa 1925. (<em>Wylie</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: IA (Fiji, New Zealand).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 526 (b. 28 Mar 1870); BL 1: 220, 324;
Bossert p. 444; Hirsch p. 330; ME 3: 682; NW p. 62; Tucker 3: 342; Zander ed. 10, p.
734, ed. 11, p. 838 (d. 9 Jun 1959).

	1969; Natl. Cycl. Amer. biogr. 50: 618. 1968 (portr.); New York Times 10 Jun 1959,
	P. 37; Who's who Amer. 14-26. 1926-1951; Who was who Amer. 3: 944. 1960.

Xuarez, Gaspar (1731-1804), Argentine botanist and clergyman; studied at the
Colegio Monserrat, Cordoba; entered the Society of Jesus 1748; banned from Argentina
by Carlos III 1767; in Faenza, Italy 1767-1773; after the discontinuation of the Jesuit
order in Rome 1773-1804, head of the Giardino vaticano-indico. (<em>Xuarez</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Backer p. 631; BM 2: 677, 5: 2370; Hirsch p. 144; PR
3332, ed. 1: 3626; Saccardo 1: 174; TL-1/1123; TL-2/9769; Tucker 1: 756.

Parodi, L.R., Darwiniana 13: 195-208. 1964 (biogr. sketch; discussion bot. publ.,
	sources).

prodr.</em>, see TL-2/9769.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Xuarezia</em> Ruiz et Pavon (1794).

Yabe, Hisakatsu (1878-1969), Japanese geologist and paleontologist; Grad. Tokyo
Univ. 1901; at Graduate School Tokyo Imperial University 1901-1906; instructor of
geological sciences ib. 1906-1908; studied in Germany, Australia and America 1906-
1912; professor of geology at Tôhuku Imperial University 1911-1939. (<em>H. Yabe</em>).

yamada, Yukio (1900-1975), Japanese algologist; Grad. Tokyo Univ. 1924; studied at
European and American institutions 1928-1930; Dr. phil. Tokyo 1931; assistant profes-
sor (1930) and regular professor at The Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University 1931-
1964, from 1931 also director of the Muroran seaside Institute of Algological Research,
Hokkaido University. (<em>Yamada</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SAP. – Other material in C, K, NY.

(bibl.), suppl. 398-399 (bibl.); Roon p. 125.

	1966. 4: 589. 1969; J. Jap. Bot. 50(10): 318-319. 1975 (obit., portr.); Japan biogr.

	1975).
Merrill, E.D., Contr. Natl. Herb. U.S. 30(1): 319. 1947.

<sm>MEMORIAL PUBLICATION</sm>: Sorui, Bull. Jap. Soc. Phycology, vol. 25, suppl., 14 Aug 1977
(tribute, portr.).

Yamamoto, Yoshimatsu [born Wakamori] (1893-1947), Japanese botanist; studied
at the Fukui Teacher's College [Normal School] 1908-1913; primary school teacher in
Sabae 1913-1915; at Hiroshima higher Teacher's College 1915-1919; biological teacher
at Kagoshima Teacher's College 1919-1920; studied at Tokyo University 1920-1923;
assistant with Hayata 1923-1928; asst. professor Taihoku University, Taiwan from 1928;
studied in the United States and Great Britain 1933-1934; Dr. Sci. Tokyo Univ. 1934;
continued his teaching at Taihoku Univ. from 1934, becoming ordinary professor of
botany at the National Taiwan University 1945-1947. (<em>Yamamoto</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TAI. – Further material in BO, MO. – <em>Letters</em> at NY (e.g.
Barnhart corr.).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 528; BJI 2: 195; BM 8: 1463; IF suppl. 3:
219; Langman p. 814; Lenley p. 443; MW p. 540 (main bibl.), suppl. p. 401-402 (main
bibl.); NI p. 814; SK 1: 588 (coll.); TL-2/2499; Tucker 3: 343.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Frodin, D.G., Guide standard floras world no. 886. 1984.
Hisazumi, H., Taiwania 1: 7-12. 1948 (obit., portr.).
Musamune, G., Taiwania 1: 13-17. 1948 (bibl.).
Quisumbing, E., Philipp. geogr. J. 8: 36. 1964.

HEADING: YAMAMOTO

Yatabe, Ryôkichi (1851-1899), Japanese botanist; BS Cornell 1876; studied with A.
Gray and Farlow at Harvard; first professor of botany at Tokyo Imperial University;
founder of the Botanical Society of Japan and president of the Higher Teacher's College;
director of the Botanic Gardens Tokyo Imperial University 1877-1890. (<em>Yatabe</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: TI; further material in G. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, GH.

Yates, Lorenzo Gordin (1837-1909), British-born American naturalist (botanist,
paleontologist, conchologist); to U.S. 1853; studied medicine and dentistry; settled in
Centerville, California 1864 as practicing dentist; in various ways associated with the
geological and botanical survey of California, ultimately (1905-1906) Horticultural
Commissioner, Santa Barbara. (<em>L. Yates</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: UC (<em>Pter</em>.) and SBM. Other material at E. – <em>Letters</em> at FH, GH. -
<em>Manuscripts</em>: Bancroft Library.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 530; BB p. 337; BL 1: 169; BM 5: 2373; CSP
11: 867, 12: 796, 19: 739; Desmond p. 681.

Yendo, Kichisaburo (1874-1921), Japanese algologist; studied at the College of
Science, Imperial University of Tokyo (grad. bot. 1901); professor of marine botany
Hokkaido Imperial University 1907; Dr. Sci. ib. 1908; retired on account of ill health in
1919. (<em>Yendo</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: SAP and TI; other material at C, K, NY, W.

Young, Aaron (1819-1898), American botanist; studied at Bowdoin College 1841-1842;
at Jefferson medical college, Philadelphia 1842-1843; assistant in chemistry Bowdoin
College 1840-1841; apothecary in Bangor, Maine, ear surgeon and peddled cure-all in
Maine, newspaper editor id.; American consul at Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil 1863-1873;
practicing physician in Boston from 1875. (<em>Aa. young</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GH. – <em>Letters</em> to Torrey at NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 533 (b. 19 Dec 1829, d. 13 Jan 1898); DAB
20: 617-618; Lenley p. 473; ME 3: 453, 753.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Who was who America, Hist. vol. 601. 1963.

PAGE: 492
HEADING: AA. YOUNG

Spalding, J.A., <em>in</em> H.A. Kelly &amp; W.L. Burrage, Arner. med. biogr. 1279-1281. 1920.

<sm>EPONYMY</sm>: <em>Youngia</em> Cassini (1831) (and the derived genus x <em>Ixyoungia</em> Kitamura (1942))
was named for two Englishmen, a poet and a physician, according to Cassini. Neither
can be identified with certainty although the phsycian may have been Dr. Thomas
Young (1773-1829).

Young, Mary Sophie (1872-1919), American teacher and botanist; BA Wellesley Coll.
1895; Dr. phil. Univ. Chicago 1910; teacher at Sullivan, Mo., 1895-1897; high school
teacher Dundee Ill. 1897-1898; id. Grafton Hall, Fond du Lac, Wisc. 1898-1906; at
Waterman Hall, Sycamore, Ill. 1907-1908; fellow in botany, Univ. Chicago 1908-1910;
instructor in botany, Univ. Texas 1910-1919. (<em>M.S. Young</em>).

Young, William Jr. (1742-1785), American (German-born) botanist; came to Philad-
elphia from Cassel (Germany) 1744; nurseryman and gardener at Kingsessing 1761-
1764; to England 1764; studied botany and gardening; returned to America 1766 as
Queen's botanist and commercial gardener and plant collector; again in England 1768
accompanying a consignment of plants, in the Carolinas 1768, to England 1769-1770,
1771-1772; continued his collecting activities from Philadelphia 1772-1785. (<em>W. Young</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BM. – <em>Manuscripts</em>: BM.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 534 (b. 30 Nov 1742, d. 16 Mar 1785); BB p.
337-338; BM 5: 2376; Dryander 3: 186 (mss.); ME 1: 244, 3: 353, 743; Tucker 1: 344, 3:
343.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Britten, J., J. Bot. 32: 332-337. 1894.
Coats, A.M., Plant hunters 275, 279-281. 1969.
Darlington, W., Memorials 266, 267, 270, 279, 285, 286, 344, 504, 509, 510. 1849.
Ewan, J. et al., Short hist. bot. U.S. 3. 1969.
Hadfield, M., Brit. Gard. 313. 1980 (b. 1705 [err.]).
Harshberger, J.W., Torreya 17(6): 91-99. 1917 (biogr. based on original sources).
Kinch, M., Newsl. Soc. Bibl. nat. Hist. 10: 8. 1981.
Murray, G., <em>in</em> Hist. coll. nat. hist. depts. Brit. Mus. 1: 193. 1904 (Carolina pl. 1767).
Woodward, B.B., <em>in</em> Hist. coll. nat. hist. depts. Brit. Mus. 1: 53. 1904 (302 water colour
	drawings 1767).

18.453. <em>Catalogue d'arbres et plantes herbacées d'Amérique</em>, par M. Yong [sic, for Young],
Botaniste de Pensylvanie. Ce catalogue est divisé en deux parties; la première contient
les plantes que M. Yong peut fournir aux Européens, soit en graines, soit en plants [sic].
La seconde contient celles qu'on ne pourra se procurer, qu'en les demandant dans

Youngken, Heber Wilkinson (1885-1963), American pharmacologist; studied phar-
macy and natural sciences at Med. Chir. Coll. Philadelphia, Buchnell Univ. and Univ.
of Pennsylvania 1903-1915; Dr. phil. Pennsylvania 1915; demonstrator of biology and
pharmacy at Med. Chir. Coll. 1909; professor of botany and pharmacognosy at Philad-
elphia College of Pharmacy and Science 1911-1923; id. at Massachusetts College of
Pharmacy, Boston, 1923-1951; research professor ib. 1951-1956; emeritus professor from
1956. (<em>Youngken</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PENN, MCP. – <em>Letters</em> at NY.

Yuncker, Truman George (1891-1964), American botanist; studied at Michigan
State University, East Lansing; B.S. ib. 1914; M.A. Univ. Nebraska 1915; at Emmerich
Manual Training High School, Indianapolis, Indiana 1915-1916; graduate assistant in
botany, Univ. Illinois 1916; Dr. phil. ib. 1919; assistant professor of biology De Pauw
University, Greencastle, Indiana 1919, professor and head of the Dept. of Botany from
1921-1956; emeritus professor from 1956; collected in Honduras 1934, 1936, 1938.
(<em>Yunck</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: DPU. – Other material at A, BISH (first set Nive, Tonga), BM,
BUT, F (first set Honduras), G, GH, ILL, K, MICH, MIN, MO, NY, PH, S, U,
UCWI, US (impt. set), WELT. – <em>Letters</em> at G, NY (e.g. to Barnhart).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 535 (b. 20 Mar 1891); BL 1: 149, 325;
Bossert p. 447; Hirsch p. 331; Hortus 3: 1207; IF suppl. 4: 349; IH 1 (ed. 1): 38, (ed. 2):
55, (ed. 3):67, (ed. 4): 73, 79, (ed. 5): 79, (ed. 6): 366, (ed. 7): 346, 2: 375, suppl. 4: 349;
Langman p. 815; MW p. 547;, suppl. p. 412; NAF ser. 2. 4: 46; NW p. 62; PH 209, 450;
Roon p. 126; SIA see index; TL-2/781, 15.051; Zander ed. 10, p. 735, ed. 11, p. 838.

	599-600. 1969; Who's who Amer. 20-33. 1938-1965; Who was who Amer. 4: 1044.

Zabel, Hermann (1832-1912), German forester and botanist; assistant at the Botanical
Garden and Museum, Greifswald 1854-1860; asst. forester at Neu-Katzow 1860-1869; in
charge of the forestry botanical garden ("Akademischer Gartenmeister") at Hannov.-
Münden 1869-1895; in retirement at Gotha. (<em>Zab</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: GOET; further material at GFW, LUX, MO, WRSL. – <em>Letters

4(2): 1015, 5(2): 992; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 294, 429; LS 29437; Morren ed. 2, p. 8,
ed. 10, p. 15; MW p. 547-548, suppl. p. 412; Rehder 5: 937; TL-2/411, 11.529, see E.

Zacharias, Eduard (1852-1911), German (Berlin/Hamburg) botanist; studied in
Hamburg at the Academic Gymnasium 1872-1874 and at the Universities of Heidel-
berg, Tübingen and Strassburg; Dr. phil. Strassburg 1877 with A. de Bary; Habil.
Strassburg 1879, e.o. professor of botany 1882-1894; curator ("Kustos") of the
Hamburg botanical garden 1894-1899, director 1899-1911; from 1901 also director of
the Botanical Museum and the later (1908) Hamburg Botanical State Institutes. (<em>E.
Zacharias</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: HBG. – <em>Letters</em> at G, NY.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 536; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10238; BJI 2: 196;
BM 5: 2378; Bossert p. 448; Christiansen p. 321; CSP 8: 1291, 11: 874, 19: 751; De Toni
1: CXXXV, 4: lxiv; GR p. 156 (b. 16 Mai 1852, d. 23 Mar 1911); Herder p. 329; Lenley p.
444; LS 29453-29454; Moebius p. 174, 182, 188; Morren ed. 10, p. 28; Rehder 1: 135,
137; TL-2/14.579.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Centralbl. 57: 159. 1894 (curator bot. gard. Hamburg), 73: 128.
	1898 (app. director bot. gard.), 89: 208. 1902 (dir. Hamburg Bot. State Institutes),
	116: 432. 1911 (pres. Ver. angew. Bot.), 117: 240. 1911 (H. Fitting succeeds Z.); Bot.
	Zeit. 37: 472. 1879 (habil. Strassburg), 40: 495. 1882 (e.o. prof. bot. Strassburg), 52:
	28. 1894 (called to Hamburg), 60: 96. 1902 (director Hamburg institutes); Mitt. deut.
	Landw.-Ges. 26: 182. 1911 (obit. not.); Nat. Nov. 1: 159. 1879 (habil. Strassburg),
	16: 54. 1894 (called to Hamburg), 24: 187. 1902 (dir. bot. gard.). 33: 232. 1911 (dir.
	State Inst.); Nuova Notarisia 26: 206. 1911 (d.); Österr. bot. Z. 48: 119. 1898 (dir.

Zacharias [Emil] Otto (1846-1916), German (Saxonian) zoologist and hydrobiolog-
ist; autodidactical scientist of private means, ultimately associated with the Hydrobiolo-
gical Station of Plön. (<em>O. Zacharias</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

CSP 12: 798, 19: 731-753; De Toni 4: lxiv; Futak-Domin p. 665; LS 29445-29457,
40779; Moebius p. 70; Nordstedt p. 17-18, 34, suppl. p. 14; PH 239; TL-2/see E.F.A.W.
Migula.

1907. Oct. (<em>Süssw. Plankt.</em>).

<em>Publ</em>.: 1907, p. [i-iv], [1]-130, [131]. <em>Copy</em>: M.

Zahlbruckner, Alexander (1860-1938), Austrian (Hungarian-born) botanist
(lichenologist); studied at Vienna University 1878-1883 with e.g. A. v. Kerner and J. v.
Wiesner; Dr. phil. ib. 1883; voluntary assistant with G. Beck at the Vienna Natural
History Museum 1883; "Hilfsarbeiter" 1886, assistant 1891, asst. curator 1897, curator
1899, head curator 1912, director 1918-1922; continuing his lichenological work in re-
tirement from 1922; general secretary of the II International Botanical Congress,
Vienna 1905; Hofrat 1918; FMLS 1925; corr. memb. Bot. Soc. Amer. 1928. (<em>Zahlbr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W. – Other material (often in exsicc): A, BM, DUKE, LD, M,
MSC, PAD (impt. set), STE-VB, US, WU.
<em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) <em>Kryptogamae exsiccatae</em>, editae a Museo Palatino Vindobonensi, cent. 1-26,
1894-1922 (until 1899 with G. Beck). For Schedae see below 1894-1923. 20 sets issued.
Sets at BM, BPI, C, COLO, DPU, FH, G, GJO, H, K, M, NY, O, P, PC, S, U, UC, W.
(2) <em>Lichenes rariores exsiccati</em>, nos. 1-385. 1902-1936. Sets at B (mainly destr.), FH, TUR-
V, W, WRSL.
Nos. [1-267 with labels only] 1-20. Mai 1902; 21-40. Jun 1903; 41-60. Jul 1904; 61-80.
Mai 1907; 101-120. Feb 1909; 121-140. Jun 1910; 141-165. 1911; 166-187. 1914; 188-
207. 1921; 208-240. 1922; 241-267. 1927; [issued with <em>Schedae</em> from 268 onward] 268-
288. Feb 1931; [with K.M. Redinger from no. 289] 289-311. 1933; 312-338. Feb 1935;
339-360 Jan 1935; 361-385. Mar 1936.
<em>Letters</em> at G, UPS-UB.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 791; Ainsworth p. 336, 349; Barnhart 3: 536
(b. 31 Mai 1860, d. 8 Mai 1938); Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10251; BJI 1: 65, 2: 196; BM 5: 2379,
8: 1468; Bossert p. 448; Christiansen p. 321; DTS 1: 333, 4: xlvi; Futak-Domin p. 664;
GR p. 444, <em>pl</em>. [7], cat. p. 74; Hawksworth p. 187, 198; Hegi 3: 500; IH 1 (ed. 6): 366,

Zahlbruckner, Johann [Baptist] (1782-1851), Austrian botanist and mineralogist; in
the service of Johann of Austria from 1808, from 1818 as private secretary, accompany-
ing the archduke on his many travels. (<em>J. Zahlbr</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: W; further material at GJO, PRC. - <em>Letter</em> to Steudel at UPS-
UB

PAGE: 511
HEADING: ZAHN

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 536 (b. 15 Feb 1782, d. 2 Apr 1851); BM 5:
2379; CSP 6: 481; Futak-Domin p. 665; Hegi 6(1): 377; Hortus 3: 1207; Klásterský p.
206; PR 10434; WU 59: 87-88; Zander ed. 10, p. 735, ed. 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Flora 2(1): 29-32. 1819, 14(1): 413. 1831, 15(2): 413. 1832, 16(2): 659-
	661. 1833, 17(1) (Lit.-Ber. 8): 125-128. 1834, 34(1): 336. 1851 (d.); Österr. bot. W. 1:
	124, 137-139. 1851 (d., obit.).
Neilreich, A., Verh. zool.-bot. Ver. Wien 5: 40-41. 1855.

18.546. <em>Darstellungen der pflanzengeographischen Verhältnisse</em> des Erzherzogthums <em>Oesterreichs</em>
unter der Enns ... Wien 1832. Oct. 

<em>Publ</em>.: 1832 (Flora rd. by 16 Oct 1833), Beitr. Länderk. Oesterr. u.d. Enns 1: 205-268.
	1831.

Zahn, Karl Hermann (1865-1940), German (Baden) botanist (specialist on
Hieracium); studied at a teachers college in Karlsruhe 1884-1885; from 1891 high school
teacher in Heidelberg, Freiburg and Donaueschingen; from 1923 professor of geometry,
chemistry and building material technology at the Karlsruhe Technical College; from
1931 in retirement, from 1934 in Haigerloch (Hohenzollern). (<em>Zahn</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: B (main Hieracium herbarium acquired 1941, destroyed 1943;
manuscript, drawings and a number of further original herbarium specimens of Hiera-
cium acquired 1970, extant). General herbarium acquired by Philippe de Palézieux,
now at G.
<em>Hieraciotheca europaea</em> cent. 1-9, 1906-1914. – Sets at B (mainly destr.), F, G, GB, K,
LAU, MAN CH, MPU, W, WRSL, Z. – For <em>Schedae</em> see below (1906-1914). – <em>Letters</em> at
G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 65, 12(2): 123; Barnhart 3: 536 (b. 3 Dec 1865,
d. 8 Feb 1940); BFM no. 6; Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10251, 10253; BJI 2: 196 BM 5: 2379, 8:
1468; CSP 19: 757; DTS 6(4): 210; Futak-Domin p. 664-665; MW p. 548; Rehder 2:
102; TL-2/200, 1713, 2571, 14.793, see J. Murr.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Hedwigia 75: (168). 1936; Österr. bot. Z. 85(1): 80. 1936 (hon. memb.
	Bot. Ver. Prov. Brandenburg); Rhein-Neckar Zeitung 3 Dec 1980 ("sein Name war
	in aller Welt bekannt"; 115 yrs anniv. of birth, family portr., biogr. sketch).
Kneucker, A., Mitt. Bad. Landesver. Naturk. Natursch. Freiburg i. Br. ser. 2. 3(15-16):
	223-227. 1936 (tribute 70th birthday; biogr. sketch, portr., list publ.); Ber. bayer. bot.
	Ges. 25: 158-161. 1941 (portr., biogr. sketch, list publ.).
Lack, H.W., Willdenowia 8: 439-442. 1978 (ills., mss., herb, specimens at B, extant).
Palézieux, Ph. de, Bull. Soc. bot. Genève 32: 192-194. 1940 (obit.).
Sleumer, H., Ber. Bayer, bot. Ges. 25: 161-163. 1941 (list publ., 86 nos.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 5: 196, 197. 1939, 6: 141. 1941.

<sm>COMPOSITE WORKS</sm>: (1) <em>Berichtigungen und Ergänzungen zur 16. Auflage von</em> Dr. Aug. <em>Garcke's
Flora von Deutschland</em>, Deut. bot. Monatschr. 8: 112-115. 1890. (See TL-2/1949).
(2) <em>Hieracium, in</em> A. Engler, Das <em>Pflanzenreich</em>, see below 18.545.
(3) <em>Hieracium, in</em> W.D.J. Koch, <em>Syn. deut. schweiz. Fl.</em> ed. 3 (ed. E. Hallier, R. Wohlfarth)
2: 1697-1910. Sep 1900, 1911-1931. Apr 1902 (TL-2/3804). – For review see Kneucker,
Allg. bot. Z. 7: 214-217. 15 Dec 1901; Vollmann, Bot. Monatschr. 19: 164-166, 185-191.
1901.
(4) <em>Hieracium, in</em> H.G.L. Reichenbach, <em>Icon. fl. germ. helv.</em> 19(2). 1904-1911, see TL-
2/8885 (with J. Murr and J. Poell). "<em>Hieracia critica</em> vel minus cognita <em>florae germanicae et
helveticae".</em>
(5) <em>Hieracium, in</em> H. Schinz &amp; R. Keller, <em>Fl. schweiz.</em> ed. 2. 2: 231-347. Aug-Sep 1905 and
ed. 3, 2. 136 p. 1914. ((TL-2/10.714).
(6) <em>Hieracium, in</em> G. Hegi, <em>Ill. Fl. Mitteleur.</em> 6(2): 1182-1351. 1929. (TL-2/2571).

HEADING: ZAHN

(7) <em>Hieracium, in</em> Ascherson and Graebner, <em>Syn. mitteleur. Fl.</em> 12(1): 1-492. 1922-1930,

(TL-2/200).

18.550. <em>Hieraciotheca Europae</em> edita e Carolo Hermanno Zahn. Schedae ad Centuriam I.
Nr. 1-100. Karlsruhe (E typographia J.J. Reiff) 1906. Oct. (<em>Hieracioth. Eur.</em>).

<em>1</em>(nos. 1-100): Oct 1906 (G rd. 7 Nov 1906; AbZ 15 Dec 1906), p. [1]-30.
<em>2</em> (nos. 101-200): 1 Jan 1907 (G rd. 6 Jan 1907; ÖbZ for Dec 1906-Jan 1907; AbZ 15
	Feb 1907), p. [1]-31.
<em>3</em> (nos. 201-300; 103 nos.): 1 Jan 1908 (AbZ 15 Mai 1907: erscheint auf 1 Jan 1918; 15
	Jun 1908: indeed early Jan), p. [1]-28.
<em>4</em> (nos. 301-400 109 nos.): 1 Jan 1909 (AbZ 15 Feb 1909), p. [1]-29. – Karlsruhe (E
	Typographia "Konkordia". Buehl.).
<em>5</em> (nos. 401-500; 110 nos.): 1 Jan 1910 (AbZ 15 Feb 1910; ÖbZ for Mai 1910), p. [1]-28.

Zalessky [Zalyesskii], Mikhail [Dmitrievich] (1877-1946), Russian palaeobotanist,
born in Orel; studied at St. Petersburg University (grad. 1900); taught at the High
School of Mining at Dniepropetrovsk, from 1918-1943 in Oral, employed by the Geolog-
ical Committee of the U.S.S.R.; from 1943-1945 prisoner in Berlin; to Moscow 1945, to
Leningrad 1946; Dr. geol. 1934. (<em>Zalessky</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Andrews p. 351-352; Barnhart 3: 536; Biol.-Dokum. 19:

Anon., Cat. gén. livr. impr. Bibl. natl. 229: 768-770. 1980.
Houfek, J. &amp; V. Skalický, Bibl. bot. Lit. Südböhmens 96-97. 1963.
Prescott, G.W., Bibl. Desmidiac. univ. 572. 1984.

E.F. Cirkova-Zalesskaja (1964).

Zamelis, [Zamels] Aleksandrs (1897-1943), Latvian botanist and geneticist; studied
natural sciences at St. Petersburg 1914-1917 and Riga 1917-1921; Mag. rer. nat. Riga
1921, habil. ib. 1925; assistant at the Botanical Institute of the University of Riga 1922-
1925, hon. lecturer from 1925-1943; Dr. phil. 1942; also professor of genetics at the
Agricultural Academy at Jelgava 1942-1943. (<em>Zamelis</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>NOTE</sm>: The author spelled his name "Zamels" on his publications up to and including
1927; from 1928 onward he used the spelling "Zamelis".

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: BJI 2: 196; Hirsch p. 332; Hortus 3: 1207; Zander ed. 10,
p. 735, ed. 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Skuja, K., Ber. deut. bot. Ges. 68a(2): 121-124. 1955 (obit., portr., bibl.).
Verdoorn, F., ed., Chron. bot. 2: 117, 226. 1936, 3: 197, 431. 1937.

Zanardini, Giovanni [Antonio Maria] (1804-1878), Italian physician and botanist;
Dr. med. Padova 1831, Dr. chir. obstet. Pavia 1934; practicing physician in Padova and
Venezia; secretary at the R. Istituto Veneto di Scienze e Lettere, (<em>Zanardini</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Museo civico di Storia naturale, Venice, Italy (inf. P.W.
Gabrielson); some material also at BASSA, BM, DBN, L (herb. Kützing), WRSL. – For
a description of the <em>Algarium Zanardini</em> see G.B. de Toni &amp; D. Levi-Morenos 1886 and
1888 (IDC 6357). – <em>Letters</em> at G.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 2(2): 302; Barnhart 3: 537 (b. 12 Jun 1804, d. 24
Apr 1878); Biol.-Dokum. 19: 10258; BM 5: 2381; Bossert p. 448; CSP 6: 482, 8: 1292, 11:
876; De Toni 1: cxxxv-cxxxvi, 2: cxxiv, cxxix; DTS 1: 333, 6(4): 21; Frank 3 (Anh.):
116; GR p. 541; Herder p. 180, 225; Jackson p. 317; LS 29511-29512; NI 2192; Nord-
stedt p. 34; PR 10441-10447, ed. 1: 11398-11400; Saccardo 1: 175, 2: 115, 156; Tucker
1: 757.

Zander, Robert (1892-1969), German (Prussian) horticulturist and botanist; on active
service in World War I; Dr. phil. Halle 1923; assistant at the Halle Botanical Institute
1923-1926; with the Reichsverband des deutschen Gartenbaues, Berlin, in charge of
library and documentation and working on the nomenclature of plants of horticultural
importance; lecturer in the history of horticulture at the Berlin-Dahlem Forschungsan-
stalt für Gartenbau; creator of the Library of German Horticulture, from 1936. (<em>Ro.
zander</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 537; BFM 2363; BJI 2: 196; Bossert p. 448;
Hirsch p. 332; Plesch p. 465; Tucker 3: 344.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., in R. Zander, Handw.-Buch bot. Pfl.-Namen ed. 12. 6-7. 1980 (obit.
	not.); Die Orchidee 20(4): 226. 1969 (obit, not.); Österr. bot. Z. 46: 411. 1896 (d.).
Kaegbein, P., Neue Landschaft 14(6): 285-287. 1969 (obit., portr.); Gartenamt (Berlin)
	18(6): 276-278. 1969 (obit., portr.).
Krüssmann, G., Deut. Baumschule 21: 217-218. 1969 (obit, not., portr.).
Lack, E. &amp; H.W., Botanik und Gartenbau in Prachtwerken, Berlin &amp; Hamburg 1985,
	p. 22-26 (on Zander and the Berlin horticultural library).
L.H., Tagesspiegel 26 Jul 1962 (70th birthday, portr.); 14 Oct 1965
	(Bundesverdienstkreuz); 24 Oct 1965 (id.).
Lowden, R.M., Taxon, Index pers. names vols. 1-30. 811. 1985.

HEADING: ZANFROGNINI

Maatsch, R., Taxon 18: 681-682. 1969 (obit., bibl.).

18.591. <em>Handwörterbuch der botanischen Pflanzennamen</em> einschliesslich der gebräuchlichsten

und Forstwirtschaft, des Gartenbaues und der Industrie unter Berücksichtigung der in
ausländischen Verzeichnissen abweichend gegebenen botanischen Namen. Herausge-

sche Verlagsgesellschaft ...) 1927. Oct. (<em>Handw.-Buch bot. Pfl.-Namen</em>).

Zannichelli [Zanichelli], Giovanni Gerolamo [Gian Girolamo] (1662-1729), Italian
physician, pharmacist and botanist in the republic of Venice. (<em>Zannichelli</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: PAD (fide Saccardo 1902, 1904). Some other material at OXF.
Saccardo (1904) refers to a Zannichelli herbarium at PAV. We do not know whether
this is the original herbarium extant with the family until 1850 mentioned by Burdet
(1979).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 1: 360, 12(1): 315; Backer p. 633; Barnhart 3: 537

10448-10452, ed. 1: 11402-11406; Quenstedt p. 471; Rehder 5: 938; Saccardo 1: 175,

Zapalowicz, Hugo (1852-1917), Polish military lawyer and botanist; studied law at
Kraków; Dr. jur. ib. 1880; combined an active career in the military administration of
the Austro-Hungarian empire with botanizing. (<em>Zapat</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: KRAM. – <em>Letters</em> at G.

Zawadzki [Zawadzsky, Zawadski], Alexander [Jan Antoni] (1798-1868), Austrian-
Silesian botanist; studied at the Universities of Ölmütz 1819-1820 and Lemberg 1821;
botanical assistant at Lemberg 1822; high school teacher at Lemberg 1824; assistant for
mathematics and physics Univ. Lemberg 1830-1837; regular professor id. Przemysl
1837; professor of physics Univ. Lemberg 1849; teacher for natural history at the k.k.
Oberrealschule, Brünn 1850-1867. (<em>Zaw</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: BRNM; some material also in OXF.

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: AG 5(2): 51; Backer p. 633; Barnhart 3: 538 (b. 6 Mai
1798, d. 5 Mai 1869); BM 5: 2383; Clokie p. 268; Futak-Domin p. 668; GR p. 463;
Herder p. 193; Hortus 3: 1207; Jackson p. 266, 268; Klástersky p. 208; LS 29529; PR
10463-10464, ed. 1: 11418-11419; Rehder 5: 938; Tucker 1: 757, 3: 344.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Bot. Zeit. 26: 512. 1868 (d.); Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 263: 70.
	1966; Österr. bot. Zeit. 18: 203. 1868 (d.); Ottuv slovnik naucný 27: 483. 1908; Verh.
	zool.-bot. Ges. Wien 10(3): 632-634. 1860 (obit. not.).

Kafka, J., Verh. naturf. Ver. Brünn 8(1): 53-54. 1870 (monument).

18.600. <em>Enumeratio plantarum Galiciae &amp; Bucowinae</em>, oder die in Galizien und der Bukowina

18.601. <em>Flora der Stadt Lemberg</em>, oder Beschreibung der um Lemberg wildwachsenden
Pflanzen, nach ihren Blüthezeit geordnet von Dr. Alexander Zawadzki, ... Lemberg

<em>Publ</em>.: 1836 (p. x: 31 Dec 1835; Flora 21 Jul 1836), p. [i-xvi], [1]-230. <em>Copies</em>: HH(2),
	NY.

Zea, Francisco Antonio (1770-1822), Colombian statesman and botanist; educated at
the Seminary of Popayan and the College of San Bartolome in Bogota; successor to J.C.
Mutis on the "Expedicion botanica" 1789; sent to Spain for political reasons 1794-1799,
part of the time imprisoned in Cadiz; on a scientific mission to France 1799-1803; direc-
tor of the Madrid botanical cabinet 1803; chief clerk of the secretary of the interior 1808,
afterwards prefect of Malaga; left Spain after the French occupation, to Bolivar in Haiti
1815; with Bolivar to Venezuela in 1816-1819; vice-president of Colombia after its pro-
clamation as a republic 1819; sent to France and England 1820; student of quinine.
(<em>Zea</em>).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: MA (Spanish material). – <em>Letter</em> to J.E. Smith at LINN, <em>letters</em> to
Banks at BM, other letters at G(?).

<sm>BIBLIOGRAPHY</sm> and <sm>BIOGRAPHY</sm>: Barnhart 3: 538 (b. 21 Oct 1770,d. 22 Nov 1822);
Bossert p. 449; Colmeiro penins. p. 191; CSP 6: 491; Dawson p. 893; Hegi 6(1): 155;
Lasègue p. 470; PR 8867, ed. 1: 7904; Rehder 3: 720; RS p. 149; TL-2/9783 (on the
discovery of quinine); Zander ed. 10, p. 735, ed.1 11, p. 838.

<sm>BIOFILE</sm>: Anon., Appleton's Cycl. Amer. biogr. 6: 657. 1889; Encicl. univ. ilustr. eur.-
	amer. 70. 1135-1137. 1930; Brit. Mus. gen. cat. print. books 263: 95. 1966.
Bory de St.-Vincent, Drapiez et Van Mons, Hommage à Monsieur Zea, Ann. gen. sci.
	phys. 5, 1820 (2 p. with portr., KNAW).

Zederbauer, Emmerich (1877-1950), Austrian botanist; Dr. phil. Wien 1903; botan-
ical demonstrator Bot. Inst. Univ. Wien 1901-1902, assistant ib. 1903-1905; assistant at
the Forestry Station Maria-Brunn 1905, adjunct ib. 1906, inspector 1913, "Oberinspek-

1921, ordinary professor from 1924-1938. (<em>Zederb</em>).

Zeiller, [Charles] René (1847-1915), French palaeobotanist; studied at the École
polytechnique 1865-1867 and the École des mines 1867-1870; from 1871 with the
Conseil général des mines; from 1878 as secretary; from 1878 also professor of
palaeobotany at the École des mines; from 1911 vice-president of the Conseil général des
Mines; Acad. Sci. 1901. (<em>Zeiller</em>).

Zeller, Sanford Myron (1884-1948), American plant pathologist; B.S. Greenville
College 1909; A.B. Washington (Seattle) 1912; A.M. 1913; Dr. phil. Washington Univ.,
St. Louis 1917; fellow Washington Univ., St. Louis 1914-1917; special investigator den-
dropathology ib. 1917-1919; associate professor plant pathology Oregon State College
1919-1920; assoc. id. 1920-1924; professor id. 1924-1948. (<em>Zeller</em>).

Zenker, Jonathan Carl (1799-1837), German (Sachsen) botanist; studied theology
(1818-1821), later (1821-1823) natural history and medicine at the University of Jena
1818; private teacher at Dresden 1823; continuing his studies at the medico-surgical
school; Dr. phil. Jena 1825, Dr. med. ib. 1825; e.o. professor of natural history at Jena
1828, hon. regular professor in the philosophical faculty 1832, id. medical faculty 1836.
(<em>Zenk</em>.).

<sm>HERBARIUM</sm> and <sm>TYPES</sm>: Unknown. – <em>Exsiccatae</em>: (1) (with D.N.F. Dietrich) <em>Musci thurin-
gici</em>. Jena 1821-1825,4 fasc. Oct., 25 specimens per fascicle, nos. 1-100; fasc. 1: Aug-Nov
1821, 2: Jun-Nov 1822, 3: Jan-Jul 1823, 4: 1825 (81) p. 238. – Sets at B (mainly destr.),
BM, BR, FH, LZ (destr.), M, NY, OXF, PC, W. For further details see below.
(2) <em>Herbarium florae germanicae</em>, with D.N.F. Dietrich, see TL-2/1: 651-652 and Zenker &amp;
Dietrich (1825).
<em>Letters</em> at G, HAL (to D.F.L. von Schlechtendal), UPS-UB (1, to Brönner).

18.637. <em>Flora von Thüringen</em> und den angrenzenden Provinzen ... Jena (in der Expedition
der Thüringischen Flora) und Leipzig in der Niederländischen Buchhandlung) 12 vols.,
1836-1855. Oct. (<em>Fl. Thüringen</em>).

<em>Original publication</em>: in 144 Hefte of <em>10 unnumbered plates</em> with text, each between 1836 and
	1855 in undated Hefte with cover and with preliminary, also undated, volume titles
	as given above in the heading.
<em>Authorship</em>: Hefte 1-12 by J.C. Zenker (constituting prel. vol. 1), prel. vols. 2-3 by D.F.L.
	von Schlechtendal; vols. 4-12 by von Schlechtendal and L.E. Langethal.
<em>Definitive Publ</em>.: in 12 vols, provided with definitive t.p.'s and indexes in which the plates
	are referred to by numbers not present on the plates themselves. The volumes have
	the plates arranged in <em>systematic</em> order and have indexes.
<em>General definitive t.p.</em>: 1855, Leipzig (Druck und Verlag von Friedrich Mauke). – <em>Flora von
	Thüringen</em> und den angrenzenden Provinzen. Herausgegeben von Dr. Jonathan Karl
	Zenker, ... D.F.L. von Schlechtendal, ... Chr. Ed. Langethai und die Originalzeich-
	nungen nach der Natur gefertigt von Dr. Ernst Schenk, ... mit 1440 [sic] ..
	[Abbildungen].
[<em>1</em>]: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 1-149.</em> – Erste Abth. Thalamifl.
<em>2</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 150-280.</em> – Id.
<em>3</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 284-431.</em> – Zweite Abtheilung. Calycifloren.
<em>4</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 432-547.</em> – Id.
<em>5</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 548-644.</em> – Dritte Abtheilung. Calycanthen.
<em>6</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 645-771.</em> Id.
<em>7</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 772-891.</em> – Vierte Abtheilung. Thalamanthen.
<em>8</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 892-979.</em> – Id.
<em>9</em>: 1855, p. [i-viii], <em>pl. 980-1096.</em> – Fünfte Abtheilung. Monochlamydeen.
<em>10</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 1097-1204.</em> – Sechste Abtheilung. Monocotyledonen.
<em>11</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 1205-1318.</em> – Id.
<em>12</em>: 1855, p. [i]-viii, <em>pl. 1319-1444</em> [or <em>1440</em>?]. – Id. and Anhang.
<em>Copies</em>: G, HH, MO, NY.
<em>Note</em>: It was not possible for us to establish the order of publication of the plates in the
	original Hefte. Many details are available (e.g. through Hinrichs) on the dates of
	publication of the Hefte, but in the absence of a copy in the original order, dating
	remains impossible. One of the copies at NY has the original t.p.'s but the assigned
	nos. of the plates are in the order assigned in 1855.
